Description: Pottery alabastron of Base Ring I ware; hand-made; short cylindrical neck with everted rim; biconical body with slightly flattened base; three horizontal pierced lugs spaced around shoulder; thin, lustrous reddish brown to dark brown slip; burnished; decorated in white paint above shoulder with framed band of concentric chevrons with a central line between handles, dots on rim; fabric light brown; small hole in side.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Alabaster alabastron with a Cypriot Syllabic inscription; ground and polished vessel; long body with curving base; broad mushroom-shaped rim curving downwards towards the edges; stone eroded in places; two small ears; round moulding about the upper part of the vase dividing two lines of engraved and painted signs or dots running around the body of the vessel; approximately 30 signs above and 32 below and each line is ca.13cm long; very regularly sized letters, finely engraved and showing traces of red paint; division marks between groups but no obvious starting point for the text.
Dimensions: Height: 23 centimetres; Length: 13 centimetres inscription ; Width: 5.50 centimetres max.
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Eteocypriot Inscription script: Cypriot Syllabic Inscription transliteration: (1) · i-le-ka-te-se-ti · ? o-ta-te-pe · wa-sa- II · to-po-ra-te-li-me-lo-we-to-ko ·
(2) · we-ka-te-ti-po-si-ro-ti · ta-o-pe-wa · la-a-ke-xe-lo-ra · se-lo-li-to-pe-pa · Inscription note: Eteocypriot?
Transliteration after Masson 1966. The text is described as Eteo-Cypriot because it cannot be read and even the beginning of the text is uncertain (Masson 1966, 28).
Curators Comments:
The alabastron was discovered or collected by Luigi Palma di Cesnola but ended up in Lang's personal collection where it remained until 1903. When Lang left Cyprus in 1872, he gave around 1500 fragmentary items to Cesnola in exchange for a dozen pieces of high quality (BM GR archives, Original Letters 1869-72, vol. 2). This is possibly one of these exchanges, though it was commonplace for the antiquarian community to give or swap items from their excavations and collections, and Lang says that he ceded Cesnola the right to excavate at Golgoi so he may have been given items from the site before this time.  
The inscription was published in various places since its discovery: by Cesnola (1877, pl. IV, 17); Cesnola 1885-1903, III, Supplement, pl. CXLI, no. 15; Schmidt 1874, 100; Schmidt 1876, 7 and pl. XIX, 1; Hall 1885,  226ff. See also Mitford 1961, p. 45 no. 30.
Bibliography: 
Cesnola, L. 1877, Cyprus. Its ancient cities, temples and tombs (London)
Cesnola, L. 1885-1903, A Descriptive Atlas of the
Cesnola Collection of Cypriote Antiquities (New York).  
Hall, I. 1885, The Cypriote Inscriptions of the Cesnola Collection in New York, Journal of the American Oriental Society 11,2, 209-238. 
Mitford T. 1961, Studies in the signaries of south-western Cyprus. BICS Supplement 10 (London). 
Schmidt, M. 1874, Die Inschrift von Idalion und das kyprische Syllabar. Eine epigraphische Studie (Jena). 
Schmidt, M. 1876, Sammlung kyprischer Inschriften in epichorischer Schrift, Jena.
Bib references: Masson 1983 / Les inscriptions chypriotes syllabiques. Recueil critique et commenté; Masson 1966 / Kypriaka III. Vases d'albâtre inscrits du temple de Golgoi
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Alabastron in light yellow alabaster; ground and polished slightly ovoid body with abrupt juncture to short straight neck; flat mushroom shaped rim with two small lugs (or false handles) on opposite sides one third of the way down the body; inscription of three incised signs, 0.99-1.5 cm high, between the two lugs, a series of three parallel horizintal line followed by a single horizontal stroke 0.6-0.7 cm long (= = = -) and an isolated 'V' with a '=' (possibly a variant of a syllabic sign for 'so' in the main sign group) near the left handle.
Culture: Cypro-Archaic II; Cypro-Classical I; Eastern Mediterranean
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Levant (?);  Made in: Egypt (?)
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Ancient Greek Inscription script: Classical Cypriot Syllabary Inscription transliteration: sa-ko-ma...70...sa Inscription note: After Masson 1966, pp. 30-31; 'sa-ko-ma' appears to refer to a unit or instrument of weight though the actual unit represented by the figure of 70 is unknown. See also Masson 1983, 417 no. 296a
Ancient Greek?
Curators Comments:
For Cypriot parallels from established archaeological contexts see: SCE IV/2, fig. 39 no 38 (Marion); Chavane 1990, 78-80, esp. nos 588-656 passim and pl. XVIII (Amathus); Salles and Chavane 2003, 336-7 nos 811-19 and figs 263, 265 (Kition-Bamboula, Hellenistic levels).See Chavane 1990, 77-8 for a general comment (with bibliography) on the difficulty of dating these vessels on form alone. 
Bibliography:
Chavane M.-J. 1990, La nécropole d'Amathonte. Tombs 110-385. IV. Les petits objets (Nicosia).
Salles J.-F. and Chavane M.-J. 2003, 'Les petits objets' in J.-F. Salles ed. Kition-Bamboula IV. Les niveaux héllenistiques (Paris), 331-46.
Bib references: Masson 1966 / Kypriaka III. Vases d'albâtre inscrits du temple de Golgoi
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) alabastron terminating  in a female figure. 		The lip of the vase and nose of the woman are broken away. The upper part  of the alabastron is terminating in the bust of a woman on top of whose head  the vase's lip was placed. The figure is wearing a thin veil, falling over the hair and shoulders towards the front; the ears are covered. The face is rather rounded with slim, fairly long, oblique, the lower lid is more or  less straight, the upper plastically rendered. The mouth is smiling broadly  with full lips; the nose is short (and chipped). The back is left round. Only top part preserved; black substance sticking to neck.
Dimensions: Diameter: 1.40 centimetres inside mouth ; Height: 4.20 centimetres; Width: 3.30 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.; Cypro-Ionian style alabaster alabastra in the form of Kore, have been dated 575-550BC (Jenkins 2001, 172, figs. 11-12; Höckmann 2007, 189-190,  N36; pl. 40 a-d, Type 5.1, style groups 3), correcting the higher dating of Smith (Smith 1892; Pryce 1928. Four examples are known from Naukratis (Bolton Museum 1966.112.A), two from the sanctuary of Aphrodite (contexts Φ8 and  Φ10; Boston 88.738; British Museum GR1888,0601.15; Gardner 1888, pl. XIV, no. 11; Höckmann 2007,  189-190, no. N35) and one from the sanctuary of Apollo (stratum AΠ 7; British Museum GR1886,0401.1393, previously erroneously attributed to Aphrodite, Höckmann 2007, 189-190, N36). All three contexts are late Saite in date. They were likely made in the same workshop (Höckmann 2007, 190 ). Parallels (Maximova 1927, 128, no.1; Poulsen 1912, 99; J. Paul Getty Museum no. AA.306) include an example from Kamiros, Rhodes (Jacopi 1933, 152-3, figs 181-2).
Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7.
Maximova, M. I. 1927. Les Vases plastiques dans l’antoquité (époque archaïque). Paris.
Poulsen, P. F. S. 1912, Der Orient und die frühgriechische Kunst. Leipzig.
Bib references: Höckmann 2007 / Zyprisch-griechische Kleinplastik: Kouroi, andere Figuren und plastisch verzierte Gefässe; Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 3)

Description:
Alabaster alabastron with Cypriot Syllabic inscription in Eteo-Cypriot (?); long cylindrical body, with rounded base, narrowing to short cylindrical neck; mushroom rim splaying slightly towards the edge; two small lugs on upper part of body of vessel; an inscription, approximately 5 cm long, is incised below one of the lugs in shallow characters, six or seven in number and separated into two groups by a space; the vessel is intact but restored from three pieces, except for a chip underneath the rim and one on the middle of the body.
Two old Egyptian Department registration numbers are written on the body of the vessel (98333 on the neck and, more faintly, 89330 between the lugs).
Dimensions: Height: 29.50 centimetres; Length: 5 centimetres inscription ; Weight: 610 grammes; Width: 5 centimetres
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Eteocypriot Inscription script: Classical Cypriot Syllabary Inscription transliteration: ti-pa-?-i-wo-to-te/ ti-to-wo-i-?-pa-ti Inscription note: Masson restored seven signs but the last element, adjacent to the lug, is not particularly clear. Neither the direction of the script nor the linguistic affinity of the text could be established by Masson but it appears to be definitely not Greek and has therefore been defined as Eteo-Cypriot by default (Masson 1966, 29).
Curators Comments:
Two old Egyptian Department registration numbers are written on the body of the vessel (98333 on the neck and, more faintly, 89330 between the lugs).
The alabastron was discovered or collected by Luigi Palma di Cesnola but ended up in personal Lang's collection where it remained until 1903. When Lang left Cyprus in 1872, he gave around 1500 fragmentary items to Cesnola in exchange for a dozen pieces of high quality (BM GR archives, Original Letters 1869-72, vol. 2). This is possibly one of these exchanges, through it was commonplace for the antiquarian community to give or swap items from their excavations and collections, and Lang says that he ceded Cesnola the right to excavate at Golgoi so he may have been given items from the site before this time
For Cypriot parallels from established archaeological contexts see: SCE IV/2, fig. 39 no 38 (Marion); Chavane 1990, 78-80, esp. nos 588-656 passim and pl. XVIII (Amathus); Salles and Chavane 2003, 336-7 nos 811-19 and figs 263, 265 (Kition-Bamboula, Hellenistic levels). See Chavane 1990, 77-8 for a general comment (with bibliography) on the difficulty of dating these vessels on form alone. 
Bibliography:
Chavane M.-J. 1990, La nécropole d'Amathonte. Tombs 110-385. IV. Les petits objets (Nicosia).
Salles J.-F. and Chavane M.-J. 2003, 'Les petits objets' in J.-F. Salles ed. Kition-Bamboula IV. Les niveaux héllenistiques (Paris), 331-46.
Bib references: Masson 1966 / Kypriaka III. Vases d'albâtre inscrits du temple de Golgoi; Masson 1983 / Les inscriptions chypriotes syllabiques. Recueil critique et commenté

Description:
Pottery white-ground alabastron (oil or perfume flask) with figural scene and a 'kalos' inscription; wheel-made; elongated body with a rounded base; narrow, slightly concave neck with a mushroom lip; pair of opposing lugs at the upper part of the vessel. Made of fine buff-orange clay with a white slip or ground, decorated with black and yellow; vessel restored from fragments and reconstructed in places (especially parts of the lower body).  
Above and below the figural scene are tongues painted in black, on the bottom a rosette in red on black; on either side of the vase an ear in red. The pictorial scene shows a Bacchic ceremony. On the left is a Maenad to right, with hair in a tuft at the back, and a yellow plume (?), long yellow chiton and white himation over her shoulders, holding out a phiale in left hand. Before her is a crane to right, painted black, with yellow feathers on head and breast. On the right is a Maenad rushing towards the other, with sphendone and cap over her hair, chiton and himation as the other, sandals, and nebris tied at the neck, holding a laurel-branch in either hand. Around the flask just below the shoulder is an inscription in Greek alphabetic script naming Pasiades as the potter; around the mouth proclaims 'the boy is handsome [kalos]'.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Group of the Paidikos Alabastra;  Made by: Pasiades (potter)
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription position: Top Inscription language: Greek Inscription script: Greek Inscription quoted: (1) Above design: ΠΑΣΙΑΔΕΣ : EΠOIEΣEN, πασίάδης έποίησεν. 
(2) On the top of the vase: ΗΟΠΑΙΣΚΑΛOΣ, ό παϊς καλός. Inscription translation: (1) Pasiades made it
(2) The boy is handsome
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
J.H.S. viii. pl. 82, pp. 291, 318; The Owl (Science Suppl.), Nikosia, 1 Sept. 1888, pl. 1, p. 5 (Duemmler); Class. Rev. i. p. 25; Klein, Meistersig. p. 222; Duemmler, Bonner Stud. p. 80.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; ARV / Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters; Gjerstad et al. GGAPC / Greek Geometric and Archaic pottery found in Cyprus; Childs et al. 2012 / City of gold. The archaeology of Polis Chrysochous, Cyprus
Exhibition history:
Exhibited:
2006 8 Jun-4 Sep, Los Angeles, The Getty Villa, The Colors of Clay
October 2012-January 2013, USA, Princeton, Princeton University Art Museum, 'City of Gold: Tomb and Temple in Ancient Cyprus'.

Description: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) alabastron with pointed end. The top and rim of the alabastron is lost. On the right is sculptured the left forearm (wearing long sleeved garment?) and hand (fist, with thumb extended) hanging down straight, very small vestiges of right elbow (bent) on the other side. The back is left round. Roughly drilled hole, 1.5cm in diameter. Broken off at the top.
Dimensions: Width: 4.30 - 4.40 centimetres; Diameter: 1.50 centimetres; Height: 20.40 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.; Marked in pencil Φ10 (Sanctuary of Aphrodite context 10). The 0, looks like it has been later modified into a 2, or underlined. Cypro-Ionian style alabaster alabastra in the form of Kore, have been dated 575-550BC (Jenkins 2001, 172, figs. 11-12; Höckmann 2007, 189-190,  N36; pl. 40 a-d, Type 5.1, style groups 3), correcting the higher dating of Smith (Smith 1892; Pryce 1928. Four examples are known from Naukratis (Bolton Museum 1966.112.A), two from the sanctuary of Aphrodite (contexts Φ8 and  Φ10; Boston 88.738; British Museum GR1888,0601.15; Gardner 1888, pl. XIV, no. 11; Höckmann 2007,  189-190, no. N35) and one from the sanctuary of Apollo (stratum AΠ 7; British Museum GR1886,0401.1393, previously erroneously attributed to Aphrodite, Höckmann 2007, 189-190, N36). All three contexts are late Saite in date. They were likely made in the same workshop (Höckmann 2007, 190 ). Parallels (Maximova 1927, 128, no.1; Poulsen 1912, 99; J. Paul Getty Museum no. AA.306) include an example from Kamiros, Rhodes (Jacopi 1933, 152-3, figs 181-2).
Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7.
Maximova, M. I. 1927. Les Vases plastiques dans l’antoquité (époque archaïque). Paris.
Poulsen, P. F. S. 1912, Der Orient und die frühgriechische Kunst. Leipzig.
Bib references: Höckmann 2007 / Zyprisch-griechische Kleinplastik: Kouroi, andere Figuren und plastisch verzierte Gefässe; Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 3)

Description:
Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) alabastron with pointed end; terminating in a female figure.
The lip of the vase and nose of the woman are broken away. The upper part of the alabastron is terminating in the bust of a woman on top of whose head the vase's lip was placed. The figure is wearing a long-sleeved garment and a thin veil, falling over the hair and shoulders towards the front; the ears are not covered and the veil might as well be a wig-like hairstyle. She is wearing a necklace which is falling down to her breasts which she clasps with her right hand; alternatively it has been suggested that she is holding another object thus covering the necklace. The left arm is hanging at the side, the fingers are clenched with the thumb projecting. The face is rather rounded with a pointed chin. The slim oblique eyes are fairly long, the lower lid is more or less straight, the upper plastically rendered. The mouth is smiling broadly with full lips; the nose is short with a broadening tip. The back is left round.
Curators Comments:
Marked in pencil Φ8 (Sanctuary of Aphrodite context 8). The 8 is partially erased and faint, so a 5 is possible.
Cypro-Ionian style alabaster alabastra in the form of Kore, have been dated 575-550BC (Jenkins 2001, 172, figs. 11-12; Höckmann 2007, 189-190,  N36; pl. 40 a-d, Type 5.1, style groups 3), correcting the higher dating of Smith (Smith 1892; Pryce 1928. Four examples are known from Naukratis (Bolton Museum 1966.112.A), two from the sanctuary of Aphrodite (contexts Φ8 and  Φ10; Boston 88.738; British Museum GR1888,0601.15; Gardner 1888, pl. XIV, no. 11; Höckmann 2007,  189-190, no. N35) and one from the sanctuary of Apollo (stratum AΠ 7; British Museum GR1886,0401.1393, previously erroneously attributed to Aphrodite, Höckmann 2007, 189-190, N36). All three contexts are late Saite in date. They were likely made in the same workshop (Höckmann 2007, 190 ). Parallels (Maximova 1927, 128, no.1; Poulsen 1912, 99; J. Paul Getty Museum no. AA.306) include an example from Kamiros, Rhodes (Jacopi 1933, 152-3, figs 181-2).
Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7.
Maximova, M. I. 1927. Les Vases plastiques dans l’antoquité (époque archaïque). Paris.

Bib references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum; Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II; Höckmann 2007 / Zyprisch-griechische Kleinplastik: Kouroi, andere Figuren und plastisch verzierte Gefässe; Jenkins 2001 / Archaic Kouroi in Naucratis: The Case for Cypriot Origin; Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 3)

Description:
Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) alabastron, terminating in a female figure, fragment.
Upper part of an alabastron in the shape of a woman. Preserved from the lip down to below the right elbow; the lip is damaged, the back of the nose broken away. The woman is wearing a long-sleeved garment which is combined with a veil leaving the ears uncovered and falling over the shoulders towards the front. The left arm is hanging down at the side, the right is angled with the clenched hand with the horizontally pointing thumb resting right below the pointy breasts. Indications of jewellery are missing but were possibly painted onto the surface. Therather plump face has slim flat eyes and a small, slightly smiling mouth. The entire surface is worn.
Curators Comments:
Marked in pencil AΠ7 (Sanctuary of Apollo stratum AΠ7). The pencil mark has faded, or has been cleaned off in part. 
Cypro-Ionian style alabaster alabastra in the form of Kore, have been dated 575-550BC (Jenkins 2001, 172, figs. 11-12; Höckmann 2007, 189-190,  N36; pl. 40 a-d, Type 5.1, style groups 3), correcting the higher dating of Smith (Smith 1892; Pryce 1928. Four examples are known from Naukratis (Bolton Museum 1966.112.A), two from the sanctuary of Aphrodite (contexts Φ8 and  Φ10; Boston 88.738; British Museum GR1888,0601.15; Gardner 1888, pl. XIV, no. 11; Höckmann 2007,  189-190, no. N35) and one from the sanctuary of Apollo (stratum AΠ 7; British Museum GR1886,0401.1393, previously erroneously attributed to Aphrodite, Höckmann 2007, 189-190, N36). All three contexts are late Saite in date. They were likely made in the same workshop (Höckmann 2007, 190 ). Parallels (Maximova 1927, 128, no.1; Poulsen 1912, 99; J. Paul Getty Museum no. AA.306) include an example from Kamiros, Rhodes (Jacopi 1933, 152-3, figs 181-2).

Maximova, M. I. 1927. Les Vases plastiques dans l’antoquité (époque archaïque). Paris.
Poulsen, P. F. S. 1912, Der Orient und die frühgriechische Kunst. Leipzig.

Description: Pottery: White painted ware amphora; squat body with small foot, wide neck with flat rim; decoration of bands and wavy-line; incomplete, partly repaired.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery amphora; ovoid body with cylindrical neck; vertical handles with knobs; drab slip; dull black painted decoration of bands and lattice-panels on neck, bands and waxy-lines on body; surface worn.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Large pottery amphora (storage jar) in White Painted/Bichrome ware; wheel-made. Ovoid body; tall concave neck with an everted rim; pair of opposing handles just below the shoulder. Made of buff-pink clay decorated in Bichrome technique: black horizontal bands and wavy lines around the body and neck, lattice-triangles on the shoulder, panels of lattices on the neck. Purple band just below the mouth, below which is a band of short vertical lines.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery amphora (jar) in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular-biconical on a ring base; wide neck and out-curving rim; pair of opposing flat handles. Made of thick buff clay decorated with blank and red paint: black bands and concentirc circles on body, red band beneath lip.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Large pottery amphora with ovoid body and high cylindrical neck; vertical handles; drab slip; black and purple painted decoration of chequered lozenges and vertical zig-zag between sets of six parallel lines.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Levant (?);  Made in: Egypt (?)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery amphora; Bucchero Wheelmade ware; wheel-made; tapering neck with slightly stepped rim, four horizontal ridges on flat rim exterior; two vertical handles with thumb grips from below rim to shoulder; low ridge at neck to body join; elongated ovoid body with ring base; decorated with flat vertical relief ridges down body, formed by shaving clay either side of ridge; thin matt mottled red to black slip; fabric buff.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery: White Painted I ware amphora; wheel-made; ovoid-globular body on a low ring base; tall cylindrical neck with slightly concave sides; everted rim; pair of opposing loop handles; on the base of the neck mid-way between handles is a conical knobs; made of buff clay with with small inclusions with surface fired a cream-buff finish; decorated with brown matt paint: hatched triangles on the shoulder and a large horizontal wavy lines on the body, solid paint on the neck, base and handles (the latter now very worn).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery jar (amphora) in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; piriform/ovoid-biconical body on a low pedestal foot; short, slightly convex neck with a squared, everted rim; pair of opposing vertical double-ribbed handles. Made of orange-buff clay, fired to a light cream colour, with purple and black-brown decoration: wavy line around the neck; on the shoulder, chevrons and semi-concentrics, concentric with solar (?) rays, and vertical files of zig-zags framed by parallel lines; horizontal bands of various widths around the body and foot, and inside neck; solid paint on handles.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome V ware (Polychrome variety); globular-ovoid body on a low ring base; tall, wide neck splaying upwards to an everted, rolled rim; pair of opposing horizontal loop handles; cream-buff clay and slip, decorated in brown to purple and red paint in a dense 'close' style of parallel bands and registers: between the handles are hatched or filled triangles, lozenges or panels, below is a frieze of lotus calices, above on the shoulder narrower bands of tongue-like semi-circles, white dots on black, leaves, hatched or solid triangles, on the neck large rosettes in panels and other vegetal motifs, under the handles are five vertical rows of chevrons in black or purple and smaller panels with leaves, lattice motifs and oblongs; vase repaired from fragments and much restored in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Small pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; ovoid-globular body on a flat, slightly concave base; concave neck and flaring everted rim (part missing); pair of opposing horizontal loop handles; buff clay and slip, decorated in black, purple and yellow paint: bands on the body and a zig-zag band on the neck; surface worn.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Large pottery amphora in White Painted ware with a painted Cypriot Syllabic inscription recording the name of Onasilos; wheelmade; ovoid body on a large ring base; wide cylindrical neck with an off-set squared rim ; pair of large opposing loop handles; buff clay and cream slip, decorated with matt brown paint: bands on the body and neck; lotus buds on the body; a zig-zag motif on the rim; solid paint on the handles and base; the inscription on the shoulder of the vase consists of five characters, arranged sinistroverse, in brown paint; much of the vase, including some of the decoration, is restored.
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription position: Shoulder of vase Inscription language: Ancient Greek Inscription script: Cypriot Syllabic Inscription transliteration: o-na-si-lo-se Inscription translation: Onasilos Inscription note: After Masson ICS no. 147, p. 169 who follows Meister 1890.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Masson 1983 / Les inscriptions chypriotes syllabiques. Recueil critique et commenté; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti

Description: Pottery Bucchero Handmade ware amphora; hand-made; vertically-ridged ovoid body; ring base; triple-ridged handles with thumb-pieces projections; thin, matt dark brown self slip.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Dimensions: Diameter: 7 centimetres rim ; Diameter: 12.10 centimetres; Height: 21 centimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; biconical-ovoid body on a low foot; wide cylindrical neck, tapering upwards to a thick, rolled rim; pair of large, opposing loop handles; buff clay and slip, decorated in brown, purple and white paint: large chequered and geometrically composed panels on body between the handles, the latter based on triangles and lotuses; narrower parallel bands on neck filled with hatched and solid triangles, chevrons, tongues, wavy bands, groups of white dots on dark etc; plain bands on the lower part of the body; chevron and ladder motif on the handle; solid foot; bands inside the mouth; rings on the lip.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery amphora with straight neck in a variant of White Painted/ Bichrome ware; wheelmade; globular-ovoid body on a rounded ring base; short conical neck with a thick swelling rim; pair of opposing loop handles; fairly coarse cream-buff clay covered with a similar slip, over which has been added a dark brown slip on body, with added white details: lattice pattern framed by horizontal bands between the handles, with a row of small dots at the junction of neck and body, narrow bands on the neck and rim; surface very worn and encrusted; body dented in places, probably during firing.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery jar (amphora) in Bichrome ware; wheelmade; ovoid body on a ring base; narrow neck; made of buff clay decorated with black and purple painted decoration: lattice-pattern on body and horizontal bands above and below.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus
Acq notes (acq): The vase arrived in the Museum with the rest of the Amathus material in 1894 but was not apparently registered at this time. At some point from 1912 onwards, its BM vase catalogue number seems to have been added to the wrong entry in the GR 1894,11-1. sequence. This was corrected by Don Bailey in 1978 who assigned it the current registration number by adding it to the end of the 1894 sequence.

Description: Miniature White Painted V amphora with a painted Cypro-Syllabic inscription; wheel-made; piriform-biconical body on a flat base; short neck with a plain rim; pair of tall loop handles; made of buff clay decorated with dull black paint: on one side is a horned face on the lower one side, possibly a deity or apotropaic figure such as Bes; on the other side a painted inscription in the Cypro-Syllabic script, four characters probably reading from left to right. Made of fine buff clay decorated with black paint: apart from the human head, there are vertical bands on the body and handles.
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription script: Cypriot Syllabic Inscription transliteration: pi- ?- ? - se Inscription note: According to Massimo Perna (e-mail of October 2015), the first character on the left is a 'pi' and the last a 'se' but the two characters in between are uncertain. The 'se' might represent the genitive ending of a word, such as a name, in which case this could be a possessive formula indicating ownership or dedication (e.g. I belong to X, a human or a deity).
Curators Comments: Walters' catalogue of vases assigned this item to Tomb 17, possibly based on a number written on the object that is no longer visible. However, no inventory of tombs has survived and the archival sources preserved in the Department of Greece and Rome suggest that none was ever made. Furthermore, the numbers written on the three terracotta figures found in the same tomb in 1899 (GR 1899,12-29.1-3) are all different - respectively 4, 9 and 21 (i.e. two numbers on one object), and 2 - and clearly do not represent tomb tombs.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Assoc name: Representation of: Bes (?);  Representation of: Great God of Cyprus (?)

Description: Pottery storage jar (amphora) in Red Slip ware; hand-made; spherical body on a round base; short neck with a horizontal everted rim; pair of opposing arched, horizontal handles; made of buff clay covered with a thin lustrous slip, fired a reddish-brown colour; decorated with raised bands and wavy-lines; rim chipped and surface worn in places with much accretion.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery amphora or jar in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; short cylindrical neck with a flat everted rim; pair of opposing handles from shoulder to mouth; made of fine buff clay covered with an orange slip, decorated with black paint: small groups of concentric circles on the shoulder, bands of thick lines around the body, solid paint on the handles and rim; repaired from sherds with some parts of the body missing; one of the handles is chipped; paint worn in places.
Curators Comments:
For the type see SCE IV/2, fig. XL, 2. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District  Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery amphora (jar) in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a low ring base; tall splaying neck with a rolled everted rim; pair of opposing loop handles (oval section). Made of buff clay decorated with red and black paint: bands around the body and body, separating friezes of hatching and dots (on the neck and shoulder), wand intersecting lines on both sides of the body. Surface scratched and worn in places.
Curators Comments: SCE IV/2, fig. L-LI passim for the shape in Bichrome Ware and fig. LV, no. 3 for the shape in Bichrome Red II ware.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; wide cylinidrical neck with a thick, rolled rim; pair of large opposing vertical loop handles; made of buff clay with similar slip, decorated with brown and purple painted decoration: alternating branch and spear motifs on body; lozenges on the neck; parallel bands on the neck and lower body.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome V ware reconstructed from fragments; ovoid-globular body; cylindrical neck with an everted, rounded rim; ring base; two horizontal handles; buff slip, decorated in red and black paint with incised details; the central frieze of figures is framed below by lotus blossoms and above by registers of floral motifs and parallel lines; the central panel depicts feasting in a wood represented by three evenly spaced trees with birds in the branches; some of the figures are reclining under the trees, two are standing playing or holding musical instruments, one (perhaps a servant) carries a jug.
Curators Comments:
Belongs to the Amathus Style which is influenced by Attic Black Figure, especially in the use of incised details. See Raptou 1999 for its possible cultic significance and Stach 2007, 47 and fig. 10 for its place within CG and CA banquetting scenes on Cypriot vases. 
Additional bibliography: 
Des Gagniers J. 1972, 'Une fête champêtre sur une amphore d'Amathonte', Revue Archéologique, 53-6
Reyes A 1994, Archaic Cyprus. A study of the textual and archaeological evidence (Oxford), 1994, 111 and pl. 32.
Raptou E 1999, 'Une "fête champêtre" à Amathonte et le culte d'Héra à Chypre', RDAC, 207-221 
Stach Y. 2007, ‘Bankettszenen in der Cypro-geometrischen und –archaischen Vasenmalerei als Beispiels für Akkulturation’, in ed. S. Rogge, Begegnungen. Materielle Kulturen auf Zypern bis in die römische Zeit. Schriften des Instituts für Interdisziplinäre Zypern-Studien 5, Münster, 39–64 (p. 6 and pl. 3).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Neck fragment of a large pottery amphora in White Painted ware; wide cylindrical neck with a flat, everted rim; buff-pink clay with drab cream slip decorated in purple-black paint: metopal frame of vertical bands and lattice pattern within which is a representation of a palm tree growing from a rectangular structure divided internally with crossing diagonal lines; birds either side perch on middle one of three branch-like features projecting from the structure; swastikas in the field above each bird; parallel bands below the rim on the inside, on the rim is a group of parallel strokes.
Curators Comments:
Part of the same vessel as GR 1881,8-24.51 (BM Vase C858). It was was found in a tomb the Ayios Ioannis area in the north-west part of the historic town of Larnaca (Reinach 1891, 175). See Nicolaou 1976, 169-181 and fig. 10 for other tombs in this cemetery found in more recent times. Also Fourrier 2015 for a more recent overview of the topography of the town. 
See the comments of the excavator Max Ohnefalsch-Richter (1893, pl. 155,9). Benton (1961, 50 and pl. IV,3) identified the birds as turtle-doves and the square structure as a flower pot, not an altar as stated in the BM Vase Catalogue.   
Bibliography:
Benton S. 1961, 'Cattle egrets and bustards in Greek art', Journal of Hellenic Studies 81, 44-55.
Fourrier, S. 2015, 'The Iron Age topography of Kition' in: Kyprios Character. History, Archaeology & Numismatics of Ancient Cyprus (kyprioscharacter.eie.gr/en/t/AY)
Nicolaou, K. 1976, The historical topography of Kition (Göteborg: P. Åström)
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Available free online via Internet Archive (https://archive.org)
Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1893, Kypros, the Bible and Homer (London: Asher). 
Available free online via Internet Archive (https://archive.org)
Reinach, S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient (Paris: Firmin-Didot).
Available free online via Internet Archive (https://archive.org)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Fragments of a pottery amphora in Bichrome V ware, reconstructed as a complete vessel with plaster, decorated with a female head of Hathor type painted in silhouette with incised details; ovoid-globular body; low ring base; cylindrical neck (rim missing); between the handles (also missing) is a frieze framed above by floral and abstract motifs and below by an indeterminate scheme; the central frieze depicts a Hathor head with incised details on the hair, with stylised trees on each side; the large panels on either side are in-filled with cross-hatching.
Curators Comments:
The sherds from this vase were given three separate registration numbers. 
The vase belongs to the Amathus Style of Cypriot vase painting which is influenced by contemporary Attic Black Figure styles, especially in the use of incision. See Carbillet 2011 for a survey of Hathoric imagery on Cyprus.  
Bibliography:
Carbillet A. 2011, La figure hathorique à Chypre (IIe –Ier mill. av. J.-C.). Alter Orient und Altes Testament 388 (Münster: Ugarit Verlag).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery White Painted V amphora; hand-made; two vertical handles with projections on shoulder; cream slip and red-brown paint; decorated with horizontal bands framing sets of vertical lines at top and bottom of neck framing hatched chevrons. Body decorated with multiple horizonatal and vertical lines and wavy lines. Interior rim with horizontal line and rim ticks. Two string holes through neck below rim.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; ovoid body on a prominent ring-base; tall, wide neck splaying upwards to a flat everted rim; pair of opposing horizontal loop handles; cream-buff clay and slip, decorated in black and red paint: registers of stylised lotus flowers and buds with tendrils between the handles, with a row of hatched triangles above, large rosettes between cross-hatched panels on the neck, solid broad bands of black and red on the body between the registers, beneath the rim and foot (the latter mostly eroded), parallel strokes at intervals on the rim with a solid band inside the vase; the surface of the vase is scratched in various places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery amphora in Black-on-Red ware amphora; globular-ovoid body on a ring base; wide cylindrical neck with a flat everted rim; opposing handles from shoulder to rim; buff clay and a polished orange-red slip, decorated in black paint: parallel bands around the body and concentric circles on the neck.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXVIII, 2. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
 
Bibliography:
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome V ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; cylindrical neck with a thick rolled rim; pair of large opposing loop handles; buff clay and slip, decorated with black, brown and purple paint: lattice panels on the body between the handles, tree or branch motifs under the handles, parallel horizontal bands on the lower body, shoulder and neck.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Neck fragment of a large pottery amphora in White Painted ware; wide cylindrical neck and flat, everted rim with a lug-like projection on one side; buff-pink clay with drab, cream slip decorated in purple-black paint: metopal frame of vertical bands and lozenges on one side (the other is missing) within which is a representation of a palm tree growing from a rectangular structure divided internally with crossing diagonal lines; a bird perches on the middle one of three branch-like features projecting from the structure; the same motif on the other side is mostly missing, except for the branches; swastikas in the field above and below the bird; parallel bands below the rim on the inside, on the rim are two groups of parallel strokes.
Curators Comments:
Part of the same vessel as GR 1881,8-24.52 (BM Vase C859). It was was found in a tomb the Ayios Ioannis area in the north-west part of the historic town of Larnaca (Reinach 1891, 175). See Nicolaou 1976, 169-181 and fig. 10 for other tombs in this cemetery found in more recent times. Also Fourrier 2015 for a more recent overview of the topography of the town. 
See the comments of the excavator Max Ohnefalsch-Richter (1893, pl. 155,9). Benton (1961, 50 and pl. IV,3) identified the birds as turtle-doves and the square structure as a flower pot, not an altar as stated in the BM Vase Catalogue.

Description: Pottery amphora or jar in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a rounded base; wide cylindrical neck with a flat everted rim; pair of opposing handles from shoulder to mouth; rim; thin handles; made of fine buff clay covered with a reddish-orange slip, decorated with black paint: groups of small concentric circles on the neck and shoulder, bands round body, solid paint on the rim and handles.
Curators Comments:
For the type see SCE IV/2, fig. XL, 2. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).

Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Small pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a raised base; upward-sloping handles; buff slip; black and purple decoration including panels of lattice and flowers round body and ivy-wreath round neck.
Curators Comments: For the shape and variety of decoration in this class of Bichrome Ware, probably made in Amathus, see SCE IV/2, fig. L, nos 10-14 and fig. LI, no. 1.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Large pottery amphora in White Painted ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a wide base, slightly concave underneath; tall and wide cylindrical neck; pair of opposing loop handles placed just below the shoulder of the vase; flaring mouth with a substantial rim; yellow-buff clay (some white inclusions) and a drab slip, decorated in dark purple to brown paint: parallel lines and wavy bands on the body, panels on the shoulder with geometric and organic patterns (lozenges, hatched and latticed triangles, stylised floral motifs, a quadruped standing next to a tree, swastikas etc), bands also around the mouth and inside the rim; surface worn in places.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material. Additional bibliography: Payne, ABSA XXIX, p. 294 n. 4.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: Pottery amphora (jar) in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a disc base; wide cylindircal neck with a thick, rounded rim; pair of small vertical loop handles on the shoulder of the vessel. Made of buff clay covered with a lustrou slip, fired red, decorated with black and white paid: bands around the body, and white dots round base of neck.
Curators Comments: The number 33 pencilled on the body of the vase was interpreted by Walters in his
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Bichrome V pottery amphora decorated on either side with a large marine creature with a long beak; wheel-made; ovoid-globular body; cylindrical neck with a thick, rolled everted rim; horizontal loop handles on each side of the body; annular base; decorated in black paint on a white slip; the main frieze on each side is framed with parallel bands of paint of varying width; the large fishes (possibly dolphins), swimming right or left respectively, are painted in silhouette with the scales and eye socket indicated by exposing the white ground beneath; neck of the vase painted in bands of red and black: a frieze of lozenges in black on a white ground hangs just below the rim.
Curators Comments: Belongs to the Amathus Style which is influenced by contemporary Attic Black figure vases (see Reyes, Archaic Cyprus, 1994, p. 111).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome V wear, reconstructed from fragments, with painted Hathor head; ovoid body with wide cylindrical neck and rounded, everted rim; tall loop-handles rising from the middle of the body (mostly restored); buff slip with purple-black and white painted decoration and incised details arranged in horizontal registers: incised and painted lotus leaves on the bottom, above this on one side is a Hathor head framed by stylised trees flanked by bands of elaborate palmettes between the handles, on the other side are three bands of palmettes; above this are numerous bands of floral and abstract motifs, including a band of large rosettes around the neck; the rounded rim is decorated with a continuous chevron pattern.
Curators Comments: Belongs to the Amathus Style which shows signs of influence from contemporary Attic Black Figure, especially the incised details.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome V ware decorated with a painted female head in a Hathor pose; ovoid-globular body; low ring base; slim vertical loop-handles at each side; neck missing (possibly broken and then deliberately levelled off); between the handles is a central frieze framed below by alternating light and dark bands and above with registers of floral and abstract motifs; on both sides of the vase, the central frieze depicts a Hathor head between two stylised trees: details of her hair are incised; the flanking panels are in-filled with cross-hatching.
Curators Comments:
The vase is an example of the 'Amathus Style' (Reyes 1994, 111 and pl. 21), which is influenced by contemporary Attic Black Figure, especially in the incised details, but also by Egyptian and/or Phoenician images of Hathor. For the widepsread use of the imagery of Egyptian Hathor to depict the Great Goddess of Cyprus, see Carbillet 2001 passim; for Amathus, see Karageorghis 2005, 75-112; also Hermary in Aupert et al. 1996, 186.
Additional bibliography: 
Aupert P. et al. 1996, Guide d'Amathonte. Ecole Française d'Athènes. Sites et Monuments XV (Paris: De Boccard).
Carbillet A. 2011, La figure hathorique à Chypre (IIe–Ier mill. av. J.-C.) (Münster: Ugarit Verlag).
Karageorghis J. 2005, Kypris. The Aphrodite of Cyprus. Ancients and archaeological evidence (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation)  
Reyes A. 1994, Archaic Cyprus (Oxford: Clarednon Press).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir William Mitchell Ramsay

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; cylindrical neck with thick everted rim; pair of thick opposing loop handles; made of buff clay with reddish-buff slip decorated with black, purple and white paint: stylsed trees in panels on each side of the vase and under the handles; bands above and below the central panels; white wavy line around the shoulder; files of dots and triangles on the neck; file of oblique lines on the rim.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Large pottery amphora in Bichrome Ware with figural scenes; wheel-made; ovoid biconcal body on a narrow flat base; wide cylindrical neck, tapering upwards towards an everted rim; pair of large opposing handles on the shoulder; made of buff clay with a cream surface (probably the result of firing rather than a slip) decorated with red and black paint: a procession of sphinxes and women on the shoulder; on the neck files of rosettes arranged horizontally between guilloches and plain bands; the handles are painted solid black but the lower body is plain.
Curators Comments: This is possibly the vase mentioned by Percy Christian (q.v.) in a letter to Alexander Murray (GR Original Letters 1896-1897, 13 February 1897) in relation to a vessel decorated with lotus flowers he had sent to the Museum along with the Enkomi material which he said matched a vase from Leonarisso 'in shape and colour'. He may have been alluding to this vessel which was sold to the BM by Christian's associate J.W. Williamson (q.v.) and which may have been obtained from local dealers through Gregorios Antoniou who bought items in the Karpas Peninsula around this time.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)

Description: Pottery amphora in Bichrome ware (Polychrome variety); ovoid body on a ring base; tall wide neck, splaying outwards towards a rounded everted rim; pair of opposing horizontal loop handles; buff-cream clay and slip, decorated in brown to purple and white paint: dense 'close' style of parallel bands and registers: between the handles are panels of hatched triangles and lotus flowers flanked by metopal-like arrangements of lozenges; below is a double row of rays, above on the shoulder is a series of narrower parallel bands with white dots, semi-circles, cross-hatches, 'metope-and-triglygh' motifs; on the neck, a band of alternating brown and purple leaves, solid handles, bands on and inside the rim; bull's-eye motif on the underside of the base.
Dimensions: Diameter: 7.50 centimetres; Height: 21 centimetres; Width: 8.10 centimetres handle-to-handle
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery two-handled jar (amphora) in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; ovoid-biconical body on a flat base; wide verical neck with everted rim; only one of the original two strap handles remains, extending from shoulder to rim. Made of buff-cream clay decorated with brown and purple paint: bands around the body and a plant motifs framed by vertical straight and wavy lines on the shoulder, ladder pattern on handle(s).
Curators Comments: Attributed to [Yeri-]Phoenikiais in the register where it is said to be no. 12 on a now lost list of finds related to the site. (The same number is pencilled on the base along with the site name). This attribution seems very odd given that this is an Iron Age pot and it is said to be 'probably' from Dhali in Walters' catalogue, though the tombs Ohnefalsch-Richter excavated on behalf of Charles Newton in this area were described as Hellenistic (but could have included Roman burials as well). Several other Iron Age pots in the GR 1884,12-10 sequence are said to have come from Dhali, so Ohnefalsch-Richter may have explored or collected material from tomb)s) of this date.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Large pottery jar in Bichrome-Red ware; wheel-made; biconical body on a ring base; wide cylindrical neck with a thick, rolled rim; pair of opposing handles at the shoulder. Made of orange clay covered with a dull red slip and decorated with black/brown and white paint clay: horizonral bands on the body and neck: friezes of concentirc circles on the body and neck, the former superimposed by a faint lattice in white paint. The neck has distorted in firing; hole in the wall of the vessel; surface worn in many places.
Curators Comments: The finspot is not given in the Register but an annotation on the entry by H.B. Walters says 'probably Dali' based on Ohnefalsch-Richter's not lost reports and letters. This findspot repeated in the BM vase catalogue.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Large pottery amphora with figural decoration in White Painted ware; ovoid-piriform body on a ring base; wide short neck, with a flat everted rim; ridge at the junction of body and neck; pair of thick, opposing vertical handles from shoulder to rim; buff-brown clay with a buff-cream slip (very worn in places) decorated with black paint: parallel bands on the body, neck and rim; rough zig-zags on one of the handles (the other has lost its slip and paint); groups of short parallel strokes around the top of the rim; on the shoulder on both sides are motifs drawn in free field: a Maltese Cross with hatched fans, and a bird facing right, in what looks like a leaping or flying motion: the body is drawn in outline with hatching within, perhaps thereby indicating the wings; the long neck, feathers shown as short oblique lines, is turned towards the left, the head shown in outline with two strokes inside for eyes and other strokes top and bottom indicating facial features; vase repaired from fragments but substantially complete apart from some chips from the rim and parts of the body.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Three fragments, each made up of multiple sherds, of a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) amphoroid krater (probably Furumark type FS 53) showing scenes of fish/sea mammals of uncertain species. Wheel-made; made of buff clay covered with a pale buff slip and decorated with black painted representations of fish and with parallel bands. One fragments is made up of six sherds showing a large fish; the second of seven sherds depicting parts of two creatures, parallel bands below; the third comprises three sherds, with a fish with finds and sharp teeth at an oblique angle (? swimming upwards).
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA; Late Helladic IIIB
Curators Comments:
For a detailed discussion of these fragments from the same vessel, with drawings and citing paralllels for the fish motifs, see Crouwel and Morris 1987; they suggest that this belongs early in the sequence of Mycenaean pictorial vases (LH IIIAI or IIIA2 early). 
The species of marine animals represented is/are uncertain: sharks, dophins and tunny fish have been suggested based on various details, as well as the red mullet (see Crouwel and Morris 1987, 45-6; see Gill 1985). It is possible however that no one species was intended by the artist or that an intended one was not rendered with sufficient accuracy to permit identification.   
 
Bibliography:
J. Crouwel and C. Morris 1987, 'An early Mycenaean fish krater from Maroni, Cyprus'. Annual of the British Schools at Athens 82, 37-46.
Gill, M.A.V. 1985, 'Some observations on representations of marine animals in Minoan art, and their identification'. In. P. Darcque and
 J.-C. Poursat (eds), L'Iconographie Minoenne. BCH Supplement XI, 63-81.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery Late Helladic IIIA2a (Mycenaean) amphoroid krater of Furumark type FS 53, restored from a number of fragments. Red painted decoration on two faces of the krater represents four chariots each pulled by two horses and with two riders, in a procession (?); palm and chevron motifs fill the spaces.
Curators Comments:
This vessel was found in a tomb excavated by Grigorios Antoniou and purchased by Percy Christian (GR archives, Original Letters, 26 February 1898). The tomb also contained other Pictorial Style vessels, much gold jewellery, ivory figurines, several alabaster vessels and a haematite cylinder seal. Johnson attributed a Pictorial Style krater with an octopus/cuttlefish (GR 1898,12-1.319) and a conical seal GR 1898,2-25.2 to this tomb  which she suggests was found at British Museum Site C (i.e. Maroni-Vournes – se Cadogan 1992). 
Both the attribution and tomb location are however incorrect. While the present item was said to be found with a crater decorated with cuttlefish, it is far from clear if this is the same as GR 1898,12-1.319 which was registered in the same sequence as the finds from the BM excavation. Purchased items would normally be indicated as such and registered in a separate group. In this particular instance, Murray was adamant in his reply to Christian that this tomb group must be sold Furthermore, the only gem mentioned in Percy Christian's letter to Murray recording the discovery of the tomb and its contents was a haematite cylinder seal (GR archives, Original Letters, 26 February 1898); the seal Johnson attributed to this tomb was actually purchased by the BM from a dealer in a separate transaction. In general, it is difficult to identify the items from the tomb listed in the vendor's letter in the BM collection apart from the chariot crater. In the 1898,12-1 sequence there are a number of items - mainly sherds of Mycenaean pictorial style pottery - that were not assigned to tombs, so some could in principle be among those mentioned in Christian's tomb group (such as one showing rather odd drawn animals, apparently lions which may be the ‘goats’ mentioned in his letter – though this seems unlikely). At the same time, the BM expedition found fragments of chariot vases at both sites B and C so these could account for the corresponding pieces in the group with tomb numbers. It is quite possible that, for some reason, the museum did not in fact buy the complete tomb group, possibly because it had acquired similar objects in the excavations at Marni (but also at Enkomi the previous year).   
As for the location of the tomb itself, this is explicitly said in a letter to Walters the previous day (op. cit.) to have been found '1/2 mile from the place called Bamboula & Vournes in a N. Westerly direction' which seems to correspond with the Kapsaloudhia areas (Cadogan 1992, 125-6). Johnson perhaps based her supposition on the fact that the BM had discovered fragments of vases with chariot scenes at their Site C (Vournes) and Site B (which Johnson placed on the eastern edge of Vournes, but judging by the distances cited, this is in fact further away). 
Bibliography: 
Cadogan, G. 1992, 'The British Musuem's work at Maroni', in G. Ioannides (ed.), Studies in honour of Vassos Karageorghis (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation).
Bib references: Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Kiely 2011b / Maroni
Exhibition history:
Exhibited:
2009-present, Ashmolean Museum, Cyprus Gallery, LT Loan
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: F Barker (More likely an intermediary)
Acq notes (acq): The sherds making up the craer probably arrived in the Museum in 1898, sent by Percy Christian with some of the finds from the British Museum excavations at Maroni and Hala Sultan Tekke. Christian had bought them from the excavator, Gregorios Antoniou. They were sold to the Museum through a Mr F. Barker of Limassol, as Christian was not allowed to sell items to the museum while employed as its agent organising excavations.

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean amphoroid krater of Furumark type FS 54, restored from fragments, with flat rim and flat slightly ridged handles; pink clay and buff slip decorated with papyrus or lily plants and bands on the body, and chevrons on the rim; the foot is chipped.
Curators Comments: The tomb number is provided in the Register but Bailey (p. 12) observes that  this is uncertain as the vase is not mentioned in the tomb lists. At the same  time, it was Walters who entered the finds from HST in the Register and he  may have had a reason for attributing this item to Tomb IV.

Description:
Late Helladic (Mycenaean) pottery crater (wine mixing bowl) with Pictorial Style decoration; wheel-made; conical-piriform body (Furumark Shape 53) on a stemmed foot with disc base; short cylindrical neck, slightly concave sides, with a horizontal everted rim; pair of opposing strap handles from rim to shoulder with a central ridge on each, probably imitating metal. 
Made of finely levigated buff-cream clay, with a similar slip, decorated with red to black lustrous paint, over which pictorial details are drawn in cream-white paint: the neck and base are painted in solid bands of dark colour; on the shoulders on each side are pictorial motifs: each face shows two large, highly stylised birds (in a nest?) facing each other; interior of bodies filled with various abstract motifs: lines, chevrons, vertical tongues (perhaps feathers), s-curves, wavy lines and dots; circle-and-dot floral motifs in the field; various floral motifs under the handles.
Repaired from fragments with some restoration; surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Late Helladic (Mycenaean) amphoroid krater, Furumark type FS54; wheel-made; piriform body on a splaying, moulded; wide cylindrical neck with a flat everted rim; pair of opposing strap handles with 'metallic' ridges up the centre; each handle is pierced several times on the top and bottom before firing; made of fine buff-cream clay and slip, decorated with lustrous red-brown paint: on each side, framed by horizontal bands, is a large, highly schematised cuttlefish or octopus with large eyes, its waving legs filling the frame symmetrically, including under the handles; solid paint on the base and neck; vessel reconstructed from fragments, paint worn throughout, especially on one side of the vessel where most of the cuttlefish is very faded.
Curators Comments: Johnson (1980, 34 no. 249) attributed this vase to the tomb whose contents, which included a crater with similar decoration, were acquired by Percy Christian from Gregorios Antoniou in  February 1898. The Register however does not provide any further information on whether the present item came from Walters' excavations of that of Antoniou.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.

Description: Blue glazed (faience) composition amulet in form of ram; mould-made.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Egypt (?);  Made in: Rhodes (?)
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, 9) as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.
Bibliography:
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Blue faience (glazed composition) amulet in form of male genitals; mould-made.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Egypt (?);  Made in: Rhodes (?)
Curators Comments: The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not provided in the GR register in every case but virtually verything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the large majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenistic and Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items and the likelihood that Ohnefalsch-Richter seems to have concentrated on burial grounds of this period near the villages of Enkomi and Ayios Sergios.
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Pottery aryballos or juglet in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; narrow concave neck with ridge, flaring to a mushroom-shaped lip; buff clay and deep buff slip, decorated with black, purple and red paint: vertical concentric circles on the sides, bands around the neck; solid mouth and handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Pottery aryballos (juglet) in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body with a broad flat base; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a trumpet mouth; small arching handle from shoulder to ridge; buff clat with bright red slip, decorated in black paint: bands around the neck and mouth, fine lines around the body, groups of small concentric circles on the shoulder, solid paint on handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery aryballos (juglet) in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular-ovoid body on a broad, flat base; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a trumpet mouth; small arching handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and light red slip, decorated in black paint: fine parallel lines around the body, concentric circles on shoulder, bands on the neck and mouth.
Curators Comments:
For parallels see SCE IV/2, fig. Also Schreiber 2003 for a modern survey of the ware (with previous refs).
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture and history of the ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).

Description: Pottery aryballos or juglet in Bichrome ware; spherical body on a flat base; narrow biconcave neck with neck-ridge flaring to a mushroom lip; small arching handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; reddish-buff clay and slip, decorated with red and black paint: concentric circles on the sides with a central bull's-eye motif; rings on the neck, red paint on inside and outside of mouth; complex arrow-head motif on body.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery aryballos or flask in Bichrome ware; globular body with slightly concave, disc base; concave neck with central ridge and flaring, flat rim; narrow mouth; vertical strap handle from shoulder to ridge; buff clay with thick cream-white slip; decorated in black-purple and red paint; on each side of the handle, three vertical concentric red bands in frame a smaller set of concentric lines in the middle; three similar concentrics in a vertical line below the neck; black parallel lines on the neck with a solid black band on the handle; red-purple paint on and beneath the rim.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery aryballos or jug in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; squat globular body on a broad, flat base; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a trumpet mouth; single arching handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and red slip, decorated in black paint: ladder pattern on handle, fine bands around the body, three swastikas on shoulder.
Curators Comments:
See SCE IV/2, figs XXV, no. 9 (BoR I) and XXXVIII, no. 9 (BoR II). See Schreiber 2003 for a modern survey of this ware and its chronology.

Description: Pottery aryballos or juglet in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; narrow concave neck with ridge, flaring to a mushroom-shaped lip; small arching handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; buff clay and slip, decorated in black and purple paint: bull's-eye motif surrounded by concentric bands on each side; horizontal bands on the neck; geometric motif of intersecting lines with pendant chain below the neck; solid paint on the lip and neck.
