Description: Pottery aryballos; squat body; small handle; short narrow neck with handle-ridge; flat lip; buff slip; black painted banded decoration, annules below neck.
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Glazed composition aryballos in the shape of the head of  an African, with the conventional concave aryballos mouth, intended for the application of oil, and a strap handle behind. Glaze pale blue of a fine texture, with dark glaze in spots on iris of eyes, core not visible. Facial features well modelled, with  oval  eyes outlined with raised lines.Nose short with broad nostrils, and short mouth with broad lips  Hair line clearly marked with a rounded downward curve over the forehead, and pushed back indentations at either side. No decoration visible on hair. Large ears which may have earrings fixed to lobes of ear. A well-conceived  depiction of an African black, with features which can be paralleled in other faience objects of the same period.
Curators Comments:
Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.; Fairbanks gives Naukratis as the findspot, but the provenance is not assured.
Although this piece is most likely not from Naukratis itself, it nevertheless belongs with a number of other finely executed aryballoi, which form a distinct group within the sixth century faience industry. It is one of a range of mixed-style heads which have very finely observed features, and which display details of modelling which link them closely to the conventions of Saite sculpture. The best comparison is the glazed composition Achelous head aryballos from Kawa in Nubia, now Oxford Ashmolean, 1931.482. (Webb 1978, no 845; Boardman 1999, fig. 148, 127.) This displays the same shaped hair-line as the Boston piece, a shape which was considered typical of the black African, for it imitates the hair line of a closely shaven head, and  can also be seen on some of the moulds from the scarab factory at Naukratis, though in cruder form. (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, nos 8 & 9; Gorton fig.35, nos. 2 and 3 in top line.) However, since this second piece (from Kawa in Nubia) represents the bull-headed river god Achelous, the hair line is stretched right down to the beard and neck.  The modelling of the face, particularly the eyes, is very subtle, and like our Boston head, can only find adequate comparisons with Saite sculpture (Bothmer 1960, figs. 65-67, pls. 28-9, and passim.) Other features are the elongated, almond shaped eyes, with projecting cosmetic lines at the outer corners, while the perforation holes at either side of the mouth have parallels with both Egyptian sculpture (Dows Dunham 1950, Canopic head vase, Ku 16. 19.3, 573, pl. 37, F.) and Egyptian contemporary work in glass (Journal of Glass Studies, 2 (1960), fig. 14, p. 22-3.)
Other related pieces, also with depictions of  black African heads, are the glazed composition vases in the form of a Nubian and a Syrian head, back to back (Webb 1978, nos. 874, 875). However, these are not such finely modelled studies, although there is the same hair line, here with the addition of internal detail represented as of African type with incised squares/diamonds and a central dot in each cell. One of the two wears circular earrings, as suspected for the Boston piece (Webb 1978, 875, pl. XX) and facial features are similarly if more crudely represented.
 Other pieces can also be compared with our black African head- a group of vases where a girl's head is combined with various monsters. (Webb 1978, 131, nos 880-883.) These include (in the depiction of the girl) cosmetic lines on the eyes, a mouth with perforations at either corner, and carefully modelled ears. There is also a series of helmeted head aryballoi. (Webb 1978, nos. 840-844) which similarly have almond shaped eyes, and charmingly combine Greek-style helmets with Egyptian decoration.
To sum up,  the Boston aryballos in the form of the head of a Black African belongs with a finely modelled group of head vases, which are part of the sixth century faience aryballoi industry, and demonstrate close links with Egyptian sculpture of the Saite period. They are distributed in both Egypt, Cyprus, Rhodes, Aigina, and Italy as well as probable Black Sea sites.We should not be wrong in assigning these to  workshops established in a part of Egypt where Greek influence was strong, but was willingly mixed with local traditions, and where trading links with the Mediterranean were vibrant.  
Unfortunately, we have no dated contexts for any of these aryballoi. We can only suggest that there are stylistic links with the cartouched aryballoi, which although they appear to bear the cartouche Wa ib re (Apries) (589-570) may in fact be dated to the second quarter of the sixth century.; Aryballoi in faience are a rare find in Naukratis. Amongst the four hedgehog aryballoi said to come from Naukratis, only BM 1886.0401.1501 can be assuredly assigned to the site (Webb 1978, 133, no. 905, pl. 21), while the provenance of the aryballoi kept in Edinburgh, Copenhagen and New York is highly doubtful (Webb forthcoming). To the British Museum specimen can be added two fragments of spherical aryballoi kept at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston (Eg.Inv.3623-3624). 
All these examples of finds actually made on the site of Naukratis demonstrate the poor conditions of preservation which prevailed there -either due to damp and their making up part of what were rubbish dumps in antiquity, or the damage caused by the conditions prevailing in the 1880's when the Sebakhin were extracting the rich soil for fertiliser. Their fragmentary condition makes it even less likely that complete examples  can be assigned a findspot from Naukratis itself, although this does not rule out the possibility of their manufacture there. See the comment on fragmentary hedgehog aryballoi noted by Edgar in piles of rubbish near the scarab factory. (Hogarth 1905, 134). 
Such containers were very popular in the Mediterranean world especially during the 6th century BC and belong to the Phase III in the Archaic Greek Faience typology by Webb (Webb 1978, 133–5; Webb forthcoming; Pierrat-Bonnefois forthcoming). Apart Naukratis, other Egyptian sites provided aryballoi in faience, such as Tell el Yehudiyeh and Thebes (Webb 1978, nos 907–915).
Pierrat-Bonnefois, G. forthcoming, Some remarks on the place of Naukratis in the history of faience, Proceedings of the first Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th–17th December 2011, ed. R. Thomas.
Webb, V. 1978, Archaic Greek Faience: Miniature Scent Bottles and related Objects from East Greece, 650 - 500 B.C., Warminster.
Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bib references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware; Webb 1978 / Archaic Greek Faience, Miniature scent bottles and related objects from East Greece, 650-500BC; Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt
Acq name (previous): Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston

Description: Glazed composition aryballos,  fragments of shoulder and upper belly, with tongues on shoulder, double horizontal ridge running round underneath, separating the shoulder from the projecting diamond pattern on the body. Glaze now light blue colour remaining, core  whitish, medium texture. On inside clear traces of wound bundle of grass/reeds used for modelling vessel..
Curators Comments:
Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.; For the type, compare the spherical aryballos from Rhodes, British Museum 1860,0201.56  (Webb 1978, p. 109 no. 707, pl.17, 'Early Fine Group, Group 1'). This is a member of the group (Webb 1978, 109-10) with the most elaborate moulding, where almost all the surfaces are decorated. On the concave upper surface of the lip there can be incised a flat rosette, while the outer edge of the lip is decorated with an 'egg and dart' moulding,  normally on the upper part of the outer rim of the lip, with a step down to a plain band below (though this is sometimes reversed). On the body, there are three zones of decoration: the shoulder has broad tongues - which can be flat or modelled - separated from the belly by various arrangements of ridges and incised lines. On the belly is an interlocking pattern of projecting lozenges, which is the most noticable feature of these vessels and very probably linked with depictions of fruit which occur in a parallel series of clay aryballoi in the form of fanciful fruit (Webb 1978, 72, n.5, 108, n.7). Underneath, the decoration is concluded by a flat tongue rosette, which mimics the lip and shoulder decoration. The two examples from Naukratis are fragmentary: one (Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, RES 86.136) consists of part of the central lozenge decoration only, while the other (RES.86.135) has part of both the central lozenge and raised rosette decoration above from the shoulder zone. However, it is to be noted that there are other similarly elaborate types of faience aryballoi:  Group II with vertical tongues (Webb 1978, 112-3), and Group III, in undoubted form of fruit (Webb 1978, 113-114), which have similar but not so widespread distribution. Finally, it must also be noted that there is a close relationship with the cartouched aryballoi, which bear the cartouches of Apries,  and which are found in Rhodes, Cyprus, Black Sea and Ibiza. 
 
 Distribution of the class Group I  is overwhelmingly centred on Rhodes, with examples coming from other sites in East Greece, the Black Sea, Cyprus, Al Mina, coast of North Africa, and Italy. An example of an aryballos in the fruit -like form with elongated vertical tongues (Webb Group II, 112-113) was found in excavations at  Memphis, Mit Rahineh, Palace of Merenptah, University of Pennsylvania Museum, Philadelphia. no. ??? unpublished. But they are not commonly found on Egyptian sites. It is the later forms, such as cruder spherical aryballoi, hedgehogs, and other figured vases, which have a more established distribution in Egypt. 
Whether they were actually being manufactured in Rhodes or in Naukratis can not yet be determined. But the initial inspiration is East Greek and stems from the parallel production of clay aryballoi in the form of fruit. 
The interlocking patterns of projecting lozenges degrade into roughly incised diamond patterns in the later groups (Webb 1978, 119-121) and the other elaborate decorative  elements also disappear.
The two examples from Naukratis in Boston may belong to the same vessel, though I think this doubtful. They can be dated to the second quarter of the sixth century (575-550), see the example from a well dated grave from Samos Boehlau, Tomb 44. (Boehlau 1898, pl. 13, 5, p. 160 f; Gercke and Löwe1996, 57-61 no 44, 11, colour pl. 10.)
Boehlau, J. 1898, Aus ionischen und italischen Nekropolen, Leipzig. 
Gercke, P. and Löwe, W. 1996, Samos – die Kasseler Grabung 1894 in der Nekropole der archaischen Stadt von Johannes Boehlau und Edward Habich, Kassel.
Webb, V. 1978, Archaic Greek Faience, Warminster.; Aryballoi in faience are a rare find in Naukratis. Amongst the four hedgehog aryballoi said to come from Naukratis, only BM 1886,0401.1501 can be assuredly assigned to the site (Webb 1978, 133, no. 905, pl. 21), while the provenance of the aryballoi kept in Edinburgh, Copenhagen and New York is highly doubtful (Webb forthcoming). The aryballos in the shape of an African head – Boston Museum of Fine Arts 03.835 – is also unlikely coming from Naukratis. To the British Museum specimen can be added two fragments of aryballoi kept at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston (Eg.Inv.3623-3624). 
All these examples of finds actually made on the site of Naukratis demonstrate the poor conditions of preservation which prevailed there -either due to damp and their making up part of what were rubbish dumps in antiquity, or the damage caused by the conditions prevailing in the 1880's when the Sebakhin were extracting the rich soil for fertiliser. Their fragmentary condition makes it even less likely that complete examples  can be assigned a findspot from Naukratis itself, although this does not rule out the possibility of their manufacture there. See the comment on fragmentary hedgehog aryballoi noted by Edgar in piles of rubbish near the scarab factory. (Hogarth 1905, 134). 
Such containers were very popular in the Mediterranean world during the 6th-early 5th century BC and belong to the Phase III in the Archaic Greek Faience typology by Webb (Webb 1978, 133–5; Webb forthcoming; Pierrat-Bonnefois forthcoming). Apart from Naukratis, other Egyptian sites provided aryballoi in faience, such as Tell el Yehudiyeh and Thebes (Webb 1978, nos 907–915).
Pierrat-Bonnefois, G. forthcoming, Some remarks on the place of Naukratis in the history of faience, Proceedings of the first Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th–17th December 2011, ed. R. Thomas.
Webb, V. 1978, Archaic Greek Faience: Miniature Scent Bottles and related Objects from East Greece, 650 - 500 B.C., Warminster.
Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bib references: Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt

Description: Pottery bird-shaped askos in White Painte Pendent Line Style; handmade; crescent-shaped vase with a rounded base, a bird's head at one end and a spout forming the tail at the other end; ring-handle on back; buff clay withorange-buff slip and red painted decoration comprising wavy line pendents and encircling lines.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Pendent Line Style (SCE type IIIc)

Description: Pottery askos or vase in form of bird; hand-made; horizontal ovoid body with central ridge along the back; tubular spout tapering to a trefoil mouth; vertical loop handle from body to rim; tail rendered as simple fan; small schematic wings on each side; three short conical legs, two at the front and one at the back; pink-buff clay and self slip (?); decorated with red and black bands on the body, spout and hand; surface, including the paint, is very worn.
Dimensions: Height: 14 centimetres; Length: 15.10 centimetres; Width: 11 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Compare Webb 2001, cat. no. 230 (Bichrome Red I (IV)) (Nicholson Museum);  Pieridou 1970, 98, no. 10 and pl. XIV,8 (Bichrome Red I (IV)). On askoi in general and the interlaye between Aegean and Cypriot examples, see Pieridou 1970; Desborough 1972; Lemos 1994; Korou 1997.  
Bibliography: 
Desborough, V. 1972, 'Bird vases', Kretica Chronika 24, 245-77.

		Lemos I. 1992, 'Birds revisited', in V. Karageorghis (ed.), Cyprus in the 11th  century B.C. (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation), 229-38.

Description: Pottery spouted rhyton or trick-vase in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; spherical body with high splaying concave foot perforated on the underside; the spout is attached to the body through an head protome; arched basket handle with tall boss on top; buff clay with red-orange slip decorated in black and white paint (the latter especially faded in many places): concentric bands around the body and shoulder of the vase framing concentric circles and black vertical strokes on white ground; the anatomical details of the ox-head are also picked out in paint.
Curators Comments: The number 19 has been pencilled on the lower part of the body.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery zoomorphic askos with a spout and basket handle in Proto-White Painted ware; wheel-made; squat body on a raised, slightly concave base; short concave neck and rounded, everted rim; wide curved spout on shoulder; double basket handle arching over the rim, two pierced lugs on each side of the body and another in the form of a bird's tail at the back opposite the spout; orange-buff clay and drab slip decorated with bands of black paint.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Kourou 1997 / Cypriot zoomorphic askoi of the early Iron Age

Description: Animal-shaped pottery vase in Black Slip III ware; ovoid body with a flat base; animal head at one end and beak-shaped spout at the other with a handle on top; buff clay with worn brown slip.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Black Slip III (SCE form V c)
Curators Comments:
This appears to be the vessel shown on Pl. CLXXXIII, 20-21 and pl. CXLVI, 3B of Kypros though the drawing there is not accurate. The volume of the present vase is not properly represented and the animal has a much fleshier neck and no horns. 
See Merrillees 2014 for a modern survey of this kind of vessel, esp. pp. 36 and 42-3 (with bibliography) discussing an unusual example in Berlin. 
Bibliography:
Merrillees, R.S. 2014, 'An exceptional Late Cypriote Bronze Age askos with animal protome', in V. Karageorghis et al. (ed.), Cypriote antiquities in Berlin in the focus of new research (Münster; New York: Waxmann)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893 / Kypros, the Bible and Homer Oriental civilization, art and religion in ancient times

Description: Pottery zoomorphic vase in the form of a horned quadruped (perhaps a bull or ox) in Bichrome Wheelmade ware; wheel-made; cylindrical body on four stump feet; arcing basket handle extending from the back of the animal to the opening just behind the head; simple small opening at the beast's mouth for pouring; one horn restored; vessel made of fine buff clay with a self-slip, decorated with brown and red paint: panels on the side with cross-hatching and St. Andrew's crosses, brown and red bands around the neck, brown stripes on the head.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Terracotta head and neck of a bird (possibly a duck) in Bichrome ware, originally forming the spout of an askos; the fragment is hollow and hand-made, with a narrow tubular neck; rounded head and elongated bill (now broken at the tip) acting as a spout; buff clay decorated with black and red paint: bands on the neck, St. Andrew's crosses with hatched lozenges or triangles in panels on the body, the eyes are also painted in black.
Curators Comments:
The number '17' is pencilled on the inside surface of the fragment. Numbers on other items in the Kouklia group were interpreted by Walters in his vase catalogue of 1912 as tomb numbers, though not in his earlier terracotta catalogue where the present item was first published. However, no tomb inventories have survived, and the archival sources for the excavations suggest that none were made. 
The fragment is very similar to the head and neck of an askos found in Kouklia-Hasan Agha Tomb 90 dating to the Cypro-Geometric III period which had a bird-shape body, three feet, and a central flaring spout flanked by handles (Georgiou in Hadjisavvas 2010, no. 99: KM 331/1) and to an unprovenanced vessel in Copenhagen ascribed by Gjerstad to Bichrome III (SCE IV/2, fig. XXIV, 6). 
On bird askoi generally see Pieridou 1970; Desborough 1972; Lemos 1994; Koorou 1997. The bird-head askos is believed to originate on Cyprus in the 11th century BC, from where it was introduced to the Aegean world, though there is considerable interplay between the examples found in both areas. 
Bibliography: 
Desborough, V. 1972, 'Bird vases', Kretica Chronika 24, 245-77.
Hadjisavvas S. ed. (2010), Cyprus. Crossroads of civilizations (Nicosia: The Government of the Republic of Cyprus).  
Kourou N. 1997, 'Cypriot zoomorphic askoi of the early Iron Age. A Cypro-Aegean interplay', in V. Karageorghis et al. (eds), Four thousand years of images on Cypriote pottery (Nicosia 1997), 89-106.
Lemos I. 1992, 'Birds revisited', in V. Karageorghis (ed.), Cyprus in the 11th century B.C. (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation), 229-38.
Pieridou A. 1970, 'Κυπριακά πλαστικά αγγεία', RDAC, 92-102.
Bib references: Terracotta / Catalogue of the terracottas in the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, British Museum

Description: Pottery bull askos in Base Ring II ware; hand-made; elongated elliptical body with pointed ends on an oval ring base; the surface, including spout and neck of protome, has been shaved with a tool; tall cylindirical spout, with slighly concave sides, rising from the centre of the body; single vertical handle arching from body to rim of spout; bull's head protome on the end of the vase: hollow spout, pellet eyes, plain horns and ears (one of the latter is missing); made from orange-buff clay fired black-red and painted in white with a chequer pattern on the body.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery askos or flask in White Painted ware; hand-made elliptical body in the form of a bird, pinched together at the prominent central ridge running along the back of the vessel; the clay surface has been smoothed with a tool; narrow spout, with a swelling at the juncture with the body, flaring to a trumpet mouth at one end; arching basket handle in the middle of the back; buff clay and slip, decorated in matt brown-black paint: lattice patterns along the flanks with a ladder motif on the back-ridge and handle, bands on the underside and the spout and rim; a hole has been punched or drilled into the body of the vessel close to the spout.
Curators Comments:
The number '40' (?) in blue pencil on the underside of the vessel appears to refer to the original excavations, though this is not certain. 
On askoi generally see Pieridou 1970; Lemos 1994; Korou 1997. The bird-head askos is believed to originate on Cyprus, though there is considerable interplay with the Aegean duringt he 11th century when the general shape appears in both areas.  
Bibliography: 
Desborough, V. 1972, 'Bird vases', Kretica Chronika 24, 245-77.
Korou N. 1997, 'Cypriot zoomorphic askoi of the early Iron Age. A Cypro-Aegean interplay', in V. Karageorghis et al. (eds), Four thousand years of images on Cypriote pottery (Nicosia 1997), 89-106.
Lemos I. 1992, 'Birds revisited', in V. Karageorghis (ed.), Cyprus in the 11th century B.C. (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation), 229-38.
Pieridou A. 1970, 'Κυπριακά πλαστικά αγγεία', RDAC, 92-102.
Bib references: Kiely 2011a / Kourion
Acq name (acq): Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum

Description: Hand-made pottery: White Painted V-VI askos in form of quadruped; trefoil spouted mouth in place of head; short stumpy legs, fused at front and back; short tail; arching strap handle on back;  buff clay with brown striped decoration; clay shaved with a tool; chipped on rim and part of tail missing; paint worn on one side.
Type series: type series: White Painted V (WP V-VI);  type series: White Painted VI
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Large pottery spouted flask in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; spherical body on a low ring base; moulded stepped knob on the top of the vessel; triple-ribbed arched handle; short tubular spout with strainer at front; the base is perforated like a rhyton (or 'trick-vase'); made of buff clay and orange-red slip decorated in black paint with concentric circles and concentrics; below the handle is a large fabulous bird with exaggeratedly long neck, legs and wings and a large open mouth: four sinuous hatched bands extend from its body, representing several wings (at least three?) and possibly a tail or a fourth wing sticking out from the back; the surface paint is worn in many places.
Curators Comments:
See Buchholz et al. 2010, 217-222 for an account of the cemetery in which the vase was found in 1885 with details of all documented tombs from the area (and finds attributed to cemetery); on the vessel itself, see also p. 402, no. 4 and pl. 218a, in addition to the description and discussion in Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974.  
Bibliography: 
Buchholz H.-G. et al. 2010, Tamassos. Ein antiker Stadstaat im Bergbaugebiet  von Zypern. Band I. Die Nekropolen I, II und III. AOAT 48/1 (Münster).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren (executors)
Acq notes (acq):
The registration group GR 1910,6-20.1-23 was originally deposited on loan at the BM in 1886, part of the collection of antiquities loaned by Warren to the Cyprus Court of the Colonial and Indian Exhibition in London the same year (see Lang 1886, 36-8). The paper label on the base reading '336 Warren Tamasssus' refers to the exhibition catalogue.  Following his death in Canada in 1910, his executors sold the deposited material to the Trustees for £15 (see GR Trustees Reports, 3 May, 1910; information also in the GR Register for this group). A terracotta figurine, registered as 1910,6-20.22, was returned to the Cyprus Museum a few years later as it had been mistakenly sent to the British Museum with Warren's material. Not everything in the group purchased in 1910 was registered by the British Museum: the duplicate items from Tamassos donated to museum/college collections in the United Kingdom (in Aberystwyth, Dublin, Mullingar, Co. Westmeath and possibly other places) also appear to have come from the original group of items loaned by Warren.  
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1886, Colonial and Indian Exhibition 1886. Handbook to Cyprus (with map of island) and catalogue of the exhibits (London).

Description: Pottery askos in White Painted String-hole Style;handmade; body is bird-shaped with small loop handle on the top, with the head formed from a beak spout; there are seven string-holes around the centre of the body; made of orange-buff clay with a yellowish buff slip and painted with a red hatched decoration.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted String-hole Style (SCE type XV a)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery ring-vase in White Painted III ware; hand-made; horizontal tubular body on three feet; large cylindrical spout with everted rim; arched basket handle; made of buff clay with a white slip decorated in red and black paint: hatched panels and chequers on body, ladder pattern on handle, parallel bands on the spout, intersected by perpendicular lines.
Type series: type series: White Painted III;  type series: Stewart Type (WP III, Class III F type k);  type series: SCE type (SCE type IXa)
Curators Comments:
The number '28' is written in pencil on the vase. 
Described by Smith (1888, 265, d) along with other items from the group donated by Warren. The group is also discussed in Walters 1897, 71-3 but the present item is not specifically mentioned. The object is illustrated in Ohnefalsch-Richter's Kypros (1893, pls CXLVIII, 10e and CLXX, 9e). The tomb illustrated in the latter plate may be the original findspot, but according to the accompanying text O-R presented objects from several tombs of similar type or date together. It is likely that all of the registration group GR 1888,9-27 was excavated for Ohnefalsch-Richter on behalf of Col. Warren.  
Bibliography: 
Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1893, Kypros, the Bible and Homer (London). 
Smith C. 1888, 'Acquisitions of British Museum', The Classical Review 2,8, 265-6. 
Walters H. 1897, 'On some antiquities of the Mycenaean Age recently acquired by the British Museum', Journal of Hellenic Studies XVII,  63-77.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery askos or flask in the form of a ox in Black-on-Red ware; spherical body on two wide legs; two spouts connected by an arching basket handle: one is long and cylindrical terminating in an ox head with prominent horns, the other is ridge-necked with a trumpet mouth; buff clay with orange-red slip decorated in black paint: a bull's eye design in the centre of each side, flanked by groups of concentric circles within a frame of fine concentric lines; bands on the neck and small strokes on the handle; details of the ox's head are also painted; a hatched rectangle on the neck with a group of concentric circles below.
Curators Comments: NB: Both the date and fabric type given in Kourou Askoi are incorrect.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kourou 1997 / Cypriot zoomorphic askoi of the early Iron Age; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description:
Pottery Attic red figure askos (oil flask); wheel-made; flat body with splaying sides and a convex top; prominent spout with an everted rim; basket handle; made of fine buff clay decorated in red figure technique on the shoulder. The surface of the vessel has been discoloured during firing and some of the black gloss surface is worn. 
On the shoulder on one side is a Satyr on all fours facing to the right towards the spout; it is beardless with a bald crown. On the opposite side is a bull walking to the left, also facing the spout: fairly schematic detail but prominent hooves. 
On the underside of the vessel is a single incised Cypriot Syllabic character.
Curators Comments: The tomb number B4 is pencilled on the underside. It was found with GR 1890,7-31.29 and 32 which also have Cypro-Syllabic signs incised on the underside (see Munro and Tubbs 1890, 48-9).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti

Description: Miniature pottery barrel jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; concave neck terminating in a trumpet-shaped spout with everted rim; vertical strap handle from body to base of spout; small nipple-like bosses on each end of the barrel-shaped body; orange-red clay and thin, flaking buff slip decorated in black and red paint; four bands of parallel lines in black flanking the handle; three lines surrounded by a broader band around the bosses; traces of black bands around the neck of the spout and a solid band in the same colour at the junction of body and the neck; surface of vase is quite worn with slip missing in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Onyx barrel bead; ends chipped.
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, 9) as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.
Bibliography:
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Wheel-made pottery: rim and upper body fragment of White Painted Wheel-made III Pastoral Style bell krater of Furumark type FS 281; drab slip; pinkish-brown painted decoration: heads of two stags (?) or goats (?) to right.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Dimensions: Diameter: 27 centimetres rim ; Height: 9.50 centimetres max
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery Pictorial Style bell krater; wheel-made; reddish brown painted decoration of five stags, two on one side with hatched lozenges and dotted rosettes in the field, three on the other with only dotted rosettes in the field; mended and partially restored.

Description: Pottery bell krater decorated in the Pictorial Style; wheel-made; decorated in brown paint on both sides with a bird (cattle egret) removing a tick from a bull's hide; interior has two bands at upper body and a circle at base.

Description: Silver boss: hollow convex disc with a rim.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Greece (?)
Curators Comments:
Also registered with this object was a silver coin  of Idalion dating 'slightly before 500 B.C.' according to the register (1887,8- 1.3) and a silver boss from a shield (1887,8-1.3). The comments in the  register state that the tomb also contained 'gold cups, with acorns repoussé;  electrum ring with engraving of boat of the sun; large bronze vessel; many  black figure vases; no red figd. vases...and additional items'. Photographs of  some of these are included in Misc. Photographs II in the G&R archive.
See P. Herrmann, Das Gräberfeld von Marion auf Cypern (Berlin, 1888) for an account of the excavations conducted at Marion in 1886-1887 by Max Ohnefalsch-Richter on behalf of private speculators. Many of the contents of the 441 tombs opened during this campaign were sold in Paris by Fröhner in 1887, though the finds in the BM seem to have been bought directly from Charles Christian, one of the archaeological syndicate. The published catalogue details only a fraction of the overall finds, which amounted to several thousand items in total.
Bib references: Jewellery / Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum.

Description: Pottery bottle in White Painted ware; hand-made; elongated body with flattened base; one handle; black chequer-patterns; neck lost.
Type series: type series: SCE type (WP III-IV Latticed Diamond style, IV A 1a)

Description: Pottery juglet or spindle bottle in Base Ring II ware; hand-made; conical-piriform body on a low conical ring base; tall narrow cylindrical neck with an everted rim; strap handle from shoulder to middle of neck, neck ridge at junction; made of fine buff clay with a burnished surface, fired to a metallic lustre; decorated with white paint on the upper half of the body: vertical stripes meeting at a ring around the body; surface worn and pitted in places.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: Base Ring II (SCE type XII a)

Description: Pottery bottle in White Painted V; handmade; piriform anthropomorphic body with rounded base and cylindrical neck with everted rim; string-hole handle at the base of neck is perhaps intended to represent nose and eyes; and applied human arms resting across the body; buff clay with buff slip and brown painted decoration of mainly latticed panels.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted IV ware; ellipsoidal body with a flattened base and cylindrical neck with a horizontal rim, now chipped; high loop-shaped handle from rim to shoulder; string-hole projection at base of the neck; buff clay with buff slip; painted on the body with a brown chequerboard decoration, with encircling lines and wavy lines on the neck.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted IV (SCE type XIV A 1a)

Description: Pottery bottle in White Painted String-Hole style; hand-made; flat elongated body; short beak-shaped mouth and small ring-handle with string-hole at each side; black/red vertical bands and lattice-panels.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted III (WP III-V String-hole style, SCE X C 2a)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.

Description: Pottery bottle in White Painted IV ware; handmade; oval body with a flat base and a short, narow neck with a slightly everted rim; two string-hole handles at the base of the neck on opposite sides; buff clay with a buff slip with brown painted decoration on encircling lines on the neck, parallel lines, wavy lines and hatched diamonds vertically on the body and groups of parallellines crossing at right angles on the underside.

Description: Pottery bottle in White Painted VI ware; handmade; anthropomorphic body with rudimentary arms and feet; cylindrical neck with horizontal rim; spout at the front and a handle from rim to shoulder at the back; orange-buff clay and slip with red painted decoration comprising latticed panels on the body and groups of encircling lines on the neck and handle
Type series: type series: White Painted VI (SCE type Xa)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Pottery bowl (skyphos) in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; deep body on a raised base; concave neck; pair of opposing near-horizontal handles; made of dark orange clay with a cream slip and black and buff painted decoration: lattice band around the neck; panels on body (rosettes, quatrefoils and groups of vertical lines).

See Coldstream (1979, 262, no. 8) for a discussion of Cypriot imitations and echoes of imported Greek Geometric vessels.

Description: Pottery bowl (skyphos) in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; deep body on a disc base; pair of opposing handles; made of cream-buff clay and slip decorated with red and black paint: purple bands around the body, groups of vertical wavy lines on the body at intervals, painted red inside the vessel; complete but repaired from several large fragments.
Curators Comments:
For parallels see SCE IV/2, fig. XXX, 11 (WP IV) and fig. XLVIII, 11 (Bichrome V). See also the discussion by Coldstream (1979, 265, no. 23) of the type in the content of Greek Late Geometric imports and their local imitations.

Curators Comments: 1897,0401.866-871 were originally attributed to Tomb 14 in the register. However, a note made soon after states that tomb 14 was allocated to the Cyprus Museum and that these objects are not from Tomb 14. Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished I-II (mottled) ware; hand-made; shallow hemispherical  body with slightly incurving rim; one pierced lug on rim; polished red slip.
Culture: Early Cypriot I; Early Cypriot II
Curators Comments:
This is an probably an example of what is now generally termed Red Polished I-II mottled ware, specifically a somewhat late version of RP I-II mottled, with diagnostic features of the EC II-early ECIII. Information kindly provided by Dr Giorgos Georgiou, Department of Antiquities, Cyprus  (e-mail to Thomas Kiely, British Museum, 01/07/2014). Stewart (1962, 226-7) recognised this ware as a variant of the 'standard' north coast RP wares found in the centre and south of the island where it is the predominant RP type. Many examples, including small bowls, have been found at the settlement of Marki-Alonia (Frankel 2006, 105ff and esp.  pp. 108-9 for small bowls) and also at the cemetery of Psematismenos- Trelloukkas on the south coast (Georgiou et al. 2011, 194ff with a discussion of the broader distribution of this type on pp. 202-3). The presence of this type in small quanities at the Vounous and  Karmi sites is an important  indicator of inter-island communications during the Early Cypriot period (Webb et al. 2009,  215-19). See Webb and Frankel 2013 for a broader discussion of this issue and regional variations in material culture, especially ceramics, at this time.  

Bibliography: 
Frankel D. 2006, Marki Alonia. An Early and Middle Bronze Age settlement in Cyprus. Excavations 1995-2000. SIMA CXXIII:2, Sävedalen.
		 
Georgiou G. et al. 2011, Psematismenos-Trelloukkas. An Early Bronze Age cemetery in Cyprus (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities). .

Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished I-II (mottled) ware; hand-made; hemispherical   bowl with round base and slightly incurving rim with small vertical pierced lug  on the rim; mottled red-black polished finish.
Culture: Early Cypriot I; Early Cypriot II
Curators Comments:
This is an probably an example of what is now generally termed Red Polished I-II mottled ware, specifically a somewhat late version of RP I-II mottled, with diagnostic features of the EC II-early ECIII. Information kindly provided by Dr Giorgos Georgiou, Department of Antiquities, Cyprus  (e-mail to Thomas Kiely, British Museum, 01/07/2014). Stewart (1962, 226-7) recognised this ware as a variant of the 'standard' north coast RP wares found in the centre and south of the island where it is the predominant RP type. Many examples, including small bowls, have been found at the settlement of Marki-Alonia (Frankel 2006, 105ff and esp.  pp. 108-9 for small bowls) and also at the cemetery of Psematismenos- Trelloukkas on the south coast (Georgiou et al. 2011, 194ff with a discussion of the broader distribution of this type on pp. 202-3). The presence of this type in small quanities at the Vounous and  Karmi sites is an important  indicator of inter-island communications during the Early Cypriot period (Webb et al. 2009,  215-19). See Webb and Frankel 2013 for a broader discussion of this issue and regional variations in material culture, especially ceramics, at this time.

Description: Pottery bowl in Proto-White Painted ware; wheel-made; deep biconical body on three looped feet (which attached to a low ring base on the vessel itself); everted disc rim; four handles, two in the form of horned animal heads (possibly a moufflon) and two simpler looped examples (one now entirely missing). Kiely, Cyprus curator at the British Museum (01/07/2014)). Stewart (1962, 226-7) recognised the ware as a variant of the 'standard' north coast RP wares found in the centre and south of the island where it is the predominant RP type. Many examples, including small bowls, have been found at the settlement of Marki-Alonia (Frankel 2006, 105ff and esp.  pp. 108-9 for small bowls) and also at the cemetery of Psematismenos- Trelloukkas on the south coast (Georgiou et al. 2011, 194ff with a discussion of the broader distribution of this type on pp. 202-3). Description: Large pottery bowl in Painted Monochrome (Apliki A) ware; hand-made; deep globular-biconical body on a ring-base; carinated shoulders; pair of opposing loop handles; concave neck with everted rim; made of fairly coarse but hard fabric, covered with a reddish-brown slip, decorated with white dotted patterns on the exterior (now faded).
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Painted Monochrome (SCE type IIIB a)
Curators Comments:
First published in Gjerstad 1926, 183 (Crater, no. 1) where it is characterised as Monochrome Ware. A marginal note by Don Bailey in the GR copy of this book identifies the illustrated example as this vessel. Åström included it in his Painted Monochrome ware series (SCE IV/1B, 111, Amphora Type B, a, no. 3) but was unaware of the location of the vase. The fabric is also known as Apliki A Ware following Du Plat Taylor's designation (see Kling 2007, 111-12 for an overview and discussion of more recent discussions about the relationship between this type of pottery and various forms of Base Ring Ware and Handmade Burnished Ware).    
Bibliography:
Gjerstad E. 1926, Studies in prehistoric Cyprus (Uppsala).
Kling B. 2001, 'Pottery from Apliki Karamallos', in Kling B. and Muhly et al. 2007, Joan du Plat Taylor's excavations at the Late Bronze Age mining settlement at Apliki Karamallos, Cyprus, Vol. 1. Studies in Mediterranean Archaeology CXXXIV:1 (Sävedalen), 95-227.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description: Pottery knob-lug bowl in Red Polished I-II (mottled) ware (or related); hand-made; hemispherical body on a slightly flattened round base; plain rim; single pierced lug-handle (damaged) at the rim; made of fairly coarse clay covered with a highly polished slip, fired darkish-red. Rim chipped and the slip is worn.
Culture: Early Cypriot I; Early Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Red Polished I-II (mottled);  type series: Stewart Type (Class XIII F2 a2)
Curators Comments:
This vessel was classified by Stewart as standard RP I-II but this may instead be an example of what is now generally termed Red Polished I-II Mottled ware, though the mottling is less obvious than other examples (e.g. BM Vase 30 and 31). Stewart (1962, 226-7) recognised RP Mottled as a variant of the 'standard' north coast RP wares found in the centre and south of the island where it is the predominant RP type. Many examples, including small bowls, have been found at the settlement of Marki-Alonia (Frankel 2006, 105ff and esp.  pp. 108-9 for small bowls) and also at the cemetery of Psematismenos- Trelloukkas on the south coast (Georgiou et al. 2011, 194ff with a discussion of the broader distribution of this type on pp. 202-3). The presence of this type in small quanities at the Vounous and  Karmi sites is an important  indicator of inter-island communications during the Early Cypriot period (Webb et al. 2009,  215-19). See Webb and Frankel 2013 for a broader discussion of this issue and regional variations in material culture, especially ceramics, at this time.

Description: Pottery bowl; wide body with straight sides; single vertical wish-bone handle; low ring base; vessel complete but repaired; buff fabric and slip; brown to black painted decoration: roughly executed parallel lines on base from which four groups of vertical lines, symmetrically arranged, extend to base; on body, six regularly spaced panels framed by vertical parallel lines filled with bands of horizontal chevrons, concentric lozenges, concentric semi-circles and short horizontal strokes; band of paint inside rim; handle painted with short oval strokes; White Painted Wheelmade III ware.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments:
The tomb attribution is not certain. The GR register is annotated '[p]robably tomb 89', while Walters' catalogue of vases has a question mark against this number.  The vessel is illustrated in Excavations, fig. 129 without a tomb number but the item is not included in the corresponding inventory for tomb 89.  
Kling 1989 provides a comprehensive overview of the ware type, with further comments in Kling 2000. See also Courtois 1988, 301 no. 2 for a shallow bowl (without handle) with similar chevron motifs. 
Bibliography:
J.-C. Courtois 1988, 'La céramique de la tombe 501 d'Enkomi 1950 du Chypriote Récent IIIA (Fouilles Françaises C. Schaeffer)'. RDAC 1988/1, 301-5.

Description: Pottery White Slip I ware hemispherical bowl; hand-made; wishbone handle at maximum diameter; thick pale buff slip with traces of burnishing; painted orange to dark brown decoration in fine line style with wavy line and framed running lozenge motif below rim; frontal motif of double wavy lines above running lozenges framed by dotted lines and triple vertical lines; eight pendant sets of double vertical lines to base, alternating longer and more widely spaced sets with shorter and closely spaced sets; the shorter sets have four dots below the rim motif and very fine hatching on the central band; handle with sets of double lines framed by dots; fabric grey; pronounced line of soot and colour change of paint on exterior below maximum diameter, presumably from being stacked during firing.

Description: Four non-joining fragments of a pottery bowl (skyphos) in Bichrome ware, restored with plaster infill as approximately half a complete vessel; wheel-made; deep body on a flat base; remains of one horizontal side-handle; made or orange-buff clay with a lighter slip and matt black and red paint; panels of quatrefoils framed by zig-zags; solid paint on inside surface of the vessel.
Curators Comments:
Marked with an 'F' on the base sherd which might suggest it was found close to the highest point of the site explored by the CEF though this is not certain. The description of the discoveries in Site F include pottery of this date and general type (i.e. Bichrome wares) but nothing specifically with this type of decoration (Munro and Tubbs 1891, 146-7). At the same time, this is an example of what Munro and Tubbs recognised as a 'Cypriote Geometric cup', what are now regarded as local imitation of imported Greek Late Geometric wares. Some sherds from terracotta statues allocated to the Fitzwilliam Museum and transferred to the BM in 1909 were also marked with an 'F' and it is possible that the base fragment was recognised as joining the sherds from the same vessel in the BM, in which case the letter refers to the museum and not to archaeological site, so this attribution must be regarded as possible but unconfirmed. 
The vessel as described by Calvet and Yon in GGAPC as Eubean or Cycladic but Coldstream (1979, 263, no. 11) reclassifies it as a local imitation of an Aegean Late Geometric type. 
		Bibliography:
		Coldstream J.N. 1979, 'Geometric skyphoi in Cyprus', RDAC, 254-69.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Gjerstad et al. GGAPC / Greek Geometric and Archaic pottery found in Cyprus; Munro and Tubbs 1891 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1890. Third season's work. Salamis

Description: Pottery cup in White Painted ware; wheel-made; carinated lower body with upright, slightly concave sides splaying outwards to a plain rim; splaying conical foot; single vertical strap handle from body to rim; buff-pink clay with buff slip and brown painted decoration: two undulating intersecting wavy lines around the upper body; band around both sides of the rim (mostly missing on outer side); solid paint on foot and handle; single band of brown paint in interior below line of handle; foot chipped, pock marks on exterior surface of vase.

Description: Pottery bowl in White Painted Wheelmade III ware; wheel-made; carinated body on a ring base; plain rim with a slight groove below on the inside; single loop handle at oblique angle to rim; orange-buff clay and slip decorated with red-purple paint: a single band inside and out and a thin black line inside the rim, solid band of red-purple on the foot.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Benson 1972 / Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds. Excavated by J.F. Daniel; Kling 1989 / Mycenaean IIIC:1b and related pottery in Cyprus (wrongly assigned to Kourion)

Description: Small handleless pottery bowl in WPW III ware; flat base and straight, slightly flaring sides; counter-sunk concave base (ca. 3.1 cm in diameter); plain rim with slight lip projecting inwards, damaged in places; reddish-pink gritty clay; minimal or no slip apparent; exterior of vessel appears to have lost all of its painted decoration except for traces of a band of red paint separating the sides and the base; interior has traces of a band of red paint in the same position and a closed relief spiral on the floor of the vessel; traces of red paint in the centre of the spiral; lip of rim is painted in matt brown.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments: Similar to 1896,2-1,365 found in the same tomb. Numerous comparable examples from Daniel's exavations at Episkopi-Bamboula (J L Benson, 'Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds excavated by J. F. Daniel', Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1972, esp. p. 85). See Kling 1989, pp. 136-137 for a full survey with up-to-date assessment of Daniel's contexts.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Benson 1972 / Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds. Excavated by J.F. Daniel; Kling 1989 / Mycenaean IIIC:1b and related pottery in Cyprus

Description: Pottery bowl in Black Polished ware; hand-made; hemispherical body on a rounded base; slightly incurving rim; pierced lug just below rim; made of fairly coarse gritty clay, and covered with a polished slip fired black throughout the body; decorated with incised motifs filled with lime: groups of oblique strokes between parallel lines on upper part of body, hatched zig-zags and triangles on the lower body, concentrics on the base.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (XIII F 3a a1)
Curators Comments:
This is no. 66 in Brewster's study of this ware (2004, 250-1) [Information kindly supplied by Dr Jennifer Webb, January 2012]. In terms of shape and decoration, this vessel is similar to decorated bowls with knob-lugs classed by Stewart's as Red Polished II and dated by him between  EC II and MCII (SCE IV/1A, 333), though according to Merrillees and others this more more correctly belong in RP III. Stewart dated the Black Polished variety to the MC I-II period, as have more recent scholars (see Brewster in Frankel and Webb 2007; Webb et al. 2009). Black Polished is largely restricted to the central plain and north-central coastal area of Cyprus, but is generally rare in the Nicosia area. There is a significant occurrence at Dhenia which was probably one of the main production sites of this ware. Its proximity to Nicosia makes it reasonable to suggest that this was a likely source of this item and GR 1888,9-27.18.      

Bibliography:
Brewster D. 2004, Early and Middle Cypriot Bronze Age Black Polished Ware. Unpublished PhD Dissertation, La Trobe University.
Frankel D. and Webb J. 2007, The Bronze Age cemeteries at Deneia in Cyprus. SIMA CXXXV, Sävedalen (esp. 64-7).
Merrillees R. 1991, 'The principles of Cypriot Bronze Age pottery classification', in J. Barlow et al. (eds), Cypriot ceramics: Reading the prehistoric record. University Museum Symposium Series Volume II. University Museum Monograph 74, Philadelphia, 237-9 (see 239).
Webb J. et al. 2009, The Bronze Age cemeteries at Karmi Palealona and Lapatsa in Cyprus. Excavations by J.R.B. Stewart. SIMA CXXXVI, Sävedalen (223-5).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery krater; White Slip II ware; hand-made; short concave neck with flat topped everted rim; globular body with slightly flattened base; wishbone handle on shoulder; dark brown painted decoration comprising rim ticks on top of rim with four sets of four short vertical lines on neck interior; exterior has dotted scale pattern on neck and upper shoulder; two rows of hatched lozenges at maximum diameter with six pendant vertical rows of hatched lozenges to base interspersed with vertical wavy lines framed by dots and horned vertical lozenges in sets of one or two; sets of four lines on handle; thick light buff slip, unevenly applied on interior; fabric reddish brown; mended from sherds.
Curators Comments: M. Popham 1972 'White Slip Ware' in P. Åström, SCE IV/1C, p. 468 Type 2 Crater, Fig. 55.5, LXXXV.2.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery bowl in White Painted IV ware; handmade; shallow, roughly hemispherical  body with a flattened base and a single vertical handle rising above the rim; buff clay with a worn white-buff slip, decorated with dark brown paint (now much faded): band of four parallel zig-zags on the outside surface, with groups of three lines intersecting at right angles on the base, band around the interior rim.
Type series: type series: White Painted IV (SCE type I A a)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Frankel MCWPP / Middle Cypriot White Painted Pottery. An analytical study of the decoration; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Bronze bowl; cast and hammered; similar in shape to contemporary pottery y-shaped bowls of Base Ring II ware; straight rim with three rivets for handle attachment (handle missing); vertical shoulder with horizontal groove in centre; carinated shoulder with shallow upper part; abrupt angle to a deep, slightly convex lower bowl; low ring base; oxidised.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Catling 1964 / Cypriot Bronzework in the Mycenaean World; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi; Merrillees 1982 / Metal vases of Cypriot type from the 16th to 13th centuries B.C.

Description: Pottery bowl in White Slip II ware; handmade; hemispherical bowl with round base and horizontal, forked, wishbone handle; made in reddish-brown clay with a thick creamy-white slip and matt finish; brown painted decoration consisting of ladder pattern and hooked chain friezes.
Type series: type series: White Slip II (SCE type IA)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 1D. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Other arts and crafts

Description: Pottery bowl in Proto White Slip ware; handmade; hemispherical bowl with a horizontal, blunt wishbone handle just below the rim; made of reddish clay with a pale creamy slip and orange-brown painted decoration; this consists of two encicrclingrope patterns enclosing a festoon pattern; alternating festoon patterns and rope patterns hang vertically from the lower encircling lattice.
Type series: type series: Proto White Slip (SCE type 3)

Description: Pottery: wheel-made Mycenaean shallow bowl of Furumark type FS 296 with loop horizontal handles at the rim; brick-red clay with buff slip, decorated  with brown glossy paint; the rim and handles are painted; on the inside there are four encircling bands with zigzag, circle or vertical line patterns; base is decorated with encircling lines and a solid base; mended.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Description: Fragmentary silver bowl; similar in shape to pottery bowls of Base Ring II ware with conical lower profile, carinated shoulder and upright rim flaring at top; raised through hammering; incomplete, base and one third of rim missing; very poorly preserved.
Bib references: Crewe 2009 / Enkomi; Merrillees 1982 / Metal vases of Cypriot type from the 16th to 13th centuries B.C.

Description: Pottery bowl in White Slip II ware; handmade; hemispherical bowl with round base and horizontal wishbone handle, on one side, just below the rim; made in greyish clay with pale cream, matt slip; brown painted decoration consists predominantly of ladder pattern friezes with some hatched lozenge friezes.

Description: Pottery bowl; wheel-made; decorated with painted bands and multiple wavy stems; circle on base interior.
Dimensions: Diameter: 180 millimetres; Height: 105 millimetres; Weight: 500 grammes; Width: 200 millimetres; Depth: 175 millimetres
