Description: Silver hemispherical bowl; horizontal loop handle below rim with vertical protrusion creating 'wishbone' appearance, attached to vessel with sets of three rivets; row of engraved double circles on top of rim; hammered.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Diameter: 21.20 centimetres rim ; Height: 8.50 centimetres; Weight: 453 grammes
Bib references: Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi; Merrillees 1982 / Metal vases of Cypriot type from the 16th to 13th centuries B.C.; Matthäus 1985 / Metallgefäße und Gefäßuntersätze der Bronzezeit, der geometrischen und archaischen Periode auf Cypern

Description: Pottery bowl in White Slip II ware; handmade; hemispherical bowl with  round base and wish-bone handle; covered with buff slip and decorated with brown painted ladder pattern and hooked chain friezes.
Type series: type series: White Slip II (SCE type IA)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq notes (exc): Found unregistered; acquired before 1912; probably from R H Lang's excavations at Dali.

Description: Pottery bowl or ladle/dipper in Red Polished III ware; handmade; hemispherical body, an inturned rim and a round base; high vertical loop handle rising from rim to mid-body; made of buff clay with burnished surfaced, fired red with some patches of black mottling; rurface worn in places and handle repaired.
Culture: Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (XXII B type e);  type series: Red Polished III
Curators Comments:
Closest parallel is a bowl from Vounous in Tomb 139.42 (Webb and Frankel 2012, p.56 and fig. 8.3). Bowls of this type might also be called cups or dippers.
Bibliography:
Stewart, J.R. 2012. Corpus of Cypriot Artefacts of the Early Bronze Age,  Part 4, Webb, J.M. & Frankel, D. (eds), SIMA vol. III.4, Uppsala.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Pottery stemmed bowl in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; deep body with straight sides and a carinated base, on a narrow stem with spreading foot; plain everted rim; pair of opposing loop handles. Made of buff clay fired a cream-white colour, with black and purple decoration: on each side, a panel of rosettes formed of six leaves framed by vertical lines and zig-zags; bands of paint on the rim and lower body and fit. Vessel repaired from fragments, with some restoration; surface cracked, chipped and worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Shallow Mycenaean pottery bowl; slightly conical, concave body on a ring base; pair of opposing small loop handles; orange-buff clay and slip, decorated in paint fired red to brown: outside is a singe band around the centre of the body with solid base and handles; inside central spiral and two wide concentric bands filled with running spirals and hatched lozenges around the edge; vessel repaired from fragments; surface chipped in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery bowl in White Painted V ware in Fine Line Style; hemispherical body with plain everted rim; vertical wishbone handle rising form the rim; clay not visible but white slip is painted with brown bands of finely drawn parallel lines and chevrons; continuous wavy band between parallel lines below rim; handle decorated with oblique, horizontal and vertical parallel strokes; vessel comprises two coils of clay; the back of the handle has been shaved with a sharp implement.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: White Painted V Fine Line Style (SCE type IBc)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Frankel MCWPP / Middle Cypriot White Painted Pottery. An analytical study of the decoration; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished or possibly Red Polished Mottled ware; handmade; hemispherical body on a rounded base, inverted rim; horizontal loop handle placed just below the rim and set diagonally, small projection on rim under the handle. Made of reddish clay with a burnished surface fired red (though possibly slipped); incised zig-zag pattern round the rim and handle; body cracked and broken with the handle restored, with some mottling on the surface, possibly deliberate.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Ware: Red Polished Ware ((or Red Polished Mottled))
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (Class XIII L type d2);  type series: Red Polished IV ((or Red Polished Mottled))
Curators Comments:
Numerous small bowls with handles of this type were found at Alambra (Coleman et al. 1996, 287-291). Examples close to the present item decorated with an incised zig-zag are F176 (pls 39 and 41) and F188 (fig. 63 and pl. 39), though the latter has projections on the handle.   
Bibliography:
Coleman, J. et al. 1996, Alambra. A Middle Bronze Age settlement in Cyprus. Archaeological investigations by Cornell University 1974-1985. SIMA CXVIII (Jonsered: P. Åström).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Pottery bowl in Black Polished ware; hand-made; hemispherical body on a rounded base; flat rim, inclining inwards very slightly; small pierced lug below the rim; made of fairly coarse gritty clay and covered in a self slip fired black throughout; decorated with incised motifs filled with lime: a single zig-zag below the rim, three obliquely hatched bands on the body, and on the base are four ladder-like motifs meeting in a central in a black square; oblique strokes on the rim; the vessel is repaired from fragments with some restoration.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type XIII F3 b6
Curators Comments:
In terms of shape and decoration, this vessel is similar to decorated bowls with knob-lugs classed by Stewart's as Red Polished II and ranging in date between  EC II and MCII (SCE IV/1A, 333), though according to Merrillees and others more these more correctly belong in RP III. Stewart dated the Black Polished variety to the MC I-II period, as have more recent scholars (see Brewster in Frankel and Webb 2007; Webb et al. 2009). 
Black Polished is largely restricted to the central plain and north-central coastal area of Cyprus, but is generally rare in the Nicosia area. There is a significant occurrence at Dhenia which was probably one of the main production sites of this ware. Its proximity to Nicosia makes it reasonable to suggest that this was a likely source of this item and GR 1888,9-27.18.      
Bibliography:
Brewster D. 2004, Early and Middle Cypriot Bronze Age Black Polished ware. Unpublished PhD Dissertation, La Trobe University. 
 
Frankel D. and Webb J. 2007, The Bronze Age cemeteries at Deneia in Cyprus. SIMA CXXXV, Sävedalen (esp. 64-7).
Merrillees R. 1991, 'The principles of Cypriot Bronze Age pottery classification', in J. Barlow et al. (eds), Cypriot ceramics: Reading the prehistoric record. University Museum Symposium Series Volume II. University Museum Monograph 74, Philadelphia, 237-9 (see 239).
Webb J. et al. 2009, The Bronze Age cemeteries at Karmi Palealona and Lapatsa in Cyprus. Excavations by J.R.B. Stewart. SIMA CXXXVI, Sävedalen (223-5).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Deep pottery bowl in Black-on-red ware; wheel-made; deep body with slightly convex, vertical side and inturning rim; rounded base; buff micaceous clay with a red to brown slip, decorated in black paint: plain horizontal bands on the body with concentric circles on the underside, bands of fine concentric lines in the interior with a small bull's-eye motif in the centre; surface very worn.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished  III ware; handmade; deep conical body and unflattened base with four equidistant horned projections rising from the rim, two of the projections being smaller and lower; incised chevrons on projections and beneath rim; red clay with a red slip, worn in places.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot II
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished II ware; hand-made; hemispherical body on a rounded base; incurving rim; single pierced lug placed below the rim; made of fairly coarse clay covered with a highly polished slip, fired red throughout the body; decorated with incised motifs filled with lime: horizontal parallel lines framing a zig-zag below the rim, cross-hatched arcs on the body. semicircles and zilustorus slip, buff  redware bowl; pierced lug; incised decoration of hatched bands and zig-zags; rim chipped and surface worn in places.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished I-II (north coast) (Stewart Type XIII F3)

Description: Pottery bowl in Base Ring I ware; hand-made; carinated conical body on a ring base;  vertical neck, with a slightly everted rim; forked wish-bone handle  attached just below the rim; made of fine buff clay covered with a mottled red-brown lustrous slip.

Description: Large pottery bowl in Black-on-Red ware with zoomorphic handles; deep, slightly carinated body on a high ring base; slight concavity on the plain rim; two opposing handles, double-arched with a ram's head in the middle; buff-pink fabric and dark red slip (worn in many places), decorated in black paint: banded decoration on the exterior and inside just below the rim, handles also painted; the body of the vase has been distorted in firing.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Division of Finds: Claude Delaval Cobham

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean open cup of Furumark type FS220 with everted rim, strap handle and small raised base; reconstructed from fragments;  pinkish clay with buff slip and orange-red painted looped spiral decoration on outer surface; inner surface undecorated.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: White Painted Wheelmade III pottery bowl; wheel-made; slightly conical body on a ring base; made of fairly fine buff clay with decorated with matt to semi-lustrous paint: on the outside concentric bands of brown paint; inside, central concentric rings and outer band of latticed-lozenges between two rows of zigzags.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments: Originally classified as sub-Mycenaean by Walters, then Levanto-Helladic by Furumark.Kling did not see the original vase in her seminal study of Myc. IIIC1b/WPW III and placed it in her category 1d ('Uncertain shape'), but it belongs in her type 1a ('With plain rim') (Kling 1989, p. 133). The decoration on the inside of the bowl (along with C659) is unusual and may reflect a local variant of WPW III.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Shallow Mycenaean pottery bowl of Furumark type FS 296 with horizontal handles on the rim, decorated inside and out with brown lustrous paint on buff polished slip; decorated on inside with encircling bands and three fish and on the outside with encircling lines and band; restored.

Description: Pottery Late Helladic (Mycenaean) shallow bowl, of Furumark type FS 296; wheel-made; shallow body (shape distorted in firing) with a rounded bottom sitting on a ring base; slightly everted rim; pair of opposing loop horizontal handles just below the rim; made of buff clay with buff slip, decorated  with brownish-red lustrous paint: outside are encircling bands on the body, rim also painted; inside, encircling bands enclose four bull protomes which alternate with sea anenome motifs; the base is solid paint; vessel mended from fragments, paint is worn in places.
Curators Comments: The tomb number is recorded in Walters' vase catalogue of 1912 but not in the original GR Register.

Description: Pottery bowl with white slip and painted decoration; handmade; hemispherical body with rounded base; wish-bone handle (tip missing); slightly incurving rim; handle set below rim; pinkish-white slip, cracked in places, decorated in orange-brown paint: short vertical strokes around rim, a hooked chain frieze framed by two horizontal bands of hatched ladders, vertical bands of alternating simple and complex ladders framing hooked chains with floral finials or single dots, handle with simple parallel bands, dots and a circle at the tip; White Slip II ware.
Dimensions: Diameter: 16.50 centimetres bowl ; Height: 11 centimetres; Length: 6.80 centimetres handle
Curators Comments: See SCE IV/1C, 465 for comparisons (WS II bowl, type 1A (γ')).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery bowl in White Slip I ware; handmade; small, shallow, hemispherical bowl with a flat base and one pierced vertical lug handle, round piercing on the wall near the lug; a buff fabric and pink-white slip; bright orange painted decoration with wavy line and three parallel bands around the rim, alternating motifs of ladders and ladders framing rows of dots running vertically to the base with infills of lattice squares, on the base, intersecting wavy bands forming a cross with open circles in each resultant quadrant; inside are four panels of six parallel lines symmertically arranged around the rim of the bowl.
Type series: type series: White Slip I (SCE type 5)
Curators Comments: Belongs to Åström's WSI bowl Type 5, a rare variety represented by only a few examples (SCE IV/1c, p. 462).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks

Description: Pottery bowl in White Slip II ware; hand-made; hemispherical body on a rounded base; incurving rim; wishbone handle just below rim; made of red-orange fabric with a thin, cracked pinkish-white slip; decorated in brown matt paint with a ladder motif running below the rim and alternating simple and complex ladders arranged vertically; irregular series of narrow horizontal stokes between some of the vertical elements.
Curators Comments: See SCE IV/1C, pp. 466 for comparisons: WS II bowl type 1D.

Description: Pottery: Wheel-made White Slip II ware concave bowl with flared ring base; handle broken away and part of rim missing; dark brown clay with thick cream slip; decorated with matt brown paint with patterns of chains of lozenges and ladders on exterior and four groups of vertical stripes at intervals around inner rim, surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Large pottery bowl in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; deep, slightly carinated body on a turned ring base; pair of opposing loop handles (one lost); orange-brown clay (some mica) and red slip, decorated in brown to black paint: outside are bands of fine parallel lines on the lower body, a broad band below the rim, solid handles framed by loops; inside are concentric circles formed of fine parallel lines below the rim and midway down the body, bull's-eye motif in the centre.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.

Description: Body and rim sherd from a Mycenaean shallow bowl, Furumark type 296; wheel-made; shallow body on a low ring vase; plain rim; made of fine orange-buff clay covered with a similar slip, decorated with red lustrous paint: painted bands around exterior, fine concentric lines around the outer part of the interior, then a frieze (lattice-pattern on the left framing a figural scene of a fantastic bird-like creature with a fish-tail pursuing (?) a large fish with a large fins, possibly a shark or tuna), concentric circles in the centre of the bowl; fragment comprises two joining sherds.
Dimensions: Diameter: 19.50 centimetres original ; Height: 16.10 centimetres; Height: 4.30 centimetres

Excavations 1897-1971; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. Description: Pottery bowl in White Painted Wheelmade III ware; wheel-made; deep conical body on a ring-base; vertical, concave neck, inclining inwards slightly; pair of opposing ribbon handles; greenish-cream clay with numerous gritty inclusions, decorated in brown paint: concentric bands in the interior and on the rim, bands on the handles.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments:
Parallels: SCE IV/1C, 276-89 for details of this ware, esp. p. 282 & fig. 46, no.12.
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Rim and upper body fragment of a bowl in White Painted/Bichrome ware; probably from a fairly deep bowl with convex sides and incurving rim; buff-pink clay decorated on the outside with a frieze of oblique lines framed by parallel bands in brown-purple paint (White Painted technique), on the inside the decoration is black on a red background (original clay rather than a slip), with bands and a frieze of ziz-zags, the incomplete central pattern originally comprised a circular band fringed with concentric hemi-circles; fragment made up of two joined sherds.
Ware: White Painted Ware (WP IV-V (?)); Bichrome Ware (IV-V (?))
Curators Comments: This is a highly unusual application of the White Painted/Bichrome technique with no obvious parallels in the Swedish classification scheme. We are grateful to Dr Joanna Smith for her advice on this sherd (July 2011).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description:
Pottery White Slip II ware bowl; hand-made; hemispherical body with a slightly inverted rim (plain); pierced lug on rim. 
Made of brown clay with thick creamy white slip painted on exterior with  a brown decoration of four concentric circles around the rim and five groups of four parallel lines from top converging at the base; interior of rim decorated with groups of short vertical lines.
Curators Comments: See Popham in SCE IV/1C, fig. 56 esp. nos 9 and 10 for parallels, where a link with WS IIA is suggested.

Description: Pottery bowl in Red Polished I-II ware; hand-made; hemispherical body with a pointed base, and slightly incurving rim; single pierced lug at the rim; made of buff clay covered with a highly polished slip, fired red-orange throughout the body; decorated with incised motifs filled with lime: zig-zags framed by horixontal lines at the rim, and geometrical designs floating in the field below; rim chipped in places and surface worn.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished I-II (north coast) (Stewart Class XIII Type F3a)

Description: Pottery bowl in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; deep body with straight sides - horizontal moulding above the mid-point of the body - on a moulded pedestal foot; opposing horizontal loop-handles; plain rim. Made of buff clay fired a drab cream colour, decorated in black and red paint: above on each side of the vase are panels defined by groups of vertical parallel lines framing geometrical ornaments (diagonals with superimposed circles, chevrons, and circles); below are elaborate stylised lotus flowers and a concentric lozenge within a panel of vertical parallel lines; bands on the stem and in the interior.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: White Painted Wheelmade III pottery bowl imitating a LHIIIB shape; biconical ring base; carinated body; upright, concave rim with slight evertion; originally two opposing horizontal ribbon handles, one missing; exterior decorated with horizontal bands of orange-brown matt paint; interior likewise but also has closed spiral descendiing to floor of vessel; unslipped (?); small crack across inner part of spiral; over-firing has distorted shape of bowl.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments:
There is some confusion about the exact findspot of this bowl because of the ambiguous descriptions in 'Excavations'. According to the GR Register it was found in tomb 96, but the number 89 is given in Walters' vase catalogue. This has been corrected to '96' in the annotated copy in the GR library. In 'Excavations' however, the illustration of the bowl on fig. 129 is also labelled '89'. In the corresponding tomb lists, the only pottery vessel in Tomb 96 is described: 'Bowl as from tomb 89, with spiral pattern inside, in purple on drab ground' ('Excavations', 80, Tomb 96, no. 1). This could refer to the two shallow bowls decorated with spirals on the interior (one painted, the other incised) listed as items 10 and 11 in the tomb list for Tomb 89 but they are a rather different shape. Furthermore, the paint on the present example is orange-brown rather than purple. 
It is also possible that the the tomb list description is referring to a different example of this type from Tomb 89. However, the only other bowls mentioned in the contents list for Tomb 89 ('Excavations', 80 no. 12), and clearly identified as coming from this burial in the Register and Walters' catalogue, do not match the present example as they are decorated with spirals and chequers arranged in concentric bands (1896,2-1.35) and chevrons and chequers (1896,2-1.36) respectively. The description implies that both have two handles, rather than the single example on the present item. Conversely, the description of the bowl in Tomb 96 seems to imply a single spiral rather than the more complex design of the other examples. 
To add to the confusion, 1896,2-1.35 is attributed to Tomb 96 in fig. 129 of 'Excavations'. Overall, a simpler option is to suggest that the tomb numbers have been accidentally reversed on 'Excavations', Fig. 129. This would solve the attribution problem of the bowl with spirals and chevrons to Tomb 89, but still leave the attribution of the present item open to doubt.          
For other examples of this type see SCE IV/1C, 281-282 (Åström's Wide Bowl type 'd'); many examples are known from Daniel's excavations at Episkopi-Bamboula (Benson 1972, pp. 80 ff). A comprehensive study is presented in Kling 1989, with a more up-to-date assessment of Daniel's contexts.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (left-hand side of top row, marked as Tomb 89); Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Benson 1972 / Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds. Excavated by J.F. Daniel; Kling 1989 / Mycenaean IIIC:1b and related pottery in Cyprus

Description: Pottery spouted bowl in Red Polished (or Red Polished Mottled) ware; handmade; hemispherical body with curving sides and a narrow, flattened base; a trough spout set at the rim, opposite a vertical strap handle above which sits a wide rectangular lug; brown-buff clay with a polished reddish-brown slip; repaired from fragments and parts of the upper body are missing; surface deliberately mottled on the exterior.
Culture: Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Red Polished III (?);  type series: Red Polished IV (?);  type series: Stewart Type (XVI F type c)
Curators Comments:
This vessel was classed by Stewart as Red Polished III-IV ware and dated to MCII but should instead be classed as RP Mottled III ware. It is not clear why Stewart included this vessel in his type c, as it has more in common with those in the preceeding types a and b, including one in the latter type from Ayia Paraskevi with a similar pointed base (XVI, F, b, 1). The difference between the shape of the present example and some of the RP II-III examples of his Class XII types ('Cream Bowls': see Stewart 1999, 71 and fig. 17.3) ) is also not very obvious. See Georgiou et al 2011 passim for a modern overview of RP Mottled wares whose existence was known to Stewart but not as a distinctive regional tradition of RP ware. 
Bibliography
Stewart, J.R.B. 1999 (edited by E. Stewart), Corpus of Cypriot Artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part III.1. SIMA Vol. III:3 (Jonsered: P. Åström).
Georgiou G. et al. 2011, Psematismenos-Trelloukas. An Early Bronze Age cemetery in Cyprus (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities).

Description: Large pottery amphora (two handled jar) Black-on-Red bowl, probably for mixing or serving liquids; wheel-made; wide neck with narrow rim; twisted cable in middle of ribbed handles. Made of buff clay covered in a lustrous red slip decorated with black paint: lattice-patterns on neck and shoulder and rings and bands on body.
Curators Comments: The finspot is not given in the Register but an annotation on the entry by H.B. Walters says 'probably Dali' based on Ohnefalsch-Richter's now lost reports and letters. This findspot was repeated in the BM vase catalogue. This findspot cannot be taken as face-value however since Ohnefalsch-Richter's published work suggests that he excavated Hellenistic-Roman tombs around Dali for Newton, not 'Graeco-Phoenician' as this vase would have been terms. Tombs of this date were explored by him around Achna, Goshi and Salamis.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description:
Large pottery bowl with figural scenes in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; shallow, carinated body on a low ring base; pair of opposing horizontal loop handles. 
In the interior of the bowl, the complex frieze of figures is arranged around a central rosette bordered by an interlocking cable motif. Three quarters of the frieze is taken up with pairs of women face each other smelling flowers on a tree. The rest of the scene show two couples engaged in sexual congress in various postures, and a single female clapping her hands and dancing with one foot raised. In front of the later is a diminutive bearded male touching (?) her skirt; the stylised trees bewteen these figures may suggested a wooded landscape, or else a continuation of the motivs from the rest of the frieze. The rim is painted with a border of chevrons. On the outside of the vase are two registers of decoration: a frieze of antithetic sphinxes facing stylised trees, and a frieze of stylised lotus petals.
Dimensions: Diameter: 32.40 centimetres; Diameter: 34.29 centimetres; Height: 10.16 centimetres; Height: 9.60 centimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq notes (acq): For details of the acquisition, see letters of vendor/shipping company and Original Letters 1906-08, L-Q, nos 950-962.

Description: Possible base of a cylindrical ivory box; flat, circular disc with central hole on top, but not pierced through; smoothed surface, partially damaged and abraded at one side.
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8- 24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot  comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely,  the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they  are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum as  among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most  likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration  group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced  items.  
The lack of contextual information makes it difficult to assignt this item a precise date. Ivory and bone boxes were common in Cyprus in both the Late Bronze Age and Hellenistic-Roman periods; this may belong to the latter period given the parallels from Amathus (Chavane 1990, 73), Salamis (Chavane 1975, 176-178 and pls. 48-48) and elsewhere on the island.
Bibliography:
Chavane M.-J. 1975, Salamine de Chypre. VI. Les petits objets (Paris: de Boccard).  
Chavane M.-J. 1990, La nécropole d'Amathonte. Tombes 110-385. IV. Les petits objets. Études chypriotes XII (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities; French School at Athens).
Bib references: Amathonte IV/Les Petits Objets / Amathonte IV. La Nécropole D'Amathonte. Tombes 110-385
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Tripod cooking pot in Red Polished III ware; handmade; depressed ovoid body, with flaring rim and three stump-feet; two round handles from rim to shoulder with one broken away; coarse brown clay with brown slip; very worn with incomplete sides and rim and blackened from use;
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (VIII C a2 (poss. var. a))

Description: Coarse-ware pottery tripod vessel ('Tripod cooking dipper') in Red Polished III ware; handmade; ovoid body, flaring rim and three feet; round heavy handle rising from rim to mid-body and pinched projection on  front of rim; dark red clay with red slip; worn surface and repairs to feet..
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (Class VIII Group E Type b variety a)
Curators Comments: Described as a 'cup on three feet' in the original BM vase catalogue, this is basically a cooking pot with tripod legs and a handle typical of a dipper jug. Stewart admitted that the term 'tripod cooking dipper' was clumsy but employed it to emphasise the relaitonship between this shape and cooking pots with otherwise similar shapes and handles.

Description:
Pottery: red-figured covered kantharos, with closed-in top, at one side of which is an aperture 3.2 cm long by 1.9 cm, communicating with the centre of the bottom by means of a shaft walled off from the interior.
The lid is painted black and decorated with concentric mouldings: in its centre is a moulded Gorgon mask (3.2 cm diameter) painted white with black hair and red tongue. 
(a) Odysseus and Nausicaa. On the left Odysseus, nude, with rough hair and beard, stands as if in astonishment, holding a long beaded fillet (the credemnon) in both hands: he gazes at Nausicaa, who sinks away on the right, looking back at him; she wears a Doric chiton with apoptygma, and her hair is knotted behind with a fillet wound thrice round it. Beside Odysseus is inscribed his name, ΟΔΥΣΕΥΣ, Όδυσεύς. Beside Nausicaa, KAΛΕ, καλή.
(b) Oedipus and the Sphinx. On a high rock on the left, drawn in purple outline, the Sphinx is seated to right, her long hair knotted behind with a fillet, which has a vertical piece over the forehead: her fore and hind legs join on to her body like the arms and legs of a woman. In front of her stands Oedipus, beardless, en face, but looking towards her, his left hand on his hip, his right holding two spears: he wears a chlamys, fillet, a petasos hanging at his back, and high endromides.
Purple inscriptions, fillet, belt, and rock. Brown markings. Eye in profile.
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
Musée Blacas, pl. xii, p. 38; Inghirami, Gal. Om. iii, 24; Overbeck, Her. Bildw. pl. xxxi, 1, p. 34, no; 37 (wrongly described as an amphora), and p. 754, no. 5; Ritschl, Ino Leukothea, 1865, p. 19, pl. 2, 3; cf. Gerhard, A. V. iii, p. 132; Ann. dell’ Inst. 1829, p. 277, and 1876, p. 350; Bull, dell’ Inst. 1838, p. 12; Baumeister, p. 1037; Bolte, De Monum. ad Odyss. pert. p. 37; C.I.Gr. no. 7698.
The scene on b is almost identical with Overbeck, Her. Bildw. pl. i, 16. For the construction of this vase see Arch. Anzeiger (vii), 1892, p. 24, where a similar vase in Berlin is described, but with a low foot; it is there stated that vases of the same kind are used at this day (i.e. 1898) in Cyprus.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 4 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 5, British Museum 4

Description: Pottery White Painted Wheelmade III cup; wheel-made; flaring rim with vertical upper body, slight carination to rounded lower body with concave disc base; high vertical handle from rim to mid-body; red painted bands on exterior, rim top and interior; self-slipped; surface cream to orange.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Dimensions: Diameter: 9.70 centimetres; Height: 4.60 centimetres rim ; Height: 5.80 centimetres total

Description: Pottery cup; wheel-made; decorated with reddish brown painted bands and sets of concentric arcs with v motif between.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Curators Comments: Merlin entry before editing by lcrewe had findspot of either Tomb 83 or Tomb 66. As both the register and the catalogue say Tomb 83 there seems no reason to believe that it came from Tomb 66.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery: black-figured cup of the segment class. Design black on red ground, with purple and white accessories. Interior: Victor in the horse-race: Male figure on horseback to right, reining in his horse; he is beardless, with a white loin-cloth. In front of him is a youth moving to right, looking back, with left hand raised; over his shoulders a striped chlamys, in right hand a taenia. In the field, imitations of inscriptions.
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
J.H.S. xi. p. 45. For the subject,  cf. Vase Β144.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti

Description: Glazed composition cup; mould-made with modelled detail; flat base and low, straight walls, widening slightly to rim; two grooves round exterior wall; grooved vertical handle from rim to base; very worn dotted rosette motif in brown paint on base interior, petals filled with blue or yellow; traces of brown dotted band on exterior at rim; surface poorly preserved; mended from sherds.
Bib references: Peltenburg 1972 / On the Classification of Faience Vases from Late Bronze Age Cyprus.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Spouted pottery bowl ('milk bowl') in Red Polished III ware;  handmade; deep globular body with incurving rim and round base; tubular side-spout at the rim opposite a broken handle; light red clay with a light red slip, worn and accreted, with some blackening at the base.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (X C a1 (?));  type series: Red Polished III
Curators Comments:
This vessel is similar to examples in Stewart's Class X Group C ('round-based bowls) Type a1 (Stewart 1999, fig. 8, no 4) though the basic round bottomed shaped also occurs with other handle and spout types. 
Bibliography:
Stewart J.B. 1999 (ed. E. Stewart), Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part III:1. SIMA III:3 (Jonsered: P. Åström).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Dimensions: Diameter: 14.70 centimetres; Height: 6.90 centimetres; Weight: 151.62 grammes

Exhibition history: 2023-2024 27 April - 30 April, Jerusalem, The Israel Museum, The Feast

Description: Attic black figure stemmed cup (Little Master type); wheel-made; made of fine buff clay, decorated in black figure technique with added purple and white. On the exterior on either side are centaurs galloping to the right, with a stone in either hand, which they are about to hurl; concentric circles against reserved background at centre of interior. Intact, with small chips from the rim and handles.
Dimensions: Diameter: 130 millimetres; Height: 85 millimetres; Weight: 160 grammes; Width: 189 millimetres; Depth: 139 millimetres
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
 J.H.S. xi. p. 42.

Description: Pottery cup; wheel-made; decorated with painted bands and wavy line. Remnants of crossing lines on interior.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Diameter: 124 millimetres; Height: 54 millimetres; Weight: 149 grammes; Width: 112 millimetres; Depth: 147 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Rim sherd of Attic black-figured pottery type A cup; interior glazed black; exterior:  black band at top of rim; below, black-figure decoration; a complex and worn composition that Beazley took to be part of a courting scene, though the interpretation of the central area is perplexing, even if the number of arms suggest some form of close interaction; two ancient repair holes and remains of a third one.
Dimensions: Height: 4 centimetres; Thickness: 0.30 centimetres; Width: 4.60 centimetres
Curators Comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.; Listed in Beazley, J. D., Some Attic Vases in the Cyprus Museum, ed. D. C. Kurtz. Oxford 1989, 21, no. γ14.
Bib references: Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 1)
Assoc name: Representation of: Herakles/Hercules (possibly);  Representation of: Nemean Lion
Acq name (previous): Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford

Description: Pottery dish decorated on the inside with an olive branch. The decoration is "reserved" with painted details in imitation of the Attic red figure technique.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery dish; two thick handles with knobs; buff slip; remains of painted banded decoration and lattice-triangles; rim chipped.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery: Bichrome-red ware shallow bowl; small foot; flange on rim; black and white banded decoration inside, two goats to right and palm-branches on exterior.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery dish or plate in White Painted/Bichrome ware; shallow, slightly carinated body, shaped distorted from firing; very broad disc base; pair of opposing wish-bone handles; orange-red clay and cream slip, decorated in brown-purple and red-purple paint: spiral and concentric decoration inside, outside, concentric circles around the ring base, enclosing hatched triangles and rectangular panels arranged around a radial, eight-spoke motif in the centre; the latter motif is ringed by a broad, red-purple band in a different colour to the rest of the painted decoration.
Ware: White Painted Ware (WP II); Bichrome Ware (BiCh II)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery dish in White Painted/Bichrome ware; wheel-made;shallow body with convex sides on a low ring base; slightly everted rim; pair of opposing lug handles, triangular shaped with, pierced at the apex with small projects at each side. Made of orange clay with a buff slip and decorated with red to purple and brown paint: on the exterior are red-purple concentric bands of varying widths (including within the area of the ring base), on the interior are brown concentric bands. Surface chipped and worn in many places, and the slip is missing over a large portion of the interior.
Type series: type series: White Painted III;  type series: Bichrome III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the    Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material    originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due    to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The    material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was    probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District    Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Large pottery dish in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; shallow convex body on a turned base; thickened inverted rim; pair of opposing double-loop handles of quasi-zoomorphic type (one now lost); orange micaceous clay and red slip, decorated in black paint: bands of concentric circles of fine lines inside and out, solid handles.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: Pottery dish or plate in White Painted ware; shallow concave body, carinated at the bottom, with a slightly inturning rim; low ring base; two opposing wish-bone handles (one now missing); buff clay and slip, decorated in purple-brown paint: inside is a central spiral surrounded by a broad band, outside an elaborate geometric decoration of solid and hatched lozenges within a rectangular panel resembling a basket, also hatched triangles, groups of short parallel strokes at intervals on the ring base, and concentric circles, solid handles.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Small pottery dish or bowl in the shape of a boat in White Painted ware; hand-made and modelled; oval body with a flat, everted rim, pierced at intervals with pairs of holes; the handle is in the form of a applied human figurine attached to the rim at the 'stern' of the model: he has large pierced eyes, rudimentary limbs but with fingers and toes indicated, the left hand rests on the rim, the right is missing; very fine, thin fabric in drab buff clay, slipped and decorated in black paint with wavy lines and chevrons or zig-zags on the body and bands on the figurine.
Curators Comments:
The BM catalogue entry suggests the vessel is an imitation of a basket, but a boat model is more likely. The model is discussed by Carbillet (2011, 226 and fig. 3) in the content of other Bronze Age examples, along with a broader consideration of their possible symbolism.  
Bibliography:
Carbillet A. 2011, 'Naviguer vers l'éternité? Les modèles de bateau en terre cuite des tombes chypriotes: un réexamin', CCEC 2011, 223-38.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Westerberg Cypriote Ships / Cypriote ships from the Bronze Age to c. 500 BC; Karageorghis Coroplastic I / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. I. Chalcolithic - Late Cypriot I
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery dish or plate in White Painted ware; shallow, convex body with a inverted rim; low ring base; pair of opposing wish-bone handles; orange clay and cream slip, decorated in matt brown-purple paint: spiral motif in centre of interior surrounded by a broad band, concentric bands around the edge of the exterior, with hatched triangles surrounded a central spiral motif; four groups of short parallel strokes on the ring base; handles solid; surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Pottery Base Ring I double juglet; hand-made; ovoid bodies with long, slightly tapering narrow necks; funnel-shaped mouths (one chipped); one joint vertical strap handle rising above the rim and splitting into Y-shaped attachement on both shoulders; tall conoid rings bases; red-brown clay with worn, slightly lustrous brown slip; coarse horizontal incision on front of upper necks.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery Base Ring I double juglet; hand-made; ovoid bodies with long, slightly tapering narrow necks; funnel-shaped mouths (one chipped); one joint vertical strap handle rising above the rim and splitting into Y-shaped attachement on both shoulders; tall conoid rings bases; red-brown clay with worn, slightly lustrous brown slip; coarse horizontal incision on front of upper necks.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Dimensions: Diameter: 4.40 centimetres each juglet ; Height: 10 centimetres; Width: 8.60 centimetres total
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Hand-made Black Slip III pottery jug with a double ovoid body and narrow neck;  a pinched mouth for pouring is opposite the strap handle which is placed neck to shoulder; buff clay fabric with black slip peeling in places; incised decoration with zigzag bands.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description:
Pottery drinking-cup.
Unglazed drab ware with designs in drab-coloured barbotine.
The design on either side is apparently intended for a rough representation of a human face, with nose and eyes roughly indicated; the handles have large rings appended to them, and may represent ears with earrings.
Curators Comments:
Roman Pottery
Holder, Formen der rom. Thottgef. pl. 6, 2, gives a similar vase from Italy; see also Bonner Jahrb. lxxxvi. pl. 6, 12 (Andernach), xcvi. p. 113, and Koenen, Gefasskunde, pls. 12, 15, 17.
Similar to the so-called ‘owl-vases’ of Hissarlik (Walters, Ancient Pottery, i. p. 258).
For the representation of ears, cf. Terracotta A10 ff., 52, from Cyprus.
Bib references: Roman Pottery / Catalogue of the Roman Pottery in the British Museum

Description: Bronze statuette of a man in Egyptian costume.
Bib references: Reyes 1992 / The anthropomorphic statuettes of archaic Idalion; Masson 1966 / Kypriaka III. Vases d'albâtre inscrits du temple de Golgoi
Exhibition history:
Exhibited:
'Phoenicians and the Mediterranean', Institut du Monde Arabe, Paris, 05.11.07-20.04.08
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description: Limestone figure of a female worshipper. She wears a long chiton. The back is flat and roughly rendered. Fragment, broken. Carved from limestone.
Curators Comments:
This forms part of a donation by the EEF to Queen's University Belfast which according to the Egyptian Exploration Fund distribution lists consisted of 3 scarab moulds, 7 broken stone figures, 2 heads, 2 lamps, 5 vases. This object is listed in K.T. Frost’s Catalogue of the Museum of the Department of Archaeology (16-05-1910), page 4, under the rubric 1. Egyptian Section: F. Finds at Naucratis, but cannot at present be located in the Museum's collection and may have been lost in the war (see Dunlop et al 2004) as this was not catalogued by Russell in 1969, unless missidentified as: 'also limestone head of this god. Terracottas of human heads and figures, some representing gods and goddesses, others probably portraits and animals (60) (all probably from Egypt)' (Russell 1969, 110).
The description in this catalogue is based on the information from the EEF distribution list and the museum catalogue ("Aphrodite of Cyprus  in limestone"). The dating and classification is based on parallels known from Naukratis. The EEF were at this time distributing a number of Cypriot figurines from the sanctuary of Aphrodite, excavated by Garder in 1885-6, with Petrie's help. These figures were often missidentified as representations of Aphrodite, when the original box or label referred to the find spot (Sanctuary of Aphrodite) not identity of the figure.
Dunlop, W. M.  Hartwell B.N and  Frost. K. T. 2004. The Catalogue of the Archaeological Museum at the Queen's University of Belfast, Compiled by K. T. Frost in 1910. Ulster Journal of Archaeology 63: 130-137.
Russell, J. F. 1969. Archaeological material in the teaching collection of teh Department of Archaeology, Queen's University of Belfast. Ulster Journal of Archaeology 32, 109-11.
Bib references: Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 3)
Acq name (previous): Currently owned by: Queen's University Belfast, School of Geography, Archaeology and Palaeoecology
Acq notes (exc): Excavated 1884-1885 or 1885-1886. Given by the Egypt Exploration Fund, 1908/1909.

These figures were often missidentified as representations of Aphrodite, when the original box or label referred to the find spot (Sanctuary of Aphrodite) not identity of the figure.

Description: Limestone figure of a female worshipper. She wears a long chiton. The back is flat and roughly rendered. Fragment, broken. Carved from limestone.
Curators Comments:
This forms part of a donation by the EEF to Queen's University Belfast which according to the Egyptian Exploration Fund distribution lists consisted of 3 scarab moulds, 7 broken stone figures, 2 heads, 2 lamps, 5 vases. This object is listed in K.T. Frost’s Catalogue of the Museum of the Department of Archaeology (16-05-1910), page 4, under the rubric 1. Egyptian Section: F. Finds at Naucratis, but cannot at present be located in the Museum's collection and may have been lost in the war (see Dunlop et al 2004) as this was not catalogued by Russell in 1969, unless missidentified as: 'also limestone head of this god. Terracottas of human heads and figures, some representing gods and goddesses, others probably portraits and animals (60) (all probably from Egypt)' (Russell 1969, 110).

The dating and classification is based on parallels known from Naukratis. These figures were often missidentified as representations of Aphrodite, when the original box or label referred to the find spot (Sanctuary of Aphrodite) not identity of the figure.

Description: Terracotta female figure, probably a votary, holding a footed bowl in her arms; hand-made body with mould-made face; solid, plank-like body with a slightly concave front; no anatomical details are shown, but the base projects where the feet would be to create a stand; the arms are crude strips of clay applied to the upper body which wrap around the large stemmed vessel held by the woman; the head is very small in proportion to the body: rounded face with prominent bulbous eyes, pointed nose and well defined lips; prominent ears, only one well preserved; a line of curls is visible along the forehead, held in place by a narrow fillet, behind which a further line of curls is shown, then a veil or cloak; the hair falls in thick tresses on either side of the head; made of buff clay with traces of red paint on the body and vase.
Type series: type series: Yon and Caubet Lapithos Workshop 5
Curators Comments: For an analysis of the iconography and manufacturing techniques of the   Lapithos workshops based similar material in the Louvre from the same source, see Yon M. and Caubet A. 1988, 'Un culte populaire de la Grande Déesse à Lapithos', RDAC 1988/2, 1-17, esp. 11-13 (also Antiquités de Chypre. Coroplastique, vol. 1 (Paris, 1998), 243ff). Numerous additional examples of figurines with vases provided by Karageorghis Coroplastic, volumes VA, 60-1,
Bib references: Terracotta / Catalogue of the terracottas in the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, British Museum; Karageorghis Coroplastic VA / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. V. The Cypro-Archaic period small female figurines. A. Handmade/wheelmade figurines; Kiely 2011e / The ancient Kingdom of Lapethos
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir William Frederick Haynes Smith

Description:
Grey limestone figure of a bull with two attendants, painted. 
Group on a plinth; a bull led to sacrifice by two attendants. Of the first attendant only the right and an onset of the left hand are remaining, placing a twisted garland round the bull's neck; a circular hole in the bull's side might have held the connecting part for the first attendant. The second, behind the first, is placing his right hand on the bull's back; his head is missing.
The bull is slender and its body rather elongated, his dewlaps and hackles are shown as incised parallel folds, the dewlaps merging into a pointy line in the front. An upside-down triangle is marking the forehead, the horns are strong, the rounded ears are turned upward, the large eyes are framed by two layers of skin like eyebrows; the tail resembles a horse's tail. The second attendant is standing to the animal's left, putting his right outstretched arm on the bull's back. His left arm is bent and kept in his matle's sling, the hand is clenched into a fist, the thumb is stretched out. His cloak goes down to his ankles. What is left of his hair is shown as a thick mass with rounded edges, below there is a tounge-like form, which is supposedly the typical folds found on the back. In contrast to the careful rendering of the bull, the attendants are presented rather schematically.
Traces of red paint are remaining on the bull's ears, between nostril and ear, on top of both vessels and on the mantle of the attendant, running from the left wrist to the left shoulder; the directions of the paint on the back is less clear.
Find spot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'first temple of Apollo'.)
Dimensions: Height: 8 centimetres max ; Length: 9.10 centimetres max ; Width: 5.65 centimetres max
Curators Comments:
According to Nick (2006, 68-69), this kind of group is not unusual in terracotta statuettes though it is unparalleled in limestone. The material is understood as the reason for differences in presentation and thus explains the lack of close parallels. The garland placed around the bull's neck  clearly indicates a ritual and sacrificial meaning of the group. The accompanying vases and the style of the attendant's garment suggest a date within the first half of the sixth century BC.
The figure bears its registration number and Smith's number 107, the latter in a faint red.
See also Smith 1892, no. 107; Mallet, Premiers Etablissements, p. 268, fig. 55.
Also published by A. Hermary in ThesCRA I, 2004, 113 no. 443, pl. 23.GR.443, who notes a possible parallel from the Samian Heraion.
Bib references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum; Nick 2006 / Zypro-ionische Kleinplastik aus Kalkstein und Alabaster; Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85; Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (Phase 3)

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted ware; hand-made; oblong bag-like form; spout, ring-handle and animal-head protome; red hatched triangles.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III

Description: Pottery two-handled flask in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; narrow neck with a flaring trumpet mouth; neck ridge; pair of opposing handles arching from shoulder to below neck ridge; made of fine buff clay covered with a lustrous red slip, decorated with black paint: vertical and horizontal bands of parallel lines on the body, bull's eye motif on each side of the body, small groups of concentric circles on the shoudler, bands on the neck, solid paint on the handles.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXIX, 18. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus
Acq notes (acq): Findspot not given in GR Register.

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted IV; handmade; globular body on three feet; narrowing tubular neck with an opening on the side; small strap handle from the lower neck to the shoulder; fourteen string-holes (two now lost) along the neck and shoulder; beige clay with a buff slip decorated with black latticed triangles.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted String-hole Style (SCE type VII B1j)

Description: Pottery pilgrim flask, probably Phoenician ware; wheel-made; lentoid body with a narrow neck expanding to a trumpet mouth with a plain rim. made of fairly coarse and heavy buff clay, decorated with black pained: concentric circles on both sides of the body, bars on the handle.
Production place: Made in: Phoenicia (historic) (?);  Made in: Cyprus (?)
Curators Comments:
Probably found in a tomb. 
The pilgrim flask, originating in the Late Bronze Age, is a very common Phoenician shape on Cyprus in the CG period (Bikai 1983, 10ff nos 73-113 for numerous examples). The form changes very little during this period, but many of the examples included by Bikai in her chronological analysis belong in her Kouklia Horizon (1050-850 BC).  
Bibliography:
Bikai P. 1983, The Phoenician pottery of Cyprus (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted IV ware; hand-made; bird-shaped body (with tail feathers) with an arching handle on top of the body; small cutaway spout, concave sides; made of orange-buff clay decorated with matt orange-brown paint: parallel diagonal lines on the body, horizontal parallel lines on the neck and bands around the handle.

Description: Pottery flask or askos in the form of bird in Bichrome ware; long oval hand-made body with a long neck and trefoil spout, surface smoothed with a tool; thick strap handle extending from the bottom of the neck to the middle of the body; a slight back-ridge terminates in a pointed 'tail'; buff-pink clay with a white slip, decorated in black and red paint: on each flank, a pointed oval panel, framed by black bands on each side, with black lines and semi-circles with red fill, probably representing plumage; black parallel lines around the neck and parallel red strokes on the handle; a pair of eyes on the mouth; surface cracked in places.

Description:
Mycenaean (Late Helladic) pottery flask; wheel-made; globular-lentoid body with flattened sides on a conical ring base; narrow concave neck with a flaring mouth; ridge at the junction of shoulder and neck; pair of opposing stirrup handles from shoulder to mid-neck. 
Made of finely levigated buff clay, covered with a similar coloured slip and decorated with red-brown lustrous paint: concentric circles on each side framing a central disc filled with a motif composed of four sets of 'concentric' triangles meeting at a centre point; the flatter sides below the handles are divided into panels and filled with stylised floral motifs (perhaps trees).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery spherical bottle in White Painted Latticed Diamond Style ware; hand-made; spherical body; long narrow neck with two string-hole handles at neck base; red lattice pattern on buff polished slip.
Type series: type series: White Painted Latticed Diamond Style (SCE type IVa 1a)
Curators Comments: According to Åström, some of the WP III-IV (Latticed Diamond Style) wares were made in the same workshops as WP III-V (String-hole style) vase (SCE IV/1B, 32, note 1).

Description: Alabaster flask; ovoid or lentoid body; long neck and flaring rim with rounded profile; two vertical goose- or duck-head lugs or handles at side, details of eyes and beaks rendered as simple incisions; strap handle (mostly missing) from top of body to middle of neck; formed through both carving and grinding with an abrasive; surface corroded.
Curators Comments: According to Jacobsson (Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus, pp. 18 and 80) this object is both unique to Cyprus and lacks close parallels elsewhere, though individual features, such as the lentoid body and lug handles, can be attested elsewhere in 18th Dynasty contexts (Petrie, Stone and metal vases, London 1937, PLS. XXXVI:919 & XXXIV:882; Hayes, The sceptre of Egypt II. The Hyksos period and the New Kingdom (1675-1080 BC), 1959, pp. 207, 209 fig. 123)
Bib references: Jacobsson 1994 / Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 1D. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Other arts and crafts; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery: redware lentoid flask; two handles; black concentric decoration; polished slip.

Description: Black-on-Red ware pottery flask; spherical body with low ring base; two double-ribbed vertical handles (one lost) rising to narrow neck with ridge; spreading trumpet-shaped mouth with flaring rim (chipped); buff to red clay with light grey core and thick red, lustrous slip; painted with band of concentric horizontal rings black painted on body and on neck; row of three swastikas and three concentric circles on the shoulder on each side of the handle; ladder pattern on the handle; Black-on-Red I.
Curators Comments:
See SCE IV/2, pl. XXV for comparable examples. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern survey of this ware, but advocates a higher date for the appearance of BoR in the CG II period. 
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of Cyprus. Culture and history of the ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted String-hole Style; handmade; slim oval body with a flattened base and a narrow tubular spouted neck with lateral mouth; the handle runs from the mouth to the shoulder; string-hole projections on either side of the neck with four further projections along each side; buff clay with a buff slip decorated with red-brown paint; the decoration consists of framed latticed diamonds, framed zigzags and checquered panels.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted String-hole Style (SCE type X B 3b)
Curators Comments: Marked in pencil 'Phoenikiais no. 13' referring to a now lost list of material from Ohnefalsch-Richter's excavations at this site.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery lentoid flask in White Painted ware; wheel-made; pair of opposed arching handles; made of fine decorated clay, main surface fired a buff-cream colour, with brown painted decoration: concentric circles on the body.
Curators Comments: The number 20 pencilled on the body may be a tomb number
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Wheel-made pottery:Late Minoan IIIA1 large globular flask of Furumark type FS 187; painted decoration is red/brown on a cream ground with vertical concentric circles following the biconcave profile with stylised leaf patterns. The flask was made from two hemispherical halves joined together, with the foot, handles and neck added separately.
Dimensions: Diameter: 29 centimetres; Height: 41 centimetres; Weight: 2.10 kilograms
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni
Exhibition history:
Exhibited: 
1996 11 Jul-6 Oct, Japan, Arita, Kyushu Ceramic Museum, Ceramics and Civilisation

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted IV-VI Cross Line Style; hand-made; bulbous body; two ring-handles; red linear decoration and lattice-panels.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Ware: White Painted Ware (WP IV-VI Cross Line Style)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted String-hole Style; handmade; ellipsoidal body with flattened base and short narrow neck with beak-shaped mouth; handle from base of the neck to shoulder; four pairs of string-holes along the side of the neck and body; buff clay with buff slip; painted decoration in red/black comprising chequer-pattern and wavy-lines on body.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted String-hole Style (SCE type XIV C 2b)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery askos in White Painted V ware; swollen ovoid body with flat base and a loop handle on top; animal protome spout at one end and a cylindrical spout with beaked mouth at the other; buff clay with a buff slip and black painted decoration of latticed panels and parallel lines.
Type series: type series: White Painted V (SCE type XIIId)

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean two-handled flask with a depressed body and narrow cylindrical neck of Furumark type FS 191 and LHIIIA2 date; buff clay, slipped and painted with dark brown decoration of horizontal bands.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. Description: Late Helladic (Mycenaean) pottery flask; wheel-made; depressed globular body with narrow neck and flaring mouth; pair of opposing vertical handles arching from shoulder to neck; high ring base; buff clay and slip, decorated with black-red paint: broad and narrow horizontal bands on the body and neck; repaired and restored.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery lentoid flask ('pilgrim flask') in Phoencian ware or a local Cypriot version; wheel-made; lentoid globular body; narrow neck with a flaring mouth (one half now missing); pair of opposing handles from shoulder to mid neck. Made of fairly coarse orange-buff clay (numerous fine black inclusions), the surface fired a lighter buff-pink; decorated with black and red-purple paint: concentric bands on both sides of the body. Surface and painted very worn and cracked in places.
Production place: Made in: Phoenicia (historic) (?);  Made in: Cyprus (?)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the    Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material    originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due    to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The    material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District    Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.
