Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery two-handled flask; wheel-made; decorated with painted bands and multiple stem motif on shoulder.
Dimensions: Diameter: 120 millimetres; Height: 165 millimetres; Weight: 393 grammes; Width: 113 millimetres; Depth: 120 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery barrel-shaped jug; wheel-made; ovoid, barrel-shaped body, rounded ends with central nipple-like projections; wide cylindrical neck with central ridge, concave above; squared, everted rim; short strap handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; cream clay and slip, decorated in black and red paint: concentric bands around the body frame a large stylised bird with several pairs of wings and elaborate tail feathers facing the right (drawn in outline with hatched or filled interior); bull's eye pattern on each end of the body, with geometrical lozenge motif framed by vertical parallel lines on the shoulder above; wavy line around the neck below the ridge; surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery flask in Red Polished ware; hand-made; squat globular body; narrow neck with pierced lugs treated anthropomorphically; four pierced ear-handles round the body; buff clay and polished red slip; incised decoration (parallel and wavy lines from neck to base; groups of short parallel lines arranged in lozenge shapes, rather like tattoo-marks) filled with white lime; surface very worn on one side of the vase.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B4 type n);  type series: Red Polished III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery flask or bottle in Red Polished III (Black Top) pottery; hand-made; depressed globular body on a rounded base; tall, narrow tubular neck and flaring everted rim; two adjacent holes, pierced inwards, on the rim, possibly for suspension; made of buff clay covered with a burnished slip, fired red bwlow and black above; decorated with incised lime-filled rows of zig-zag/ladder motifs; rim slightly chipped at the edges.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (V B type a)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq notes (exc): This was sold to the British Museum in 1868 by Demetrios Pierides (q.v.) as part of a larger group of Bronze Age to Hellenistic/Roman pottery from tombs in the vicinity of Dhali. It is illustrated with a sketch in the original register. However, Walters in his vase catalogue in 1912 stated that it was 'probably from Phoenikiais' i.e. excavated by Ohnefalsch-Richter in 1884. This information was repeated in the CVA and then by Stewart in his CCAEBA. The vessel was re-registered in 1978 with this information, obscuring its original source.
Add ids: Other BM number: 1868,0905.24 (Re-registered in error in 1978)

Description: Pottery barrel-shaped juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; barrel-shaped body with bosses ('nipples') at each end; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a very large trumpet mouth; pair of opposing arching handles from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and polished red slip, decorated with dull black paint: bands of concentric lines around the ends of the vase, with a bull's-eye motif at the bosses, complex dark motif  beneath each handle, short parallel bars on the handles, broad and narrow bands on the neck and mouth.
Curators Comments:
See Schreiber 2003 for a modern survey of this ware and a reassessment of its chronology. 
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture and history of the ancient Near East 13 (Brill).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Pottery funnel in Red Polished ware; handmade; hemispherical body with single orned handle rising from just below rim and a spout at the base; red clay with red slip, repaired and restored at rim.
Culture: Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (Class XXVI Group A Type g);  type series: Red Polished III
Dimensions: Diameter: 1.40 centimetres internal bore ; Diameter: 13.50 centimetres; Height: 17.50 centimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Athenian pottery red figure glaux with two loop handles aligned in opposite directions and base ring ; glaze reserved within base ring with circle-and-dot at the centre; reserved area reddened with miltos; decorated on both sides with an owl between laurel branches; repaired from fragments.
Dimensions: Diameter: 16.50 centimetres including handles ; Diameter: 10.30 centimetres; Height: 8.50 centimetres
Curators Comments: For type see Boardman, Athenian Red Figure vases, the Classical period, 1989, p. 39 & fig. 96.
Bib references: Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Bailey & Hockey 2001 / 'New objects' from British Museum Tomb 73 at Curium; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; CVA British Museum 4 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 5, British Museum 4

Description: Conical faience goblet decorated with lotus petals; mould-made with added paint; broad splaying foot with concave indentation under foot; low pedestal with indentation at juncture with the conical body of vase; moulding at rim; decorated with six vertical lotus leaves arranged symmetrically around the body of the vase; petals and base painted in turquoise blue or yellow/ brown with a black background and rim; intact but assembled from fragments and heavily restored.
Bib references: SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 1D. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Other arts and crafts; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Peltenburg 1972 / On the Classification of Faience Vases from Late Bronze Age Cyprus.; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Fragment of a glazed composition stemmed goblet; moulded face in relief with incised angular line around face representing hair and pronounced ears.
Dimensions: Height: 7.60 centimetres max ; Width: 5.70 centimetres max
Bib references: Peltenburg 1972 / On the Classification of Faience Vases from Late Bronze Age Cyprus.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Foot and lower part of stem of a glazed composition goblet; mould-made and glazed; concave indentation under foot.
Curators Comments:
Originally interpreted as a vessel similar to GR 1896,2-1.33 or fragments GR 1896,2-1.259 (to which it may be connected). For parallels, SCE IV/1D, p. 525; Peltenburg 1972, pp. 129-136. 
However, what was previously identified as the lower part of the conical cup appears to have a proper edge or rim, in which case the fragment may be from a small stand. Alternatively, the fragment should be inverted and regarded as a flat saucer-like stand on a tall ring- base.   

Bibliography:
E. Peltenburg (1972), 'On the classification of faience vases from Late Bronze Age Cyprus', Proceedings of the First Cypriological Congress (Nicosia), pp. 129-136.
Bib references: Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description:
Pottery Attic red figure guttus (oil flask with strainer) with a spout in form of a lion's head; wheel-made and with moulded and incised details; squat body, slightly splaying sides, with a convex top; flat base; the central strainer has a single hole in the middle and two outer rings of perforations; loop handle (mostly restored); vessel made of fine buff clay, decorated in red figure technique with animals on the shoulder below the strainer. 
 
On one side of the vessel is a couchant lion, facing left, whose head is formed by the spout: the details of the head are well rendered, with incised strokes for the mane; on the other side are two couchant animals facing each other: the beast on the left has pointed ears and a long tail, jaws wide open and a determined stare emphasised by the profile view of the face with a single eye (possibly a lion); its opposite number is more crudely drawn, and is either shown in profile, or else has two snouts/heads.
Two Cypriot Syllabic signs are incised on the underside of the base.
Curators Comments: Only the site (B) is given in Munro and Tubbs' description of this item but the tomb number can be deduced from its stated association with GR 1890,7-31.28 and 1890,7-31, 32 (Munro and Tubbs 1890, 48-9).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti

Description: Terracotta pedestal and bowl in Bichrome ware, possibly an incense burner or offering stand; hollow, wheel-made stand, tall and relatively narrow, splaying outwards towards the base; two groups of horizontal ridges around the shaft with a third pair of large ones just below the neck; short cylindrical neck painted with file of vertical petals or tongues, possibly imitating metal; the rim of the stand has a square profile; this supports a circular bowl with carinated sides and a flat, everted rim (Swedish Type IV or V), potted separately but attached to the stand; made of buff clay with small white inclusions, decorated in purple and reddish-brown paint: parallel bands along the body, petals/ tongues on the neck, zig-zags on the rim of the stand, triangles on the rim, a broad band inside the rim of the bowl; some chips on the surface of the stand.
Dimensions: Diameter: 18 centimetres bowl ; Height: 5 centimetres bowl ; Height: 51 centimetres stand ; Weight: 2.949 grammes; Width: 19 centimetres base
Curators Comments:
See  Karageorghis 1996, 78-80 for thymiataria and offering stands (with further bibliography) esp. cat. no. W4 from Salamis Royal Cemetery Pyre A with a similar shaped bowl. The basic form may be Phoenician in inspiration, especially those with petals and other features imitating metal examples, but the technique of manufacture and decoration is local. 
Bibliography: 
Karageorghis V. 1996, The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus VI. The Cypro-Archaic peeriod. Monsters, animals and miscellanea (Nicosia; A.G. Leventis Foundation).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Exhibition history:
Exhibited:
2018 9 May-3 Sep, Hong Kong History Museum, An Age of Luxury
2019 4 Apr-11 Aug, CaixaForum Barcelona, An Age of Luxury
2019-2020 18 Sep-12 Jan, CaixaForum Madrid, An Age of Luxury 
2020 20 Feb-25 Oct, CaixaForum Zaragoza, An Age of Luxury

Description: Sherd from a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) open vessel, possibly Furumark type FS 36; wheel-made; fine buff clay, similar slip, decorated with dark red-brown lustrous paint: scale-pattern on exterior.
Dimensions: Height: 7.20 centimetres max ; Width: 6 centimetres max
Curators Comments:
The word 'Temple' pencilled on the sherd indicates its findspot. It is the only Late Bronze Age find preserved from the CEF excavations (see Maier and Karageorghis 1984, 114 note 1 who attributes it to LHIIIA:2). The sherd may have been part of a vessel used or dedicated in the Sanctuary, though it may also have come from a disturbed tomb.  
Bibliography:
		Gardner E. et al. 1888, 'Excavations in Cyprus 1887-88. Paphos, Leontari,  Amargetti', JHS 9, 146-271. 
		Karageorghis J. 2005, Kypris. The Aphrodite of Cyprus. Ancient sources and  archaeological evidence (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation).
		Maier F.-G. 1997, 'A hundred years after Hogarth. Digging at Aphrodite's  sanctuary at Palaipaphos', CCEC 27, 127-36.
		Maier F.-G. and Karageorghis V. 1984, Paphos. History and archaeology  (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Fragment from a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) pithoid jar of Furumark Type FS 36; wheel-made; made of buff clay with similar slip, decorated with red lustrous paint: lily motifs.
Dimensions: Height: 8 centimetres max ; Width: 13 centimetres max
Curators Comments: The number C1119.2 on the sherd appears to refer to an intended extension of Walters' Catalogue of vases.

Description: Small pottery jar or tumbler in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; swelling convex body on a slightly raised base, concave underneath; thick flattened lip, chamfered slightly inwards; buff clay and cream-white slip, decorated in red and black paint: broad and narrow bands on the body; paint worn in many places.

Description: Pottery jar with a basket-handle in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid body with pointed nipple-like base; wide neck with a two-ribbed basket-handle with pointed knob on top; made of fione buff clay covered with a polished slip, decorated with black paint: parallels bands around the body.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXV, 5. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden).

Description: Small pottery jar (amphora) in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid-globular body on a raised flat base with rounded edge; conical neck and rounded everted rim; pair of opposing vertical handles; pale buff clay and slip, decorated with brown and purple paint: frieze of leaves on the neck, bands on shoulder and foot, lattice-panels framing single leaf or tree motifs on the body; St. Andrew's crosses under the handles. Description: Pottery jar in Red Polished Ware; hand-made; depressed globular body with two opposing curved horned handles extending from lower neck to upper body;  incised with zigzag decoration.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (VII D type o)
Curators Comments:
For the classification of this vessel, see Stewart 1992, 145, VII D type n. Of the three examples known to Stewart, one is from Lapithos, the other Alambra, with the third possibly coming from the Larnaca district. The findspot of the present example may help to confirm this broader distribution. 
Bibliography:
Stewart J.B. 1992, Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. SIMA III:2  (Jonsered: P. Åström).

Description: Mycenaean pottery three-handled piriform jar; wheel-made; pedestal foot on a ring base; narrow cylindrical with a flat everted rim; fine buff clay and slip, decorated with solid or multiple bands of lustrous red paint around the base, body and base; frieze of wavy lines at shoulder; repaired from fragments and restored, paint worn in many places.
Curators Comments: See also: F. Stubbings, Mycenaean pottery in Italy, p. 35 & pl. VIII,10.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. Description: Large pottery amphora in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a flat base; wide cylindrical neck with an everted, squared rim; pair of opposing loop handles on the shoulder;  made of buff clay decorated with lustrous brown and red paint: a frieze of stylised lotus flowers on the shoulder; geometrical motifs and stylised flowers in panels separated by vertical guilloches and lines on the neck; also horizonal bands of lines around the body, with a solid band of paint at the base of the neck; surface worn in places.
Curators Comments:
For parallels, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXV, 14 (unprovenanced) (see also Karageorghis et al. 2003, no. 156); Karageorghis 1970, 60 no. 8 and pl. CXIII (Salamis Cellarka Tomb 30), 152 no. 13 and pl. CLXXXI (Salamis Cellarka Tomb 105); Kargeorghis et al. 2000, no. 143 (possibly from Ormidhia).
 
The florid style, including the use of large lotus blossoms, is typical of vase workshops in the east of the island during the Cypro-Archaic period. Karageorghis dated the burials in Salamis Tomb 105 to the very end of CA I, around 600 BC. The flaring neck on both vases hint at developments in the Bichrome V repertoire, in which case the present item may also be ng close in date to that of the provenanced Salamis example. 
Karageorghis V. 1970, Excavations in the Necropolis of Salamis II (Nicosia).
Karageorghis V. et al. 2000, Ancient art from Cyprus. The Cesnola collection in the Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York).  
Karageorghis V. et al. 2003, The Cypriot collections in the Medelhausmuseet (Stockholm).
Acq name (acq): Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum

Description: Pottery jar (amphora) in White Painted ware; ovoid body; show cylindrical neck, splaying outwards slightly, with a thick squared rim; pair of opposing horizontal handles with knobs. Made of buff clay, decorated with dull black paint: concentric cirlces on the neck, wavy line around the body at mid-point, zig-zag on the neck, all framed by multiple bands of solid paint; also solid paint on handles. Surface worn and cracked.
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Wheel-made pottery:Mycenaean three-handled piriform jar of Furumark type FS44 from Late Helladic IIIA:1/2 date, with low everted rim and horizontal handles; slipped and decorated with orange-red to brown paint as encircling  bands and a scale pattern on the shoulder.
Curators Comments: Bailey considered that this might be one of the missing three-handled jars listed against Tomb 8, but conclude that this is now impossible to determine.

Description:
Pottery: Base Ring I ware strainer-jar; hand-made; ovoid-piriform lower body on a ring base; cylindrical upper body or neck with an everted rim; perforated disc across the mouth with a large central opening for straining the contents; short tubular spout at the 'shoulder';  with wish-bone handle.

Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B

Description: Pottery: Mycenaean three-handled piriform jar of Furumark type FS45; wheel-made; piriform body on a narrow swelling base; short neck with everted, angular rim; three vertical loop handles on the shoulder; made of orange-buff clay and a buff slip with painted  bands and lattice pattern in lustrous paint.
Curators Comments: The attribution to Crowfoot's Tomb 8 is secure as the number is pencilled on the vase.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery jar (amphora) in Bichrome/Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; globular-biconical body on a ring base; short neck, flaring outwards from the shoulder with a thick, rounded rim; pair of opposing loop handles at mid-body. Made of fairly coarse buff clay, decorated with brown and white paint: the body surface has been fired an orange-red colour, with horizontal bands and a alrge white lattice patter; the neck surface has been fired white, and decorated with rows of bands, white dots, and large concentric circles on the neck; handles painted solid brown.
Type series: type series: Bichrome V;  type series: Bichrome Red II
Curators Comments: This vessel is a complex hybrid of White Painted/Bichrome and Bichrome Red ware decoration, with the .reserved pale ground of the neck comparable to WP wares of this period and the light on dark decoration of the body similar to variants of Bichrome and Bichrome Red.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery three-handled piriform jar; wheel-made; decorated with painted scale pattern on shoulder.
Dimensions: Diameter: 158 millimetres; Height: 231 millimetres; Weight: 647 grammes; Width: 170 millimetres; Depth: 163 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery jar with polychrome decoration; elongated ovoid body on a low ring base; narrow neck tapering slightly inwards towards the mouth; ridge on neck below the outward-splaying flat rim; vertical strap handles from shoulder to ridge; broken stump and surface on opposite side of the neck, the remains (now lost) of a second handle or, possibly, of an applied figurine; buff-pink slip with dark red slip over which remain traces of black, pink and green paint on a white background, now very worn: traces of a black arcading with pink infill around the base, polychrome decoration around the middle with traces of floral pattern. (According to the Catalogue, this represents a wreath tied with ribbons which was visible when first excavated).
Curators Comments: This vase is a late example of Gjerstad's Polychrome White Ware, a variant of Bichrome VII, which continued into the Hellenistic I period (SCE IV/2, p. 68; SCE IV/3, pp. 57-59, 73). The the slender elongated shape of the body is unusual. Similar examples known from Tomb 8 at Ayios Ermogenis, close to or part of 'Site B' of the Turner Bequest excavations, date from the later period (McFadden, AJA 50 (1946), pl. XLII, 71-72 and SCE IV/3, fig. 22, 5). Vandenabeele includes it in her catalogue of vases with figurines holding jugs but doubts it originally had one (cat. 315 (z)): certainly there is no perforation in the shoulder for a true spout. On the other hand, the surface break below the rim is wider than the handle opposite, suggestion some form of attachment now lost. However, this may be due to subsidiary damage, as the stump on the shoulder has a profile similar to the lower part of the surviving handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery jar in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; depressed ovoid body on a raised disc base; wide flaring neck with a plain rim; opposing pair of small crescent-shaped lugs; made of buff clay, slipped and decorated with bands of black and white paint: a central wavy band around the middle of the body, also band inside the neck; small hole in the body below the handle at one side; surface of vase chipped in places.
Curators Comments: For parallels for this shape and ware see SCE IV/2, fig. LX, esp. no. 9.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery jar (amphora) in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; biconical body on a ring base; wide neck splaying outwards, with a thick rounded rim; pair of opposing horizontal handles at the shoulder. Made of buff clay, ground surface fired reddish-brown (with some reserved white bands) and with added white paint: dots around the junciton of neck, thick wavy line around the belly. Surface worn in places.
Type series: type series: Bichrome V;  type series: Bichrome Red II
Curators Comments:
The tomb number is not given in the original Register, but a note in the margin says that the numbers '280' are faintly marked on the pot. However, while Myres' tomb inventory mentions two 'black-slip amphorae: white details' but also '2 [illegible (?) old/ord] amphorae with wavy lines around', it seems from the official copy of this document that the tomb group was allocated to the CM. (See also comment on GR 1894,11-1.529 which was also associated with this tomb in the Regster annotations).  
In this variety of Bichrome/Bichrome Red ware the background is fired a dark colour over most of the surface, but with some reserved light areas, against which the added white painted decoration is contrasted.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery three-handled piriform jar; wheel-made; painted; decorated on shoulder with two rows of scale pattern framing a row of dotted rosettes and bands on body. Post-firing pot marks on two handles, one resembling an 'A', the other a vertical stroke with two short cross bars.
Inscription: Inscription type: pottery mark Inscription position: handles Inscription note: Published in N. Hirschfeld 2002. Marks on Pots: Patterns of Use in the Archaeological Record at Enkomi, in J. S. Smith (ed.) Script and Seal Use on Cyprus in the Bronze and Iron Ages, p.84
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery three-handled piriform jar; wheel-made; painted; with tricurved arches and concentric semi-circles on shoulder, bands above and below.
Dimensions: Diameter: 260 millimetres; Height: 375 centimetres; Weight: 2600 grammes; Width: 261 millimetres; Depth: 266 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Bichrome lidded pottery jar decorated with sphinxes, goats and floral motifs in red and black. The main frieze (band of decoration) on the body of the jar shows pairs of sphinxes facing each other with a floral motif between, and two more sphinxes, over similar floral motifs, each confronting a goat under either handle. The lower body shows bands of red and black and at the rim is a series of rosettes alternating with stripes and a roundel with black centre. The knobbed lid shows a frieze of guilloches at the top followed by pairs of rosettes with stripes in between and after every two an upright single spiral; below this another frieze of guilloches with rosettes with pointed petals below and 'teeth' around the lower rim.
Dimensions: Height: 36 centimetres with lid ; Height: 25.40 centimetres; Weight: 4.293 grammes; Width: 30 centimetres; Depth: 28 centimetres
Curators Comments:
See Walberg 1979, 278 for a discussion of the decorative motivs on this vessel. 
Bibliography:
Walberg G. 1979, 'A Bichrome V bowl with wavy sides;, RDAC, 276-80.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Exhibition history:
Exhibited:
2018 9 May-3 Sep, Hong Kong History Museum, An Age of Luxury
2019 4 Apr-11 Aug, CaixaForum Barcelona, An Age of Luxury 
2019-2020 18 Sep-12 Jan, CaixaForum Madrid, An Age of Luxury 
2020 20 Feb-25 Oct, CaixaForum Zaragoza, An Age of Luxury
2024-2025, 1 May – 4 Aug, China, Suzhou Museum, I Am Ashurbanipal
Acq notes (acq): For details of the acquisition, see letters of vendor/shipping company and Original Letters 1906-08, L-Q, nos 950-962.

Description: Pottery three-handled piriform jar, Furumark Shape 39. Lower body deformed and foot chipped. Painted with thick and thin lustrous brown bands and spirals (FM 49) in the shoulder zone. Brown bands inside and outside neck.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery jar in Bichrome Red ware; wheelmade; ovoid body on a ring base; wide conical neck, with a thick rounded rim; pair of opposing handles set horizontally at the shoulder. Made of buff clay covered in a red slip, overlain with black and white on the neck and body, and with three large plant motifs in white on each side of the body. Painted decoration is damaged in a number of places.
Curators Comments: The tomb number is not given in the original Register but a note in the margin seems to refer the reader to Myres' notes for this tomb. However there is no explicit mention of a vessel with this design in his tomb inventory. Furthermore, according to the official copy of Myres' notebook, the tomb tomb was allocated to the CM. (See also comment on GR 1894,11-1.528 which was also associated with Tomb 280 in the Register annotations).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery: Wheel-made Mycenaean IIIA1 pithoid jar with three flat vertical handles on the shoulder, Furumark Type FS 31, decorated with bands and scale pattern on the body and a band of dots on the rim in dark red paint on a cream ground; below the foot is a painted mark or letter; the rim is chipped.
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription position: base Inscription script: Cypro-Minoan Inscription note: Cypro-Minoan?
Language is unclear. Cannot be read.

Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.

Description: Pottery jar in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body, tapering inwards to a ring base; annular neck with a flat disck rim; pair of opposing triple-rim handles; made of buff clay decorated with sedecorated on the shoulder with birds within geometric borders.

Description: Pottery miniature bottle in Red Polished III ware; handmade; depressed ovoid body with a round base and a narrow cylindrical neck with an everted rim; pair of opposing lug handles, with pierced string holes; made of buff clay covered with a burnished dark red slip, decorated with lime-filled incisions: zig-zags and hatched squares between horizontal bands.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (VII D i2)
Curators Comments: Stewart regarded this vessel as a miniature variant of larger amphora types, suggesting that it could also be classed in his VII Group D2 (Corpus Part 2, p. 146ff).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery storage jar ('amphora') in Red Polished III ware; handmade; globular body with a rounded base and a tall cylindrical neck with everted rim; pair of opposing horned handles from lower neck to shoulder; made of fairly fine buff clay covered with a polished orange-red slip, decorated with lime-filled incisions: zig-zags and bands composed of parallel lines on the body, hatched lozenges; surface worn in places.
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (VII A2 p3)
Curators Comments:
Smith 1888, 265-6 discusses the group of objects donated by Falkland Warren; see also Walters 1897, 71-3 no. 16.
  
Bibliography: 
C. Smith 1888, 'British Museum', The Classical Review, 2,8 
Walters, H.B. 1897: 'On some antiquities of the Mycenaean Age recently acquired by the British Museum'. JHS XVII,
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery jar ('amphora') in Red Polished III ware; handmade; squat globular body and a round base and wide flaring neck with four pierced projections on the rim; pair of opposing handles with round sections set diagonally mid-body; pair of pierced lugs on the junction of neck and body; fine buff clay covered with a burnished red slip; white-filled incised decoration: concentrics, zig-zags, lozenges, bands of horizontal and vertical parallel lines; surface worn and accreted in places.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (VII E c2)
Curators Comments:
The group donated by Warren was orignally described by Smith (1888, 266) and later by Walters (1897, 71-3 and fig. 9). 
The horizontal handles on this vessel are not common in the RP repertoire. An RP vessel with similar handles and shape was found in Ayia Paraskevi Tomb 8a (Kromholz 1982, 38, 115 and fig. XIX). A vessel of comparable shape was found in a tomb excavated in the Ayia Paraskevi cemetery in 2000, classified as RP III and with similar rim projections (see Georgiou 2002, 51 and fig. 1 (Tomb 25, no. 3) with references to further parallels). More recently, a very similar example - with modelled figues on the rim - was found in Tomb 50 (Georgiou 2013, 86 and fig. 6).
Bibliography: 
Georgiou G. 2002, 'The necropolis of Agia Paraskevi revisited', RDAC, 49-65. 
Georgiou G. 2013, '1955-2013: the necropolis of Nicosia Ayia Paraskevi almost 60 years after Stewart's excavations', in A.B. Knapp et al. (eds), J.R.B. Stewart. An archaelogical legacy. SIMA CXXXIX (Uppsala), 81-90.  
Kromholz S. 1982, 'The Bronze Age necropolis at Ayia Paraskevi (Nicosia): Unpublished tombs in the Cyprus Museum. SIMA Pocket-book 17, Göteborg.
Smith C. 1888, 'British Museum', The Classical Review, 2,8,  265-6.
Walters H.B. 1897, 'On some antiquities of the Mycenaean Age recently acquired by the British Museum', JHS XVII, 63-77.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean piriform jar of Furumark type FS36, with narrow cylindrical neck and out-turned flat rim, three vertical handles and a spreading foot; slipped; decorated with orange-red to brown paint consisting of encircling bands with flowers on the upper body; on the shoulder are raised bosses (false rivets ?);heavily restored; the foot is chipped.
Curators Comments: The tomb number is provided in the Register but Bailey (p. 12) observes that  this is uncertain as the vase is not mentioned in the tomb lists. At the same  time, it was Walters who entered the finds from HST in the Register and he  may have had a reason for attributing this item to Tomb IV.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery Bucchero Wheel-made ware small jug; wheel-made; round mouth; stepped vertical rim; narrow cylindrical neck; ridge at neck to body join; slightly piriform body; ring base; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; body decorated with vertical ridges formed by shaving excess clay from body whilst vessel in leather-hard stage; self-slipped and burnished to a slight lustre; surface and clay dark grey.
Curators Comments: This tomb supposedly assigned to Cyprus Museum.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery coarse ware jug; depressed ovoid body with flat, slightly raised base; somewhat carinated at shoulder; vertical wide neck with flat everted rim; vertical strap handle from shoulder to rim; coarse dark red clay with traces of white paint or slip on body; green wreath with yellow berries (the latter very faded) painted diagonally on the upper body.
Curators Comments: Both shape and polychrome decoration have their origins in the Type VII vases of the preceding Cypro-Classical II period (SCE IV/3, pp. 57-59, 73) from examples which it is sometimes difficult to distinguish on stylistic grounds alone.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/3 / Swedish Cyprus Expedition; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery jug in Base Ring I ware; hand-made; spherical-ovoid body on a wide disc-shaped foot; tall cylindrical neck with a prominent cutaway spout; strap handle made up of three ribs extending from shoulder to mid-neck (a pair of applied ridges runs around the neck at the juncture with the handle); made of semi-coarse buff clay covered with a lustrous slip fired reddish-orange throughout; decorated on the body,  base of neck and neck with applied relief decoration with incised cross-hatching; the relief lines on the body are arranged as antithetic spirals, resembling snakes; part of the spout is missing, and the surface worn and pitted in places.
Type series: type series: Base Ring I (VI D 2 c β' no. 14)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Pottery Bucchero Hand-made ware small jug; hand-made; concave neck; flared rim with indented outer edge; vertical handle from rim to shoulder rising slightly above rim; handle profile rectangular; handle pierced through body; ovoid body with ring base; ridge at neck base and vertical relief ribbing down body from below neck; thin matt brown to black slip.

Description: Pottery Bucchero Hand-made small jug; short cylindrical neck with flaring rim with flattened exterior face; high vertical strap handle rising above rim to shoulder; lower handle attachment inserted through body wall and smoothed; shallow relief ridge at neck body join; body ovoid with low ring base; body decorated with vertical fluting; thin matt dark brown mottled slip; fabric brown.

Description: Pottery small jug; Bucchero Handmade ware; hand-made; neck slightly tapering to thickened rim with pointed profile; rim slightly pinched on one side but may be unintentional; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; relief ridge at neck to body join; globular body with high ring base; body decorated with vertical fluted relief ridges; thin matt dark grey-brown slip.

Description: Pottery jug in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; narrow tubular neck with a slight ridge half-way up; flat everted rim; arching handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and somewhat lustrous red slip, decorated with black paint: vertical concentric circles on each side with a bull's-eye motif in the centre, band of horizontal concentrics around the shoulder, parallel lines on the neck, solid lip and handle.

Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District  Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Drab Polished ware pottery jug; hand-made; globular body with beak-mouth and cylindrical neck; round handle and four double suspension-rings; incised decoration of pendant lines and impressed annules; deep red slip.
Curators Comments: Classified by Åström in his Black Slip Type VIII.C.7.a, but actually Drab Polished ware.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age (classed as BS II); Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Small pottery jug in Late Cypriot Bucchero Handmade ware; globular body on a splaying ring base; tapering cylindrical neck with everted rim: the slightly chamfered edge has a groove down the middle; vertical stripe handle with square profile from rim to shoulder; ridge at junction of the neck runs around the vase, vertical relief ribbing from the neck to just above the base; dark-pink buff clay with a thin matt brown to black slip: the surface of the neck has been finished with a tool.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery jug or askos in the form of bird; hand-made; depressed elliptical body with a spout tapering inwards towards a trefoil mouth; three feet, two at the front, one larger at the back; wings and tail feathers rendered as simple projections; arching handle from back-ridge to the rim; buff clay with small micaceous inclusions; brown painted decoration of parallel lines intersected by vertical or diagonal elements, pair of eyes on the mouth.

Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery juglet with a black slip; piriform body on a low rounded base; relatively tall, narrow neck, with slightly concave sides; oval-sectioned handle arching from shoulder to rim; everted rim; partly worn black lustrous slip.
Curators Comments: Classified by Malmgren as Black Lustrous Wheelmade, but the fabric resembles Black Slip wares. The vessel may be an attempt to imitate or echo imported Tell Yahudiyeh juglets.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Pottery deep bowl in White Painted Ware ware; handmade; squat globular body with round base and a wide mouth with everted rim; rising vertical handle from rim to shoulder; purple hatched triangles.
Type series: type series: White Painted III;  type series: SCE type (WP III, II b)
Curators Comments:
Whilst this style has been classified as White Painted (WP) IV in SCE IV/1B (Åström, 1972, p. 50), the triangular pattern is typical of WP V Fine Line Style as discussed by Maguire (1991). 
Bibliography: 
Åström, P., 1972. The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle  Cypriot Bronze Age, Stockholm.
Maguire, L. 1991. 'The classification of Middle Bronze Age Painted pottery: Wares, styles... workshops?', In: J. Barlow et al. (eds), Cypriot ceramics: Reading the prehistoric record. Philadelphia, p. 59-65.

Description: Pottery jug in White Painted/Bichrome ware; ovoid-globular body with a narrow neck splaying outwards to a wide mouth; ridge on the neck at the junction with the handle; handle arches up from the shoulder; made of buff-pink clay and slip, possibly polished, decorated with black paint: bands of finely drawn parallel lines on the body and on. rings inside the mouth, two curved strokes beneath handle.

Description: Pottery Base Ring II ware jug; hand-made; tall neck, widening slightly towards top; everted rim with indented lip; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder; ovoid body with broad low ring base; decorated in white paint with sets of six lines executed with multiple brush tool, horizontal on neck, zig-zag on body and horizontal on lower body and shoulder; thin grey to dark brown slip, with slightly lustrous traces of burnishing preserved.

Description: Pottery jug in White Painted ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; narrow neck tapering inwards to a trefoil mouth; flat handle from shoulder to rim. Made of fine buff clay decorated with semi-lustrous red-brown paint: bands around the mid-body, around the neck and base; a stylised three-leaf floral motif (?) beneath the spout; slight depressions on the spout may indicate the location of painted eyes now worn away. Description: Pottery jug in White Painted IV; hand-made; depressed globular body with flat base; short neck; high knobbed handle ; buff slip; red painted lattice-panels and zig-zags.

Description: Pottery White Slip II jug; hand-made; concave tapering neck with slightly flaring rim; trefoil mouth; high strap handle from rim to shoulder; globular body; slightly concave flattened base; thick light greyish buff slip; matt dark brown paint; neck decorated with three sets of thin double lines framed by thicker lines; band at neck base; lattice band on shoulder with pendant alternating lattice bands and hatched lozenge bands; off-centre frontal motif of double hatched lozenge band framed by single lozenge rows; handle with zig-zag of double thin lines framed by thick lines; paint on neck interior of double vertical lines framed by thick lines.
Curators Comments: 1897,0401.866-871 were originally attributed to Tomb 14 in the register. However, a note made soon after states that tomb 14 was allocated to the Cyprus Museum and that these objects are not from Tomb 14. They also do not tally with the description of Tomb 14 finds in the notebook and therefore have been provenanced only to 'Enkomi'.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery: redware jug; bulbous body; trefoil mouth; looped handle; black painted lattice-band and double-chevrons.

Description: Pottery small jug of Bucchero Wheelmade Ware; wheel-made; neck slightly tapering towards round mouth; flared rim with ridged exterior; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; ridge at base of neck; vertical ribbing incised down body; ring base; thin reddish brown, matt, flaking slip on exterior and neck interior; buff clay.

Description: Red polished pottery jug; hand-made; globular body; no base; straight vertical neck with angular, cut away spout (partly missing); vertical handle curving from body to mouth; coarse buff-orange fabric with many inclusions; thin, flakey slip; probably Red Polished III or related ware.
Curators Comments: For comparable examples see SCE IV/1A, figs. LXVIII-LXVIX
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery jug, transitional White Slip I-II ware; globular body with flattened base; wide neck with everted lip; flat handle; white slip; band of black painted ladder pattern round upper body, four similar vertical bands descend to base.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Small pottery spouted jug in White Painted ware; wheel-made; ovoid body with short conical neck; small conical spout on shoulder; single handle from shoulder to with conical spout (broken); pale clay and slip, decorated in dark brown paint: multiple parallel bands on the lower body, pendant concentric hooks, spirals of finer parallel lines on upper body, wavy line on the neck, single bands on the handle, spout and inside the mouth.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Drab Polished ware pottery jug with globular body and rounded base; round handle from neck to shoulder; long curved beaked spout; grey clay with black polished slip (worn in places); incised decoration with white infill of zigzag lines and cirlces.
Curators Comments: Included by Åström in his Black Slip II class, but reclasssified by Malmgren as Drab Polished ware.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age (classed as BS II); Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Pottery jug with figural decoration in White Painted ware; wheel-made; squat globular body on a narrow, flat base; wide concave neck with a trefoil mouth; arching handle from shoulder to rim; greenish-cream clay and slip, decorated in black-brown paint (worn to give an greenish ting) in Free Field style: two birds in flight, drawn in outline with hatched bodies and tails and solid wings, flanking two stylised trees; single band on the neck; a pair of eyes on the mouth; zig-zag on the handle; part of rim missing.
Curators Comments:
The vase is not given a findspot in the Register but a later annotation, probably in the hand of H.B. Walters, refers to the Catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richer 1899, p. 9) which mentions two vases decorated with birds found in tombs at Mari excavated by Max Ohnefalsch-Richter for the BM in 1881. In his short discussion of these excavations, Reinach mentions among the finds 'une petite oenochoé verte ornée de deux oiseaux d'eau peintes en noir' (1891, 188). The clay of the vase is indeed a greenish hue which seems to correspond to the present vessel. Reinach however mentions only one vase among the few finds described. 
The text of the CCM possibly refers to another bird vase found in a tomb of ancient Kition (modern Larnaca) the same year (GR 1881,8-24.47; BM Vase C817). A similar annotation in the Register also hinted that this might be from Mari but, apart from the fact that it is given Kition as a findspot, the jug is also of a shape, fabric and decorative type quite different from the bird vases made by the 'Amathus Workshop' (see Benson 1982). 
The present jug is attributed by Benson to a specific workshop at Amathus (1982, 140. Phase A, no. 4). On the species, see Benton 1961, pl. II,2.
NB this version of the text was written in March 2017 and should supersede previous comments. The attribution of this vessel to Mari seems assured, while the original attribution of GR 1881,8-24.47 to Kition also seems correct. 

Bibliography: 
Benson, J. 1982, 'The Amathus workshop', RDAC (1982), 138-43.
Benton, S. 1961, 'Cattle egrets and bustards in Greek art', Journal of Hellenisc Studies, JHS 81 (1961), 44-55. 
Myres, J. and Ohnefalsch-Richer, M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press). 
Reinach, S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient (Paris: Firmin-Didot).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Kiely 2011b / Maroni
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Pottery: Bichrome-Red ware jug, painted in black and added white with concentric circles and a goat.

Description: Pottery Base Ring II ware jug; hand-made; tall neck, widening towards top with flaring rim with indented lip; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder, two incised lines down exterior; ovoid body with broad low ring base; decorated in white paint with sets of four lines executed with multiple brush tool, horizontal on neck, zig-zag on shoulder and horizontal on lower body; thin matt very dark brown slip.

Description: Pottery Bucchero Hand-made ware small jug; hand-made; neck widening to flared rim with flattened outer edge; vertical handle from rim to shoulder rising slightly above rim; handle profile square; handle pierced through body; ovoid body with ring base; ridge at neck base and vertical relief ribbing down body from below neck; thin matt brown to black slip.

Description: Pottery Black Slip V ware juglet; hand-made; long narrow, slightly tapering neck, funnel-shaped mouth with rim thinning to a point; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder; globular body with flattened base; matt slip mottled from black to red; incised decoration on body; horizontal triple-framed band around entire body containing: four triple-framed vertical bands filled with horizontal herringbone motif interspersed with three dashed diamonds; below handle are a triple vertical line intersecting two running vertical dashed diamonds, a vertical herringbone motif with a central line is to the left.

Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District     Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Part a pottery White Painted VII jug with attached terracotta figurine, known as a woman-and-pitcher jug; only part of the neck remains; the front of the figurine was mould-made of reddish buff clay, with the back and right arm hand-made; decorated with thick red paint now worn in places; the terracotta figurine is of a female dressed in a chiton; the right arm was holding a pitcher, now missing and the left arm is by the side.
Curators Comments:
This is possibly the fragment of a woman-and-pitcher jug found in Site D ('Cistern') at Salamis though this is described as 'rude' in style suggesting an earlier period than the present item. 
 
See Vandenbeele (1998) for a comprehensive survey and study of this kind of jug.
Bibliography: 
Vandenabeele F. 1998. Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe, SIMA Vol. CXX, Jonsered.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 2 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 2, British Museum 2; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Munro and Tubbs 1891 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1890. Third season's work. Salamis

Description:
Pottery jug in Bichrome Ware, decorated with a bird in the 'free field' style; wheel-made; ovoid body on a long ring base; nattow neck with a trefoil mouth; single strap handle from shoulder to rim; made of buff clay, fired to a cream-white surface, decorated with dark brown to black and red paint. 
The field below the trefoil mouth is filled with a large bird in flight facing to the right; the body is drawn in silhouette, except for the wing which is hatched or filled, while the eye shown in profile; a single large wing, drawn in outline but hatched with parallel lines extends behind the animal; the legs extend in front, the left one with three claws, the right with four. Two swastikas in the field behind the bird's neck. A pair of eyes is drawn on the mouth; hook motif below the handle which blends with the solid paint on the handle itself; along the handle is a string of small white panels.
The vase is slightly dented in places from firing; irregular patchs may be the result of contact with other vases in the kiln; surface worn in places.
Bib references: Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Miss D K Pawle

Description: Earthenware jug, wheel-thrown (?) in reddish body, with tripod feet and tall neck, decorated with three rows of rouletting on body and a single spiral of rouletting round neck; two small bosses at base of neck below lip.
Curators Comments:
Eth Doc 1752
The original label reads: 'Jug of Korno pottery, handmade ware from Cyprus imitating Bronze Age forms from Miss du Plat Taylor, Purves, [?], Berwickshire.' An annotation in a later hand reads: 'The design is almost identical with Congo (upper Ubangi) type ? introduced by sugar slaves. Rouletting not found on bronze age or classical period Cyprus pottery. It is found [on] figure scenes on Rhodes vases 8th c BC and Etruscan ware - prob. derived from Sumerian cylinder seals (Forsdyke). See Ancient Egypt 1930'.
     Sir John Forsdyke was Keeper of the Greek & Roman Department at this date, becoming Director in 1936. The donor's name on the label should read Taylor-Purves (her mother's maiden name was Purves). She wrote on Cypriot Bronze Age pottery so was probably interested in this piece as an imitation of Bronze Age forms.
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Miss J du Plat Taylor

Description: Pottery three-handled piriform jug; wheel-made; three vertical handles from shoulder to mouth and no room for a rim; mouth cutaway; decorated in reddish brown paint with bands on neck and body and flowers on shoulder.

Description: Pottery jug in White Painted/Bichrome ware; wheel-made. Spherical body; thick cylindrical neck with a ridge mid-way up and an everted rim; single large single handle, with an oval section, extending from shoulder to mid-neck. Description: Pottery jug of White Painted VI ware; hand-made; cylindrical neck with flaring rim with concave inner profile and pointed end; beaked mouth; vertical handle with flattened oval profile from mid neck to shoulder, end inserted through body wall and smoothed; globular body with slightly conves flattened base; decorated with linear motifs in brown paint of variable thickness; horizontal bands on neck; body decorated in two zones; on the upper are three broad vertical hatched bands alternating with three framed double zig-zags and one hatched band, vertical line down handle and on either side; on the lower are two horizontal bands below maximum diameter with five pendant sets of multiple vertical lines to base; pale cream slip, burnished to a medium lustre, vertically on neck and handle; mended from sherds, some areas missing.

Type series: type series: White Painted Latticed Diamond Style (SCE type IIa)

Description: Pottery jug of bichrome-red ware with female figurine holding a pierced jug, serving as a spout, opposite the handle; ovoid body with long slim concave neck; high splaying base; vertical two ribbed handle from shoulder to just below rim; buff-cream clay with red slip; body of vase decorated with alternating bands of black and white paint; bands of black paint around the rim (inside and out), on the neck and at juncture of neck and body; chevron arrangement of parallel lines between vertical bands in black paint on handle; loop motive in black paint on either side of terminal of handle and body; figure is handmade with moulded face, paint mostly vanished; she wears a long dress extending to the simply moulded feet, and a cloak around the shoulders; head covered by conical cap with tresses of hair falling on each of the body as far the simply rendered breasts; her right hand extends to hand of spout in the form of a jug; jug has a pinched spout and bands of black paint on the rim and globular body; left hand rendered crudely as two 'digits' extends as far as stomach.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Cook 1979 / Cypriote art in the British Museum; Tatton-Brown 1987 / Ancient Cyprus; Tatton-Brown 1997 / Ancient Cyprus

Description: Pottery Bucchero Hand-made ware small jug; hand-made; neck widening to folded rim with flattened outer edge; vertical handle from rim to shoulder rising slightly above rim; handle profile rectangular with central ridge on outer face; handle pierced through body; ovoid body with low ring base; ridge at neck base and vertical ribbing down body from mid shoulder; thin matt brown to black mottled slip;
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome ware; squat globular body on a narrow base; narrow neck, slightly concave, with a trefoil mouth; handle from shoulder to rim; pink-buff clay and slip, decorated in black and red-purple paint in Free Field style: three birds in flight facing right, drawn in outline with hatched wings and the body and tail filled in with purple; a single band around the neck, zig-zag pattern along the handle; rim is chipped.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: J. Benson, The Amathus workshop, RDAC 1982, p. 141, (Manner of the 'V & A painter' no. a); R.S. Morris & D.J. Symons, Four figured style vases from Cyprus, RDAC 1985, p. 187.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery jug in Base Ring II ware; handmade; piriform body with a ring base and a cylindrical, slightly widening neck and an everted neck; the handle is form mid-neck to shoulder, with pellets applied either side of the handle, at its top and base, resembling rivets of a metal vessel; made in orange clay with a mottled brown, lustrous slip.
Type series: type series: Base Ring II (SCE type IXB 1f)
Curators Comments: Two pencilled inscriptions on the base, one is the catalogue number, the other apparently 'Sandwith' whihc, if correct, refers to Thomas Sandwith from whose collection Frannks may have acquired the vessel.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware spouted jug; egg-shaped body; conical spout on shoulder; arched handle over mouth; concentric circles on body.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXIX, 11 and 12. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern survey of the ware with a proposed revision to the chronology.

Description: Pottery jug in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular-biconical body on a flat base; narrow necl and trefoil spout; small arching handle from shoulder to rim; made from buff clay with a brownish-red slip, decorated with black paint: parallel lines on the body, single bands on the base of the neck and on the mouth, eyes on the spout, ladder pattern on the handle; the vessel is slightly dented, possibly in firing, and its surface is worn.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: J. Birmingham, AJA 67 (1963), 35,f.

Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Pottery jug; Base Ring II ware; hand-made; round mouth with flaring rim; long cylindrical neck with ridge at join to body; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder, incised with three vertical lines down exterior; oviod body and flaring ring base; decorated in white paint with sets of four horizontal and crossing diagonal lines executed with a multiple brush tool; thin, dark brown slip burnished to a low lustre, worn in places, fabric pinkish brown.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot III

Description: Pottery piriform jug with a flat handle; wheel-made; painted; decorated on the body with bands and a double row of crescent-shaped markings with rows of dots between; on the handle are bars; the surface is worn and the rim is chipped.

Description: Pottery Base Ring II ware jug; hand-made; neck widening to flaring rim with flattened outer edge; vertical strap handle from mid neck to shoulder with two vertical incised lines down outer face; ridge at neck base; ovoid body narrowing to wide ring base with flattened outer edge; decorated with white lines painted with multiple brush (sets of five strokes), horizontal bands on neck and crossing oblique bands on body; thin, matt dark brown to purple mottled slip; nearly half rim missing.

Description: Pottery jug in White Painted ware; globular-ovoid body with a short concave neck and trefoil mouth; flat base; trefoil mouth; arching handle from shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated in black paint: geometric motif below the spout of four triangles arranged around the corners of a concentric square, a single band around the junction of the shoulder and neck, on hanlde, a ladder motif and St. Andrew's cross with two hooks from the base, a pair of eyes on the mouth.

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome ware; ovoid body on a flat base; wide, slightly concave neck with a trefoil mouth; handle from shoulder to rom; buff clay and reddish-buff slip, decorated with black and purple-red paint: horizontal bands around the body and neck, groups of short strokes on the lip, red stripe along handle, around the shoulder are five motifs consisting of three lines converging at one end; surface of vase very worn in places.

Description: Pottery jug in a variant of Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a very broad disc foot; narrow conical-convex sides with a very tall trefoil mouth; single handle (elliptical section) from shoulder to rim. Made of fine buff clay with a semi-lustrous reddish-brown slip decorated with brown paint: horizontal and vertical concentric circles on both sides, irregular wavy lines on the neck, floral or plant motif below the trefoil mouth, and a painted garland at the base of the handle.
Curators Comments: See SCE IV/2, fig. LX no. 2 for a parallel from Marion Swedish Tomb 25.

Description: Pottery Base Ring II jug; hand-made; rim flaring and indented on exterior edge; neck tapering; relief ridge at neck to body join; body slightly piriform with low flaring ring base; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder decorated with two incised lines down exterior; neck and body decorated in white paint with horizontal, vertical and diagonal sets of five lines executed with multiple brush tool; thin, matt, mottled red to dark brown slip; fabric reddish brown; lime spalling on surface.

Description: Pottery Base Ring I small  jug; hand-made; tall cylindrical neck with beaked mouth and flaring rim with concave end; strap handle from upper neck to shoulder; ring base; decorated with applied and incised hatched scrolls on body, neck base and around neck at handle join; red clay with thin, lustrous dark brown slip, worn in places.

Description: Pottery side-spouted jug; ovoid body; wheel-made; narrow, slightly tapering neck with round mouth and flaring rim; vertical handle, oval in section, from rim to shoulder; conical spout on shoulder at right angle to handle; pale buff self slip; horizontal band at neck base with pendant vertical lines to base, band at rim, down handle exterior and top of spout; brown paint; currently in two large and several small fragments.
