Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware small jug; hand-made; cylindrical neck flaring to everted rim with beaked mouth; vertical rectangular profiled handle from upper neck to shoulder; globular body; low ring base; horizontal relief band above wavy line from shoulder to maximum diameter, partially missing; two horizontal relief bands around neck at handle join; thin, dark brown lustrous slip, worn in places; brown clay.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Curators Comments: Incorrect registration number on object. Has 1897,0401.977 which is duplicated on a small Base Ring jar from the same tomb. However, has the correct BM catalogue number on vessel.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery bichrome red ware woman-and-pitcher jug; ovoid shaped body with tall slightly concave neck and wide splaying lip; short pedestal and splaying foot; reddish clay and slip; alternating black and whote bands on the body, solid blank on the rim, inside and out; figure wears a long robe and a pointed cap and head-band or diadem on a roughtly moulded face; right hand extends forward to hold the jug; jug is ovoid with a trefoilated spout (handle broke); left hand of figurine is folded below her breast and holds a round pellet-shaped item, possibly a flower or an apple to chest; handle is missing; small hole in body just below handle.
Type series: type series: Bichrome V (recorded as Bichrome V -VII-);  type series: Bichrome VI;  type series: Bichrome VII
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir William Mitchell Ramsay

Description: Pottery flask in White Painted III-V String-Hole style; hand-made; globular body; tubular spout; two string-holes on handle; red chequer-patterns and lattice-panels.
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description: Pottery jug in Red Polished III; handmade; globular body and rounded base with a tall narrow tapering neck with everted rim; single short handle from mid-neck to shoulder opposite an angular strinhole; dark buff clay  with a dark red polished slip worn in places, especially on the upper body and handle; decorated with incised bands and zig-zags.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (I B3 f2)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery Base Ring II ware small jug; hand-made; cylindrical neck, widening slightly towards top, flaring rim with indented lip; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder, two incised lines down exterior; ovoid body with broad low ring base; angular relief ridge at neck to body join; decorated in white paint with sets of five lines executed with multiple brush tool, horizontal on neck, diagonal on body; thin matt very dark brown slip, brown fabric; paint and slip only preserved on one side of vessel.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery jug with vertical handle, probably a dipping jug, in Red Polished Mottled ware; hand-made; deep oval body with round base and a short wide neck with everted rim; angular vertical handle rising from rim to shoulder, opposite a small pierced vertical projection on the shoulder; slipped in red and polished without decoration and fired to a mottled red and black colour; some chips on the rim.
Culture: Early Cypriot I; Early Cypriot II
Curators Comments:
Similar vertical handled bowls, also known as ladles or dipper bowls which is more accurate, have been found at Marki-Alonia (Frankel and Webb 2006, 109-110), at Psematismenos-Trelloukkas and generally at central and southern sites but they are rare at Vounous (Georgiou et al. 2011, 205-6). This example has a somewhat deeper bowl than other published examples. The closest parallel in Stewart's classification are his RPIII 'bowls with vertical handles' (2012, 56, XIII M2 type b - the illustrated example from Florence (pl. 5,10) is quite close to the present in shape and also has knobbed decoration - though the generic difference in shape with his M3 group is not that apparent. On this basis, the present item might be later in date than the standard RP I-II mottled types and/or belong in the RP III Mottled tradition.  
Bibliography: 
Frankel D. and Webb, J.M. 2006, Marki Alonia. An Early and Middle Bronze Age settlement in  Cyprus. Excavations 1995-2000. SIMA CXXIII:2 (Sävedalen).
		 
Georgiou G. et al. 2011, Psematismenos-Trelloukkas. An Early Bronze Age  cemetery in Cyprus (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities).
Stewart J.R. 2012, Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part 4 (Uppsala: Åström)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Small pottery jug in Red-on-Black ware; hand-made; spherical body with a cylindrical, concave neck; plain everted lip; round base; high handle from shoulder to rim; made of coarse buff clay covered with thick, polished black paint decorated with deep red stripes; surface worn in places and possibly shows signs of differential firing.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Curators Comments:
The juglet is listed included in a sequence of objects said to be from tombs at Amathus and Limassol without distinguishing which site. This was amended in Walters' vase catalogue to '[F]rom the neighbourhood of Amathus'. However no sites of this period are known from the immediate vicinity of the Iron Age acropolis, so it is likely that this item (and the EC-MC Bronze Age spindle whorl GR 1880,7-10.110) was found in a tomb of this date at Limassol. See Karageorghis and Violaris 2012, 22-3 (with refs) on the EC-MC burial grounds around modern Limassol. 
The ware originates in the Karpas peninsula of north-east Cyprus. See SCE IV/1B, 108-18 for details of this ware; also 162-98, esp. charts on pages 197-8, for other occurrences and relative chronology. It is mainly found in the east of the island, but examples are also known along the south coast at Hala Sultan Tekke, Maroni-Psematismeno and Limassol (Tomb 70/4 and Erimi Tomb 9/3, on which see Karageorghis and Violaris 2012, 220 and individual tomb entries).The juglet is close to one in Nitovikla Tomb 2, no. 17 (SCE I, 412 and pl. LXIX) (http://collections.smvk.se/carlotta-mhm/web/object/3211695) (We are grateful to Matt Spiegelman for providing this information).
Bibliography: 
Karageorghis V. and Violaris Y. 2012, Tombs of the Late Bronze Age in the Limassol area, Cyprus (17th-13th centuries BC) (Limassol).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the   Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material   originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due   to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The   material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was   probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District   Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Mycenaean pottery jug; wheel-made; globular-biconical body with wide neck and thick, slightly everted rim; vertical strap handle, now mostly missing, extending from body to rim; flat, slightly raised ring base; buff slip and dull red to black painted decoration: seven bands of wider parallel lines on body, painted rim and handle; rim chipped, body abraded.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB1
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description:
Pottery Base Ring II ware jug; hand-made; piriform body on a flat base; tall cylindrical neck (prominent ridge at junction with body); everted rim with trefoil mouth; strap handle from rim to shoulder; two incised crosses on handle.
Orange fabric with grey core and a semi-burnished black slip; numerous small pits over the surface, chipped rim.
Inscription: Inscription type: pottery mark Inscription position: on handle Inscription note: marked with two crosses
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery jug in Red Polished (? mottled) ware; hand-made; ovoid body on a slightly flattened base; narrow cylindrical neck with an everted rim; loop handle, with an oval section, from shoulder to mid-neck; small pierced lug on the neck opposite the handle. Made of buff-orange clay with a semi-lustrous self-slip, surface mottled in places (perhaps deliberately).
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Curators Comments: Possibly related to Stewart I B2b, var. c pl. XXIII,2.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery jug in White Painted Pendant Line Style); hand-made; globular-ovoid body on a rounded base; narrow concave neck with a flaring mouth; single rounded handle arching from shoulder to rim. Made of fairly fine buff clay with similar slip, decorated with purple-red paint: vertical wavy lines framed by bands of parallel lines from the shoulder to the base; two bands formed of parallel lines just below the junction of body and neck; horizontal bands on the neck.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: White Painted Pendent Line Style (SCE type IA 2b)
Curators Comments:
According to the excavator, this vessel was found in the same tomb as the Late Heladic IIIA2 globular flask GR 1884,1210.115 (BM Vase C561). If this is correct, the difference in date between the two suggests that the tomb was used on a number of occasions from MC II-III down to the LCIIB or IIC periods.
Reuse/continued use of tombs across the MC to LC period has also been observed in Nicosia (Merrillees 2012 for a tomb excavated by Ohnefalsch-Richter; Kromholz 1982, Tombs 6 and 15). 
Bibliography: 
Kromholz, S. 1982, The Bronze Age necropolis at Ayia Paraskevi (Nicosia): Unpublished tombs in the Cyprus Museum (P. Åström: Göteborg). 
Merrillees, R. 2012, The 'Ochsenkrater-Grab' from Nicosia Ayia Paraskevi. SIMAL Pocket-book 177 (Uppsala: Åström).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; depressed globular-ovoid lower body on a flat base, with a curving conical upper part (described as 'acorn-shaped' in the catalogue); narrow  neck with trefoil mouth; double-ribbed handle; buff clay and slip, decorated with brown and red paint: horizontal bands around lower body, triangles and stylised trees on the upper body, eyes on the mouth, stripe down handle, crossed by short bars, rings around the neck; vessel repaired from fragments but complete.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Pottery strainer jug in White Wheelmade III ware; ovoid body and long, narrow, slightly concave nack leading to a plain, everted rim; vertical strap handle from shoulder to rim; trough-shaped spout at shoulder with perforations in body of vessel for straining; ring base; decorated in matt dark-brown clay with narrow parallel lines on body and around base of neck; concentric semi-circles filled with rows of dots on shoulder.
Culture: Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made III
Curators Comments: For similar examples from this region see Hadjisavvas, 'LCIIC to LCIIIA without intruders. The case of Alassa-Pano Mandilaris', in: Barlow, Bolger and Kling eds. 'Cypriot Ceramics. Reading the archaeological record', 1993, pp. 173-179, esp. figs 17.1-5; Kling 1989,pp. 153ff for a general survey.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Buchholz 2001 / Siebkannen; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Benson 1972 / Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds. Excavated by J.F. Daniel; Kling 1989 / Mycenaean IIIC:1b and related pottery in Cyprus

Description: Pottery jug; flat base; spherical body; short narrow neck; wide mouth; flat handle; purple slip and close-set horizontal ribs on body.
Curators Comments:
This is a larger and more globular-shaped version of the juglets classified as Black Slipped Grooved Ware found in more recent excavations at Amathus in burials dating to the CA II period (Karageorghis 1982, nos 4 and 5,  T. 199/53 and T.250/46; fig. 1). An example of the smaller variety was found in Amathus BM Tomb 240 (GR 1894,11-1.567). Most examples of this rare ware with firm archaeological contexts date to the CA period but some forms occur earlier.  
The tomb number of the present example is not given in the Register. At least three tombs contained jugs that seem to correspond to this type. The example in Tomb 140, to judge by the sketch in the notebook, is closer in shape and size (apparently around 6 to 9 cm) to GR 1894,1-1.567 from Tomb 240. Another was found in Tomb 158 (also with a squat body so closer to GR 1894,11-1.567 but with a neck-ridge similar to the present example); however, since at least part of the Tomb 158 group was allocated to the Cyprus Museum, the jug itself is unlikely to be the present example. Finally, the jug sketched in the notebook entry for Tomb 252 is also closer to the squat examples than to the present item, though it should be noted that Myres' sketches were not always very accurate in terms of the shapes of the items he drew.       
Bibliography:
Karageorghis V. 1982, 'Black Slip Grooved Ware from Cyprus', RDAC, 119-122.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery jug with a perforated base, probably a rhyon or wine-lifter; ovoid-spherical body on a small carinated foot (concave underneath); tall neck tapering inwards; rounded handle arching from shoulder to neck (below mouth); the top part of the neck is slightly inset, and flares outwards; base perforated with 15 small irregularly placed holes made with a sharp implement from the inner surface; made of buff clay with cream-buff slip; decorated with black paint: band of hatched triangles around the body beneath handle, band at junction of body and neck, ladder pattern on handle, solud paint on inset part of neck.
Curators Comments: Probably found in a tomb.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 2003 / A dany dipper: the Ambleteuse clepsydra, Empedocles, and wine-thieves I have known

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware jug; wheel-made; globular body; long slim neck; arched two-ribbed handle; trefoil mouth; deep red polished slip; decoration of intersecting bands and concentric circles.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 2 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 2, British Museum 2
Acq name (acq): Division of Finds: Claude Delaval Cobham

Description: Pottery juglet in Tell el-Yahudiyeh ware; biconical body with button base; remains of a narrow neck and handle which originally probably went from rim to shoulder; made of buff-greyish clay with a back slipped and burnished finish; decoration with a horizontal incised pattern of zigzags filled with lime.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Kaplan 1980 / The Origin and Distribution of Tell el Yahudiyeh Ware.

Description: Pottery jug in Base Ring I ware; handmade; globular body with a ring base, with a tapering neck and a slightly everted rim and a pinched mouth; strap handle from neck to shoulder with two ecircling relief ridges where the handle joins the neck; orange clay with lustrous, mottled red-brown slip; spiral relief decoration.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Base Ring I (SCE type VID 2b)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.

Description: Pottery miniature jug in White Painted ware; wheel-made; squat globular body on a narrow, flat base; wide, slightly concave neck with a trefoil lip; handle from shoulder to rim; pale buff clay and slip, decorated in brown and purple paint in Free Field style: bars on the handle and three pairs of intersecting lines on the body.
Curators Comments: Comparanda: E. Gjerstad, SCE IV/2, figs. XXVIII, nos. 28-29 (classed under WP ware); V. Karageorghis & J. Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; handmade; globular body with round base and thin neck with funnel rim; round handle from rim to shoulder; orange-buff clay with dark red polished slip, worn in places; deeply incised decoration of lines and zig zags with traces of lime fill; chipped rim and damage to body.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B3 c1 variety a);  type series: Red Polished III

Description: Pottery jug in Red Polished III ware; handmade; with ovoid body and rounded base and a cylindrical neck with everted rim; thick ring-handle from mid-neck to shoulder; red clay with  red slip, worn on body; incised  wavy line decoration on neck.
Culture: Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B2 r1)

Description: Pottery strainer jug in Base Ring II ware; hand-made; globular body in  tankard-form on a ring base with a wide neck; everted rim and solid top with five strainer holes; tubular spout and strap handle from rim to shoulder; orange-buff clay with mottled orange-brown lustrous slip, white painted lattice decoration.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot IIIA
Type series: type series: Base Ring II (Type XI a)

Description: Pottery woman-and-pitcher jug in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a pedestal base with flaring foot; tall cylindrical neck with a flaring rim; double-rib handle from shoulder to below rim. Made of find buff clay coverd with a lustrous slip and decorated with black and white paint: frieze of alternating black and white triangles beneath the rim, floral decorations in white on the neck, concentric circles on the shoulder, with bands below on the body. There are two figural scenes on the shoulder on both sides of the vase in pseudo-black figure style with incisions on a black outline: one shows a combat between a bull and a lion, the other shows two opposed sphinxes, either fighting or playing. The upper part of the terracotta figurine of a woman is mould-made, the rest is hand-made and crudely attached to the body of the jug; she is dressed in a tunic (chiton) and cloak (himation) as well as being enveloped with a red veil-like garment; her right arm extends to hold a globular pitcher decorated with black bands. The vessel is complete but repaired from fragments.
Curators Comments: Originally assigned to Bichrome Red II (V) by Gjerstad (SCE IV/2, p. 74), revised to BiCh III (VI) by Vandenabeele (1998, p. 158).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery spouted jug in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made with applied details; ovoid body on a hollow pedestal base; long tubular spout rising at an angle from mid- body, pair of breasts above; the neck is modelled in the form of a female head, with applied details such as pellet eyes and curls and pairs of plaited tresses hanging down each side of the face; she wears a double choker around her neck, also formed of applied discs of clay; single arching handle from the shoulder to the rop of the female head. Made of buff clay decorated with black and red paint.
Curators Comments:
Attributed to Black-on-Red II (IV) by Gjerstad in SCE IV/2. For a survey of this genre of anthropomorphic vase, which may represent a deity, see Nys 1997. The anthropomorphic element may be related to figurines of mainly females but also male figurines on wall plaques, some of which were holders for lamps or incense burners (see J. and V. Karageorghis 2006, who also discuss the identity of the figurines which may be deities).
Bibliography: 
Karageorghis, J. and V. 2006, A propos des appliques murales de Chypre', RDAC 2006, 173-7.
Nys, K. 1997, 'Vases with anthropomorphic protomes in the Cypro-Geometric and Cypro-Archaic periods (1060-475 B.C.), in: V. Karageorghis, R. Laffineur and F. Vandenabelle (eds), Four thousand years of images on Cypriote pottery. Proceedings of the Third International Conference of Cypriote Studies, Nicosia 3-4 May, 1996 (Brussels-Liège-Nicosia), 81-7.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; short tubular (slight concave) neck neck with a trefoil mouth; double-ribbed handle from shoulder to rim. Made of fine buff clay - fired to a red colour - over which is black painted decoration: pattern of intersecting bands and concentrics; base split and surface discoloured by fire.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery juglet or flask in White Painted II ware; globular body with a rounded base; narrow neck flaring to a trumpet mouth; arching handle from shoulder to base of neck; buff-cream clay and slip, decorated in matt brown paint: on each side and on the base is a large spiral terminating in a bull's eye and enclosed by broad band, concentric bands on the neck, ladder pattern on the handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery jug with double-spout in Red Polished ware; hand-made. Ovoid gourd-like body on a rounded base; two tall cylindrical necks with cutaway mouths; single handle with an oval profile branching into two bridges to the bottom of the cutaway mouths. Made of pink-buff fabric and covered with a lustrous burnished red slip; incised with lime-filled incised geometric motifs: bands of horizontal lines on the lower body, spouts and hand; panels of vertical zig-zags and hatched triangles. Some restoration (at joins) and the surface is worn in places.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (Class I Group A3 Type b)
Curators Comments:
The source of the information on the findspot is not immediately clear from the GR register, though the vase appears to be lot no. 39 of Cesnola's sale at Sotheby's on  9-10 January where, along with various items of prehistoric metalwork (possibly among lots 1-9 passim), are said to come from Alambra. The vessel also appears to be the one illustrated in pl. VII of Cesnola's Ancient Cyprus (1877, bottom row, left). Cesnola excavated in the cemeteries around the modern village of Alambra beginning in the later 1860s (Cesnola 1877, 87ff) and this was the stated source of many of his earlier Bronze Age finds, such as those in the Metropolitan Museum. 
This was the type specimen cited by Stewart for this group which is also represenetd by an example from Vounous (Stewart and Stewart 1950, Tomb 36a, no. 33). 
Bibliography:
Cesnola, L. P. di 1877: Cyprus. Its ancient cities, tombs and temples (London: John Murray).
Stewart, E. and Stewart, J. 1950, Vounous 1937-38. Field-report of the excavations sponsored by the British School of Archaeology at Athens (Lund: C.W.K. Gleerup).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age
Exhibition history: 2021-2022 29 Jun-9 Jan, Turin, Musei Reali, Cyprus:  Crossroads of Civilization
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks
Acq notes (acq): Donated by Augustus Franks to the BM in 1871. It was excavated in Cyprus by Luigi Palma di Cesnola in the later 1860s and presuambly sold at auction at the Cesnola sale at Sotheby's on 9-10 January 1871 as it seems to correspond with lot no. 39. This was purchased by 'Wareham' for £1 6s, possibly William Wareham of 14 Charing Cross Road and Castle Street near Leicester Square. Either Wareham was Franks' agent or the latter subsequently bought the vessel from him and later presented it to the GR department.

Description: Pottery juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; tall baggy body on a ring base; narrow neck with a low neck and pinched spout; single handle; made of fine buff clay with a red-orange slip and decorated with black paint: bands and concentric circles.

Description: Large pottery jug in Bichrome Wheelmade ware of Late Bronze Age date; globular body on a flat base; narrow, slightly concave cylindrical neck and rounded, everted rim with a ; single vertical handle with round section from shoulder to just below rim; buff-orange clay and slip, decorated in black-brown and red paint: on the body, intersecting parallel lines between vertical bands in black and red, wavy lines between similar black and red parallel bands; on the neck, parallel bands in red and black; on the handle, intersecting diagonal lines between verticals; reconstructed from fragments with some plaster restoration.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: C. Epstein, Palestinian Bichrome Ware, Leiden: Brill (1966); P. Åström ed., The chronology of Base-Ring ware and Bichrome Wheel-made ware, Stockholm: Royal Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities (2001).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Bichrome Wheel-Made pottery tankard-style jug with depressed globular body, cylindrical neck, everted horizontal rim and ring base; oval handle from rim to shoulder; painted decoration is in brown, red and white; the motifs include zigzags and rings under the rim, a panel of birds on the neck and running spirals and parallel rings on the shoulder. The rim and handle are also painted.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery jug with a bird motif in Bichrome ware; squat globular body on a narrow, flat base; wide, slightly concave neck and trefoil mouth; arching handle from shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated in black-brown and red paint in Free Field style: two fantastic stylised bird in flight drawn in silhouette (one partially eroded) facing in the direction of an eight-petal rosette; a pair of eyes on the mouth; zig-zag along the handle.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: J. Benson, The Amathus workshop, RDAC 1982, p. 141 ('V & A painter' no. 3); Additional bibliography: R.S. Morris & D.J. Symons, Four figured style vases from Cyprus, RDAC 1985, p. 187 no. 1.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)

Description: Pottery jug; wheel-made; decorated with painted bands, on shoulder with three birds pecking the ground.
Dimensions: Diameter: 131 millimetres; Height: 168 millimetres; Weight: 367 grammes; Width: 133 millimetres; Depth: 131 millimetres

Description: Pottery jug; wheel-made; painted; decorated on shoulder with facing bull protomes with a bird between; 'eye' motif on either side of pinched mouth below rim.
Dimensions: Diameter: 85 millimetres; Height: 135 millimetres; Weight: 207 grammes; Width: 85 millimetres; Depth: 84 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean piriform jug of Furumark type FS 144 and LHIIIA2 date, with beaked mouth and narrow neck with a  ridged handle from rim to shoulder; pink clay with buff slip and orange painted decoration featuring four large plant motifs, apparently a development of a lily pattern.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery red slip jug with vase protome spout; wheel-made; ovoid body carinated towards the shoulder; high splaying foot (hollow) with horizontal ridges; tall, wide cylindrical neck with flat, everted annular rim; vertical, double ribbed handle from shoulder to rim; small projections at each side of handle, one of which has an applied skeuomorphic clay rivet: slight depression on other side presumably represents missing comrade; irregular incised parallel lines on neck; protome vase spout on the shoulder: a simple trefoil spout and vertical strap handle; buff-orange clay with many small inclusions, originally covered with a red slip or paint, now almost completely disappeared; traces of white paint on body; black wreath noted in original catalogue now not apparent; foot slightly chipped.
Curators Comments: The shape and polychrome decoration begins in the Type VII group of the Cypro-Classical II period and continues down into Hellenistic I; chronologically they are not easily distinguished by style alone outside of a firmer archaeological context which is not available here. (See SCE IV/3, pp. 57-59 & 73).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery jug with protome vase spout and polychrome decoration; ovoid body on a splaying ring base or foot; slight upward taper on neck with flat, everted annular rim; vertical double rib handle from shoulder to just below the rim, overlapping sheath-like feature at junction of handle and neck with applied clay discs on each side, perhaps imitating metal rivets; protome spout in the form of a miniature jug with trefoil mouth, concave neck and and cylindrical upper: the slender curving handle continues into the spout below the rim where it raises into a slight lip with horizontal incision, described as a goose or duck head by the original excavators; coarsish orange or brick-red clay with many small inclusions, buff-pink slip (mostly eroded) and residual traces of white and black paint.
Curators Comments: Both the shape and the decoration have their origins in the Type VII wares of the Cypro-Classical II period but continue into the third century BC at least until the end of Hellenistic I (SCE IV/3, pp. 57-59, 73). A closely comparable example is known from the Cesnola collection (ibid. fig. 23,6 = Handbook of the Cesnola Collection 943); Listed by Vandenabeele 1998 (cat. no 313(Z), p. 217 & fig. CXXXII) in her section on unusual shapes, but she does not discuss the possibly zoomorphic nature of the miniature jug handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Mycenaean pottery jug; wheel-made; globular-biconical body; high, narrow concave neck; short beak with deep, trough-shaped mouth; low foot; arched handle from shoulder to mouth; wheel-made; buff slip and lustrous dark red paint; solid paint on foot, base of neck, handle and mouth, short parallel strokes on shoulder; alternating fine and broad bands on the body.
Dimensions: Diameter: 60 millimetres; Height: 73 millimetres; Weight: 51 grammes; Width: 58 millimetres; Depth: 60 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Benson 1972 / Bamboula at Kourion. The necropolis and the finds. Excavated by J.F. Daniel

Description: Pottery juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheelmade; biconical body on a raised disc base, concave underneath; nrrow tubular neck with a disc mouth; single stra-like handle, oval section, from shoulder to rim. Made of buff clay covered in an irregularly-fired reddish slip, decorated with black-brown paint: wide and narrow bands on the body. Paint very worn in places, almost down to the clay on the shoulder, also numerous small cracks in the vessel.
Curators Comments: Tomb 179 is given in the original 1894 Register as the findspot of this vessel, but a later marginal note observes that there are no vases listed in Myres' inventory for this tomb. It suggests that Tomb 37 was the findspot, but the only entry in Smith's notebook that is comparable describes  'many jugs with one or two plain broad bands round the body'. Without further details, or a sketch, this is surely too vague to reattribute the present juglet to another tomb.

Description: Pottery Base Ring I small jug; hand-made; long cylindrical neck widening to slightly everted rim with flat edge; beaked mouth; vertical strap handle from upper neck to shoulder pierced through body; body squat ovoid with tall flaring ring base; double relief band at handle join on neck; body decorated with hatched relief band at neck join and hatched antithetic relief spirals joining opposite handle with incised chevrons; surface orange-brown lustrous; clay brown at outer face with thick grey core.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Curators Comments: Register notes that .920-26 marked Tomb 44 in error and .921  has '48' on it in pencil. A glass pomegranate is noted from the register and the contents are consistent with tomb 48 so all objects have been assigned 'tomb 48?'
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; hand-made; globular body with rounded base and short concave neck with spouted cutaway rim; handle from neck to shoulder; deeply incised with concentric circles, parallel strokes, dots and wavy-lines with no obvious trace of lime fill;  slipped and polished but surface very worn; intact.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I A3 type c var. b);  type series: Red Polished III
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1
Acq notes (acq): Probably the group of pottery from Dali mentioned in vendor's letter of 21st Feb 1868.

Description: Mycenaean pottery juglet; wheel-made; piriform body on a high concave stem with a splaying base, narrow neck and beaked mouth; buff slip and red to black lustrous paint; decorated with solid zones of paint on neck and foot and parallel lines of varying thickness on the body; series of short broad strokes on the shoulder.
Dimensions: Diameter: 72 millimetres; Height: 112 millimetres; Weight: 124 grammes; Width: 70 millimetres; Depth: 72 millimetres
Curators Comments: The shape is really a miniature version of FS 133 rather than FS134 which is squatter and on a wider base.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description:
Pottery jug in Handmade Bucchero ware; ovoid body on a ring base, cylindrical neck, slightly concave, with horizontal ridges at the junction with the body and roughly mid-way; everted rim with carination; oval-sectioned handle arching from rim to shoulder. 
Made of buff-orange clay with burnished slip, fired red to black over the body of the vase; applied vertical rubs around the body; numerous small pits all over surface.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery White Slip II ware jug; hand-made; ovoid body on a narrow, flat but slightly concave base; wide, concave neck with everted rim and trefoil spout; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; coarse, brown-orange clay to grey (irregularly fired) with a cream-white slip, decorated in matt reddish-brown paint: vertical rows of hatched ladders and lozenges on the body hanging from a hatched ladder running around the shoulder, on the neck, bands of horizontal parallel lines above which are groups of vertical parallel strokes at intervals; zig-zag motif on handle; interior of rim with groups of vertical parallel lines; handle repaired but slip is missing in one place showing fabric.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery jug in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid-piriform body on a flat base; wide conical neck with pinched rim; arching handle from shoulder to rim; made from buff clay with bright red slip, decorated in black paint: eyes on the mouth, ladder pattern on handle, three groups of three concentrics on each side of shoulder and five rings on body; fine horizontal lines around the body just below the handle line; rim chipped.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Neck and upper body of pottery Bichrome Red IV jug with spout in form of attached figurine of a woman holding a pitcher or oinochoe; remains of upper part of ovoid body (parts restored); very tall cylindrical neck splaying upwards towards an almost trumped-shaped rim; ridge at junction of body and neck; remains of double-ribbed handle just below rim with skeuomorphic clay rivets on each side; dark red clay and slip covered in a white wash and decorated with black and white paint (other colours noted in the original now not apparent): on neck, black triangles on a white background below rim, two rows of black on white rosettes below, then a zig-zag pattern in black fringed with white dots; on the shoulder are and petals and fainter traces of other motifs (fleur-de-lys and zig-zags) now very worn. Figurine: incomplete hand-made figurine with mould-made head and chest; she wears a long chiton and himation and a conical cap (incomplete); large band above the forehead; visible hair is detailed with incisions; elaborate double necklace of round beads (pearls) hanging between breasts; red fabric with traces of white, yellow, red (cross-hatching) and green paint on the body; arms damaged and feet missing; pitcher is almost cylindrical in shape, vertical strap handle curving into the rim and a trefoil spout (mostly missing): white zig zags on the body and a back band at the junction with the main vase.
Dimensions: Height: 14.50 millimetres figurine ; Height: 17.50 centimetres max
Curators Comments: Vase belongs to Type VII of Gjerstad's scheme and to Vandenabeele's Floral Style (Vandenabeele 1998, pp. 47, 50).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery: Wheel-made Mycenaean IIIA jug with cut-away neck of Furumark type FS 132, painted on a light ground with dark red undulating vertically diagonal lines
Dimensions: Diameter: 234 millimetres; Height: 320 millimetres; Weight: 1365 grammes; Width: 245 millimetres; Depth: 234 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.

Description: Large pottery jug in Bichrome Red ware, reconstructed from sherds with much restoration; wheel-made spherical body on a ring base; the narrow tapering neck and double handle are modern; buff clay with red slip decorated in black and white paint: wide band of concentric circles on each side, with central motif (possibly a bulls eye), now damaged and restored, surrounded by small groups of concentric circles; below the neck is a large flower head in white paint, possibly a styled lotus, sitting on three stalk-like lines forming a triangle, the whole motif is flanked on each side by three groups of concentric circles, with a much larger group beneath; the junction of the body and neck is marked by a black collar decorated with white dots; portions of the body of the vase are also restored, and one side of the vase is very blackened, possibly from firing, an effect the restorer has also reproduced.
Curators Comments: See E. Gjerstad, SCE IV/2, fig. LIII-V for comparable examples.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware jug; wheel-made; globular body; neck modelled in the form of a human face. Made of fine buff clay covered with a lustrous slip and decorated in lustrous black paint: three-stroke motif and groups of concentric circles beneath the neck, horizontal bands around the body. Surface pitted and chipped in places.
Curators Comments:
The provenance is not given in the Register but the object matches very closely a Black-on-Red vessel with an applied human face reported by Reinach to have been found in a tomb near the village of Goshi (1891, 175). Note that when he states that the vase is near identical to one illustrated by Perrot and Chipiez (1885, 691 fig. 497) he is referring to the shape and ware rather than the specific decorative scheme which is plainer in the present vase than the cited parallel.   
Bibliography:
Perrot, G. and Chipiez, C. 1885, Histoire de l'art dans l'Antiquité. Vol. III. Phénicie-Chypre (Paris: Hachette). 
Reinach, S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient (Paris (Firmin-Didot).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Small spouted pottery jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a turned base, concave underneath; narrow concave neck with a rounded, everted rim; single strap handle from shoulder to rim; short cylindrical spout on shoulder set at right-angle to handle, with three perforations in the body of the vase for drainage or straining the contents; green-buff clay with a variable slip from cream to orange, decorated in purple to brown paint: parallel bands on the body, base of neck, rim and inside the mouth; triangles filled with a checker-board pattern and swastikas in the open field; jagged line around the neck; a zig-zag on the handle; thick band around the junction of spout and body, with two curved bands down its length.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: White Painted V jug decorated with a human figure in relief on the shoulder; hand-made; slender ovoid body on a disc base, slightly concave on the underside; narrow concave neck with a beaked spout; arching handle from shoulder to just below the rim. A human figure, perhaps a bearded male, sits on the shoulder with the large right hand resting on the lap, the left held against the chin with an slight expression of anxiety; beaked nose; three horned projections extend from the body of the vase below; made of fine buff clay decorated with matt brown-red paint: parallel lines framing zig-zags and chevrons on the body, parallel lines on the neck and applied figurine.
Dimensions: Height: 5.50 centimetres figure ; Height: 21 centimetres vase
Curators Comments: The number '99' is written on a paper label stuck on the underside of the base, perhaps refererring to the original sale.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis Coroplastic I / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. I. Chalcolithic - Late Cypriot I
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola (sale); Purchased through: Rollin & Feuardent

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome ware; ovoid-biconical body on a low ring base; wide, slightly convex neck with a trefoil mouth; short strap handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip, decorated in black to purple and red paint: a fantastic bird with a large beak in Free Field style facing the right, drawn in outline with the centre filled with arcs and purple paint; a single large wing is filled with cross-bars; chevrons in the open field; a pair of eyes on the spout; bands on the neck, with a single wavy line; ladder pattern on the handle with two hooks descending from the base.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery woman-and-pitcher jug in Bichrome red ware; wheelmade body with moulded and hand-made applied figure; ovoid body on tall stemmed conical foot (hollow); ridge at junction of neck and body; tall cylindrical neck splaying outwards to an everted rim (mostly missing); vertical handle made of two joined strips of clay from shoulder to just below the neck with two small, flat knobs, aping metal rivers, at either side of the junction with the neck; applied snake-like moulding along the handle; female figure wears a chiton and himation; the right hand clutches the side of the chiton; she is richly adorned with jewellery and wears a conical cap on her carefully moulded head; narrow band of hair above forehead is rendered as a series vertically incised lines; feet more schematically rendered as simple bulges of clay extending from beneath the hem of her dress; in her right hand she holds a globular jug with trefoil spout; brownish-red clay and red slip decorated with parallel bands of black paint on body and foot; frieze of olive wreaths (?) below the applied figurine; slight traces of floral decoration at junction of neck and body; traces of white slip on the figure.
Type series: type series: Woman and Pitcher jug
Technique: painted; applied; slipped; mould-made (figurine); handmade (figurine); wheel-made (jug)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Large pottery jug with figural decoration in Bichrome Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a low ring base; narrow neck tapering upwards slightly towards the trefoil mouth; double ribbed handle from shoulder to lip; made in buff clay covered in a red slip, decorated with black and white paint: bands of vertical concentric lines around the sides of the body, framing on each side a central rosette or wheel motif surrounded by groups of small concentric circles; a horizontal band of concentric lines runs around the shoulder: a fish swimming to the right painted in outline occupies the frame created by the intersection of these bands on one side of the vase, the surface of the corresponding space on the other side is damaged, but a small fragments of the outline of a oval figure is probably the remains of another fish. Immediately below the neck on the front of the vase is a bull with long pointed horns, facing the right as is about to charge or butt an opponent; the beast is painted in black outline (quite faint on the lower body) with some internal detailing indicated with black lines over a white fill; the bull has a long tail which falls to the ground in a kind of loop; below the horizontal shoulder band is a large star-in-circle motif in black and white paint; vase assembled from fragments, with some restoration.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Levant (?);  Made in: Egypt (?)
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: R.S. Morris & D.J. Symons, Four figured style vases from Cyprus, RDAC 1985, p. 190 no. 1.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean jug of Furumark type FS 139, with trefoil mouth, cylidrical neck, wide rounded shoulders and oval sectioned handle from rim to shoulder; buff clay with brown slip; the decoration painted in brown, consist of broad encircling bands on the lower body and three bull protomes on the shoulder, two of which are locking horns; two circles like eyes sit in the depressions of the jug mouth; the jug is heavily restored with plaster; fiant red pot markes on base.
Dimensions: Diameter: 152 millimetres; Height: 265 millimetres; Weight: 1183 grammes; Width: 150 millimetres; Depth: 152 millimetres
Inscription: Inscription type: pottery mark Inscription position: base
Curators Comments: The tomb number is provided in the Register but Bailey (pp. 12-13) observes that  this is uncertain as the vase is not mentioned in the tomb lists. At the same time, it was Walters who entered the finds from HST in the Register and he   may have had a reason for attributing this item to Tomb IV.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome Red ware with a woman-and-pitcher jug spout; wheelmade; ovoid body on a raised cylindrical base with splaying foot; tall conical neck with an everted rim (partly missing); double-ribbed handle from shoulder to neck with discs of clay at the juncture with the neck, probably representing metal rivets; opposite the handle on the shoulder is a figurine of a woman holding, in her right hand, a large pitcher with a conical body and trefoil-mouth; the figure is handmade with moulded face and upper body: she is wearing a long robe and a cloak which extends over her head (possibly over a conical cap or elaborate coiffure); long tresses fall on each side of her chest; the vase is made of buff-pink clay with a dark red slip decorated with black and white paint: black and white parallel bands on the body and neck, black concentric circles with white dots on the shoulder, a register of pendant triangles below the rim; the figurine itself is painted in dark red or black with various details in black and white.
Curators Comments: Despite its highly distinctive form, this vessel is not mentioned in the tomb inventory nor in Excavations in Cyprus, but it was registered with this tomb number in 1894.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe

Description: Pottery bichrome red ware woman-and-pitcher jug; elongated oval body on a short, everted foot; concave vertical neck and everted rim; two-ribbed vertical strap brown clay and red slip decorated with black, purple and white paint: black and white bands of horizontal parallel lines of varying width on body; black bands on foot and handle; neck decorated with three birds in black silhouette and tree motifs on each side; part of neck missing and body of vase has been restored in places; Terracotta figure incomplete, missing its neck and head; handmade body covered in red slip; feet shown as two small pellets below hem of dress; right arm (missing) originally extended forward to handle of globular jug with trefoil mouth; surviving parts of left arm, with painted black and purple bands on lower part, supports right side of jug; right hand repaired and restored.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: Herrmann, Das Gräberfeld von Marion auf Zypern, 1888, p. 49, fig. 29; Ohnefalsch-Richter, 1893, p. 42, fig. 44 & p.366. pl. XXIII,1 a-c; Reyes, Archaic Cyprus, 1994, p.110, fig. 30b; Vandenabeele, 'The pictorial decoration on Cypriote jugs with figures holding an oinochoe' in Karageorghis, Laffineur & Vandenabeele eds, Four thousand years of images on Cypriote pottery, 1997, p. 134-135.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Vandenabeele 1998 / Figurines on Cypriote jugs holding an oinochoe; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware juglet; wheel-made; pear-shaped body with plain wide mouth; ladder-pattern on handle, concentrics on body.
Find spot: Excavated/Findspot: Salamis (historic - Cyprus) (?);  Excavated/Findspot: Kition (? tomb)
Curators Comments:
The finspot is only given in the vase catalogue where it is accompanied by a question mark. This may also have been found at Kition.  
For a modern survey of the ware, and a proposed revision of the chronology, see Schreiber 2003.
Bibliography:
		Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture and History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston: Brill).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Pottery Bichrome-Red ware jug with tubular spout; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; two-ribbed handle; columns of three concentric circles on body; bands dotted with white round base of neck and spout.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Base-Ring I ware pottery juglet; hand-made; depressed globular body on a ring base; tall narrow neck with a flaring mouth; flat handle from mid-neck to shoulder; horizontal ridges on neck at handle; made of fine buff clay with a red-brown burnished slip.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Pottery juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a slightly raised disc base (slightly concavity in centre of base); narrow cylindrical neck with a trefoil mouth, rim plain; single handle (oval section) from shoulder to rim, Made of fine orange-red clay with a similar slip, decorated with black paint: narrow lines around the body, junction of neck and body, neck and on rim; black lines on the handle, concentric circles on the shoulder. Surface worn.
Curators Comments: The number C1032 on a attached label refers to a planned supplement to Walters' catalogue of Cypriot vases in the BM of 1912 that was never completed.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery; White Slip II juglet with globular body flattened at base; flat handle;funnel; black painted lattice-bands and columns; white slip.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Description: Pottery juglet of unpainted White Slip I white fabric in Base Ring shape.
Curators Comments: Very rare fabric and shape. Dates to LCIA2-LCIB.

Description: Hand-made pottery juglet in White Painted IV; globular body; cylindrical neck; string hole handle; red painted wavy lines and lattice lozenges; buff slip.
Type series: type series: White Painted IV (SCE type IX A 1a)

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; handmade; depressed globular body with round base and cylindrical neck with funnel mouth; incised decoration of bands and chevrons; buff clay with polished red slip; rim damaged.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B3 c1 variety a);  type series: Red Polished III
Curators Comments: Walters' catalogue gives the provenance as 'Asia Minor or Cyprus' but the former is highly unlikely.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Small pottery juglet in White Painted ware; wheel-made; globular body with flattened sides, bosses on the sides; narrow neck with a flaring mouth, the slight ridge just above the junction of the handle gives a angular profile to the upper part of the neck; small arching handle from shoulder to neck; buff clay and drab slip, decorated in brown paint: large spirals surrounded by a circular band on the sides, rings around the neck, short parallel bars on the handle.
Curators Comments: According to the Register, this vase is from Tomb 186 but Walters' Catalogue of vases says Tomb 286. The latter is more likely as the tomb group was allocated to the CM and some items from the group were published in the Catalogue of the Cyprus Museum in 1899.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Hand-made pottery: Base Ring I juglet with spindle-shaped body and everted base; high narrow neck with horizontal mouth and an oval handle from upper neck to shoulder; dark brown to black slip, partly coloured red at firing.

Description: Pottery juglet or askos in the form of a bird (probably a duck) in Bichrome ware; wheel-made body in the shape of a bird ending in a prominent tail fan; short neck and small trefoil mouth; arched handle from top of vase to the mouth; buff clay and slip, decorated in red and black paint: stylised wings and tail feathers and a star motif on the breast.
Curators Comments: Probably found in a tomb.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Hand-made pottery juglet in Black Slip III; globular body with flattened base; narrow neck and funnel-shaped mouth; flat handle; black slip; incised chevrons.

Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware juglet; hand-made; long tapering neck with trumpet mouth; vertical strap handle from mid neck to shoulder, flanged at body join; two horizontal relief ridges at handle to neck join and around maximum diameter; globular body with high flaring ring base; thin brown slip burnished to a medium lustre; fabric reddish brown with grey core.

Description: Pottery Black Slip V juglet; handmade; thin matt black slip flaking in sections; fine light brown clay; thin cylindrical neck with funnel mouth; vertical handle with rectangular profile from lower neck to shoulder; globular body with flattened base; finely incised decoration on body: double horizontal bands at top of shoulder and near base framing sets of vertical panels, three with chevrons, one with cross-hatching and one multiple zig-zag.

Description: Pottery juglet of White Painted VI ware; body nearly globular; tubular spout on shoulder; flat looped handle; wide mouth without rim; black linear decoration on drab ground.

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished ware; globular body; short cylindrical neck tapering towards flared rim and tapering towards rim, and with a small string-hole handle at base of neck; buff clay with deep red unpolished slip partly discoloured by firing, now with surface scratches and marks; small chip on rim.

Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware juglet; hand-made; long tapering neck with trumpet mouth; vertical strap handle from mid neck to shoulder; relief ridge at handle to neck join, flanged with pronounced terminal in relief at body join; globular body with low ring base; decorated with vertical band of three relief ridges down body opposite handle and two on either side perpendicular to handle; thin dark brown slip burnished to a low lustre; fabric red with a grey core; surface worn.

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Slip/Black Slip ware; handmade; globular bodyeith globular body and a short cylindrical neck with everted rim;  single string-hole handle from base of neck to shoulder; relief decoration of parallel and wavy lines; buff clay with reddish-brown slip.

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted IV; handmade; globular body with rounded base and a short, narrow neck with slightly everted rim; two string-hole handles at the base of the neck; buff slip with red-brown painted decoration of encircling lines at the neck and hatched triangular motifs; groups of parallel lines crossing on the underside.

Description: Pottery juglet or perfume flask in Black-on-Red ware; globular body with a narrow neck and flaring trumpet mouth; arching handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; flat base; pink-buff clay with orange-red polished slip, decorated in black paint: parallel bands around the body and concentric circles on the shoulder; surface pock-marked in many places, part of the mouth is missing.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXVIII, 9. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery juglet in Black Slip II ware; handmade; globular body with round base and narrow neck with everted rim; string-hole handle from the base of neck to shoulder; small projection on shoulder opposite the handle; buff clay with traces of  brown slip; incised decoration of lines and zig-zags.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: Black Slip II (SCE type XI A 1a)
Curators Comments:
Similar to juglets in Stewart (1988, fig. 25.15 and 16)
Bibliography
Stewart, J.R., 1988. Corpus of Cypriot Artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part I, Stewart, E. and Åström, P., (eds), SIMA Vol. III:1, Göteborg.

Description: Pottery juglet in Black Slip ware; wheel-made; ovoid-piriform body on narrow splaying foot (now missing) decorated with slightly curved flutings applied with a tool; relatively tall cylindrical neck with a chamfered rim, small encircling neck-ridge at junction with body; thin strap handle arching from shoulder to neck; buff-orange clay covered with a matt black slip, worn in places.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. IX nos 11-12. Numerous examples were found in tombs excavated by the Department of Antiquities in the modern times, the best documented of which are those from the cemetery of Skales. 
Bibliography:
Karageorghis V. (1983), Palaepaphos-Skales. An Iron Age cemetery in Cyprus. Ausgrabungen in Alt-Paphos auf Cypern 3 (Konstanz: Universitatsverlag Konstanz).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description:

.
Type series: type series: Black-on-Red I;  type series: Black-on-Red II

Description: Pottery juglet in Black Slip II ware; handmade; swollen piriform body with rounded base and short cylindrical neck with everted rim, now broken away; handle slightly rising from the rim to the shoulder, with small projection above the rim; made in buff clay with traces of dark brown slip, incised decoration of circles on the shoulder and zigzags on the body.

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted ware; wheel-made; squat body with cylindrical, slightly concave neck and everted rim; vertical strap handle from body to just below rim; buff clay with many inclusions and creamy-white slip; decorated in brown paint with concentic bands around the body and base, the latter framing a maltese cross in light-on-dark technique; single broad band at juncture of body and neck; ladder motif on handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware juglet; hand-made; long narrow neck tapering to trumpet mouth; vertical strap handle from mid neck to shoulder with two relief ridges at neck join, flanged with pronounced terminal in relief at body join; biconical body and low ring base; decorated with incised and relief decoration, herringbone pattern on lower handle and relief spiral and incised relief ridges on upper body and maximum diameter; thin lustrous brown slip, worn in places; brown clay with grey core; damaged on lower body and base.
Dimensions: Diameter: 3.50 centimetres base ; Diameter: 3.40 centimetres rim ; Diameter: 5.50 centimetres; Height: 10 centimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery barrel juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; elongated body with rounded ends; narrow neck with a flaring trumpet mouth; neck ridge; pair of opposing handles arching from shoulder to below neck ridge; made of fine buff clay covered with a dark reddish-orange lustrous slip, decorated with black paint: bands of concentric lines with solid borders around the body, framing a dart motif under the handles, bands around the neck, ladder pattern on the handles; surface shows signs of burning or perhaps over-firing.
Curators Comments:
The precise findspot is not mentioned in the Register nor in the published  report. Its intact condition suggests it was found in a tomb rather than in the  Sanctuary itself. However, as the CEF explored cemeteries in numerous  locations around the village of Kouklia it is impossible to detemine even a general findspot location (Gardner et al. 1888, 264ff and pl. VII).  
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXV, 7 (= GR 1894,11-1.388; BM Vase C895). See Schreiber 2003 for a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
		Bibliography: 
		Gardner E. et al. 1888, 'Excavations in Cyprus, 1887-88. Paphos, Leontari,  Amargetti.', Journal of Hellenic Studies 9, 147-271.
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture and History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston: Brill).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery juglet or flask in Black Slip ware; hand-made; flattened ovoid body on a button base; narrow concave neck with a rounded rim; single handle with rounded section, extending from shoulder to below neck; five founded knobs down each side; made of buff clay covered with a thin slip, fired brown-black; decorated with incised zig-zags across the body flanked by vertical parallel lines; vertical stip of zig-zags and hatched triangles down the centre of each side; slip now worn in places.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Black Slip III (?);  type series: Black Slip V (?)
Curators Comments: Åström included this vessel in his BS V category which he describes as a LC development of BS III, though the difference in forms is often hard to determine without an archaeological context. Originally assigned to BS III in the annotated copy of Walters' catalogue in the GR department.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery barrel-shaped juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; barrel-shaped body with flattened ends; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a trumpet mouth; small arching handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and dull red slip, decorated with black paint: bands on the mouth and neck, ladder patter on the handle, concentric rings around the body, with large, crudely drawn spirals on each end enclosed by a broad band, complex dart motifs below the neck on each side.
Curators Comments:
SCE IV/2, fig. XXV, no. 7 for the type. See Schreiber 2003 for a modern survey of the ware, including suggested revisions to the chronology (but see also Iacovou 2004 for a critique of her conclusions).  
Bibliography:
Iacovou M. 2004, 'Phoenicia and Cyprus in the first millennium B.C.: Two distinct cultures in search of their distinct archaeologies' [Review of Schreiber 2003], BASOR 326, 61-66.
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iorn Age. Culture and history of the ancient Near East 13 (Brill).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery juglet of White Shaved Ware; short cylindrical neck with straight rim and trefoil mouth; high vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; elongated ovoid body with slightly misshapen pointed base; vertically trimmed down neck and body at leather-hard stage; greenish clay; handle pierced through body wall.

Description: Pottery juglet/feeder bottle in White Painted Stringhole ware; handmade; depressed globular body on a rounded bottom, tall narrow neck and beaked spout; single handle from shoulder to just above the base of the handle; large oval 'mouth' set into the bottom of the spout just above the handle; four pairs of string-holes, placed one above the other, at the eside of the bodies, with two more pairs at the base of the spout flanking the handle. Made of fine buff clay, fired to a buff-cream surface, with black painted decoration: vertical lines framing hatched lozenges on the body, horizontal stripes on the spout.
Curators Comments: Probably found in a tomb.

Description:
Pottery Base Ring I ware double juglet; hand-made; each juglet has a piriform body on a trumpet-shaped ring base (one damaged), and a tall narrow neck with an everted rim (both damaged); single shared strap handle from the rims to the shoulders.
Made of orange clay with white mica with a lustrous brown-grey slip; aligned suspension holes at the top and bottom of handle made before firing; relief circles on the necks; slip worn in numerous places.
