Description: Pottery Tell El-Yahudiyeh ware juglet; wheel-made; cylindrical neck flaring slightly to rolled rim; vertical handle from below rim to shoulder; piriform body; button base; two bands of horizontally combed decoration around body; traces of highly lustrous burnishing on the uncombed areas around the maximum diameter, neck and handle; surface colour mottled red and black, fabric dark grey;surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kaplan 1980 / The Origin and Distribution of Tell el Yahudiyeh Ware.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Small juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body with flat base; wide, slightly concave neck and everted rim; vertical loop handle from body to rim; pink-buff clay with thick, lustrous red slip and black painted decoration; band of four horizontal lines around the belly of the vase with single bands of varying widths on the neck and rim. Three groups of concentric circles regularly spaced around the shoulder; small chip off the rim.
Curators Comments:
SCE IV/2, fig. XXXVIII, 15. See Schreiber 2003 for a modern survey of this ware. 
Bibliography: 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture and history of the ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston, 2003).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid-biconical body on a disc base (edges chipped) with a narrow concave neck; everted rim; single handle from shoulder to neck rim. Made of fine buff clay covered with a lustrous red-orange slip and decorated with black paintL bands around the body and crude rings on the shoulder. Surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 2 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 2, British Museum 2
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Small pottery jug in Mycenaean fabric (Furumark type FS 114); wheelmade; globular body on a disc base; wide concave neck with a slightly everted rim; single strap handle form shoulder to rim; made of fine buff clay decorated with lustrous red paint: horizontal bands around the body and diagonal bars on the handle; parts of the neck and rim are missing in places; surface worn.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Description: Pottery juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; narrow cylindrical neck and plain mouth; neck-ridge; arching handle from low down body to neck ridge; buff clay and dark red slip, decorated with black paint: short parallel bars on handle and concentric circles on the body with a bull's-eye motif on each side.
Curators Comments: Found with scarabs of the Egyptian XXVI dynasty.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted III-IV Pendant Line Style ware; handmade; globular body with round base; narrow cylindrical neck with everted  rim and handle rim to shoulder; buff clay with pale slip and brown painted decoration;encircling bands on the neck, with the body painted with alternating groups of four parallel straight lines and a single wavy line.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted Pendent Line Style (SCE type  IA 2b)
Curators Comments:
Walters' catalogue text says that the present item was found in the same tomb as C273, though the latter was found at Enkomi. The following item in the catalogue sequence is from Yeri though the entry for C326 also says it was found with C561. It is possible that all three vessels were found together, though the chronological difference between two late MC items and one from the LCIIB or early LCIIC suggests that the tomb was used on a number of occasions. This is attested at several tombs in the cemeteries of Nicosia-Ayia Paraskevi (Kromholz 1982; Merrillees 2012) while a number of burial grounds in the centre of the island (but also Klavdhia-Tremithos) also continued in use across the MC to LC transition. 
Bibliography:
Kromholz, S.F. 1982, The Bronze Age necropolis at Ayia Paraskevi (Nicosia): Unpublished tombs in the Cyprus Museum. Sima Pocket-book 17 (Göteborg: P. Åström). 
 
Merrillees, R. 2012, The 'Ochsencrater-Grab' from Nicosia Ayia Paraskevi (Uppsala: Åström)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; Frankel MCWPP / Middle Cypriot White Painted Pottery. An analytical study of the decoration; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet of White Shaved Ware; short cylindrical neck with straight rim flattened on top and trefoil mouth; strap handle from rim to shoulder rising slightly above rim and neatly trimmed to a rectangular shape; handle pierced through body wall; elongated ovoid body with pointed base; pronounced vertical trimming from neck to base and around handle; white and pinkish mottled clay.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted III-V String-hole Style; handmade; globular body with rounded base and a horned handle from neck to shoulder; tubular spout with a lateral opening; six string-holes, three on the shoulder and three on the neck; pale buff slip with brownish black painted decoration of latticed diamonds and zigzags, wavy lines and chequered bands.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted String-hole Style (SCE type V C 4h)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893 / Kypros, the Bible and Homer Oriental civilization, art and religion in ancient times

Description: Handmade Drab Polished juglet; globular body with small nipple at base; vertical handle and narrow neck mostly missing; small boss opposite handle just below remains of neck; small conical perforation on neck between handle and boss; juglet decorated with incisions filled with white lime: on body, registers of vertical parallel lines, cross-hatching and circles filled with cross-hatching; on neck, registers of parallel lines; slip and lime-fill largely eroded; buff-pink homogeneous clay.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Dimensions: Diameter: 6.20 centimetres max. ; Height: 6.50 centimetres surviving
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted V ware; handmade; globular body with a long cylindrical neck, beaked mouth and arching handle from shoulder to lower neck; buff clay and slip, decorated in red paint: parallel lines along the neck, oblique parallel lines across the body, a band of parallel lines around the base from which hang a series of vertical lines to the underside of the vase.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: White Painted V (SCE type  V E 1a)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Slip ware; handmade; depressed globular body with rounded base and short tapering neck with funnel rim; handle from mid-neck to shoulder with two projections at the top; small projection at the neck opposite the handle; buff clay with red-orange slip worn in places; decorated with horizontal relief patterns of chains and parallel lines.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; handmade; piriform body with round base and long, narrow cylindrical neck with everted rim; handle from rim to shoulder; pierced vertical projection on the shoulder and a horizontal projection close to the base; buff clay with worn red-orange polished slip; incised decoration of groups of horizontal lines and zigzags; rim broken and handle repaired.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B3 c1 variety a);  type series: Red Polished III
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; globular body with rounded base and long cylindrical neck with everted rim; handle rising slightly from rim to shoulder opposite a small projection at the base of the neck; made of orange clay with red-brown polished slip, worn in places.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (I B2 type y2 variety b)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; hand-made; ovoid body with round base and narrow neck ending in a funnel-shaped mouth; an oval handle extends from rim to shoulder; made of finely levigated clay and burnished to a high lustre; it is decorated with finely executed white-filled incisions; patterns include panels of parallel horizontal lines and zigzags; there is some damage to the neck and handle.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II

Description: Pottery juglet or perfume flask in Black-on-Red ware; globular body with a narrow neck and flaring trumpet mouth; arching handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; flat base; pink-buff clay with orange-red polished slip, decorated in black paint: parallel bands around the body and concentric circles on the shoulder; surface worn in many places, rim chipped.

Description: Pottery juglet in Black Slip ware; wheel-made; ovoid-piriform body on a small splaying foot; the body is decorated with slightly curved flutings applied with a tool; relatively tall cylindrical neck with a chamfered rim, small  encircling neck-ridge at junction with body; thin strap handle arching from  shoulder to neck; buff-orange clay covered with a matt black slip, now very worn.
Curators Comments:
The number '16' pencilled on the body may refer to a tomb number, as stated in Walters' catalogue of vases, but no tomb inventory has survived and the archival sources for the excavations preserved in the BM Department of Greece and Rome suggest that none was ever made.  
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. IX nos 11-12. Numerous examples were found in tombs excavated by the Department of Antiquities in the modern times, the best documented of which are those from the cemetery of Skales (Karageorghis 1983). 
Bibliography:
Karageorghis V. (1983), Palaepaphos-Skales. An Iron Age cemetery in Cyprus. Ausgrabungen in Alt-Paphos auf Cypern 3 (Konstanz: Universitatsverlag Konstanz).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description:
Pottery Base Ring I ware spindle bottle; hand-made; long body tapering to low ring base; long cylindrical neck and horizontal rim; strap handle from mid-neck to shoulder; incised interlacing parallel lines on shoulder and neck; pot mark at the base of the handle in the form of a cross.
Made from orange clay with a slip fired unevenly around the body (orange-red to black); surface pitted and base chipped.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot II
Inscription: Inscription type: pottery mark Inscription position: base of handle
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery flask or juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a turned base, slightly concave underneath; narrow neck with central ridge flaring outwards to a trumpet mouth; arching handle from shoulder to neck-ridge; red clay (much mica) with polished surface instead of a slip, decorated in black paint: parallel bands on the body, single bands on the neck, and a single group of concentric circles on the shoulder.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: Pottery juglet in White Painted VI Soft Triglyph Style ware; handmade; piriform body with a flat base and a narrow cylindrical neck with a pinched mouth; thin flat handle from mid-neck to shoulder with and projection on shoulder (now lost); pale clay with a cream slip decorated in brown paint with chevrons and vertical parallel lines.

Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Hand-made pottery juglet in Base Ring I ware; depressed spherical body on a low ring base; tall narrow neck tapering inwards towards the flaring trumpet mouth; thin strap handle from mid-neck to shoulder; applied plastic decoration of two rings on the neck and two relief snakes on body; buff-orange clay (grey core) with a lustrous brown slip; part of the rim is missing, slip is worn away and scratched in places, while parts of the relief decoration is also missing.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Red Polished pottery juglet; hand-made; gourd-shaped body; long neck with flaring, funnel-like rim (partly missing); handle missing apart from short stump at the base; small lug or boss at base of neck opposite the handle; incised decoration on body and neck filled with white lime in organised pattern: vertical parallel lines with oblique fringe by handle and boss, parallel lines flanked by concentric semi-circles at right angles to handle, spaces between filled with zig-zag or chevron pattern, horizontal parallel lines and semi-circles on neck; homogeneous buff-pink clay; slip damaged between bosses and handle stump.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Curators Comments: For comparable examples see SCE IV/1A, figs. XC-XCI; J. Stewart, Corpus of Cypriote artefacts of the Early Bronze Age, part I (1988).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Pottery juglet or flask in Black Slip ware; hand-made; flattened ovoid body on a button base; narrow concave neck with a rounded rim; single handle with rounded section, extending from shoulder to below rim; four large hook-like projections down each side; made of buff clay with a thin slip, fired brown-black; decorated with bands of incised zig-zags arranged horizontally down the body, enclosed by vertical parallel lines; slip very worn in places.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Black Slip III (?);  type series: Black Slip V (?)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Form: Åström described BS V as a Late Cypriot development of BS III, though the difference is not always clear independently of an archaeological context as the the two fabrics are indistinguishable. (Note that this vessel was originally assigned to BS III in the annotated copy of Walters' catalogue held in the GR Department). Merrillees, who adds several examples and further details to Åström's corpus, traces the form to el-Lisht and Tell el-Yahudia ware bird- and fish-shaped vessels. As such, he argues that the Cypriot imitations could not be an earlier than LCIA and are likely to be dated to this period.     
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Merrillees R. 1975, 'Cypriote Black Slip flasks', Levant VII, 141-5.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery juglet in Bichrome Ware; wheel-made; globular body; narrow concave neck with ridge flaring to a mushroom-shaped lip; small handle arching from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and slip, decorated in black and purple paint: bull's-eye motif enclosed within a circular band on each side; vertical column of four groups of concentric circles below the neck, with a single group under the handle; horizontal bands around the neck.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9

Description: Pottery juglet or flask in Black Slip III; flattened oval body with convex sides and a flat base; narrow cylindrical neck with funnel-shaped rim, chipped on one side; string-hole handle at base of neck; made in greenish buff clay with traces of a black slip; decorated with incised patterns of groups of horizontal,  parallel zigzag and straight lines with traces of whitish paste filling.

Description: Pottery Red Polished III ware juglet with incised decoration; hand-made; depressed ovoid-globular body on a rounded base; tall narrow neck with a flaring mouth; single rounded handle shoulder to rim; made of buff clay covered with a highly burnished red slip, decorated with lime-filled incisions: rings of parallel lines on the neck, concentric circles with bands of parallel lines in between on the body and shoulder; lip chipped, some surface wear.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (Stewart Type I B3 c1 variety a)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery juglet (aryballos) in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a flat base, with a slight hollow at the centre of the base; narrow neck with a flaring mouth; neck-ridge; single vertical handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and polished orange slip, decorated with black paint: narrow bands on the body, neck and rim; single group of concentric circles below the neck; solid paint on handle.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXVIII, 9. Schreiber 2003 provides a modern assessment of the ware, including the chronology.
 
Schreiber N. 2003, The Cypro-Phoenician pottery of the Iron Age. Culture & History of the Ancient Near East 13 (Leiden; Boston).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District  Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery juglet in Red Polished III ware; hand-made; globular body with a rounded base supported by tripod feet and a short, narrow neck ending in a funnel-shaped mouth; an oval handle extends from the rim to the shoulder; made of pale clay with a brown slip burnished to a high lustre; decorated with white filled incisions; the decorative motifs consist of a horizontal panel of multiple zigzags, encircled with parallel lines; surface worn in places.
Type series: type series: Red Polished III (Stewart type I B3 h1)
Curators Comments: Stewart seems to have assumed that this vessel was Black Polished ware, despite being described as 'polished brown' in the CVA, because he cites it as a BP example of an otherwise unattested Red Polished shape in his classification sequence for this ware (Class I B3 h1 var. a).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery White  Slip I ware juglet; hand-made; globular body with slightly concave neck, everted funnel rim and flat base;oval handle from mid-neck to shoulder. Brown clay with thick creamy white slip, painted with purple-brown lattice-bands arranged vertically and circumferentially; also vertical panels of dotted lozenges; four goups of parallel line on the interior rim.
Curators Comments: SCE IV/1C, p. 470, Type 1 for further examples.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Mycenaean IIIA2b-IIIB pottery juglet, FS 144, with an ovoid body, a flat base and a pinched mouth; round handle is from rim to shoulder; painted with narrow horizontal concentric bands in red/black on a cream background.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Diameter: 55 millimetres; Height: 67 millimetres; Weight: 58 grammes; Width: 54 millimetres; Depth: 55 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery juglet in Proto Base Ring or early Base Ring I ware; hand-made; globular body on a ring base; tall narrow neck with a flaring trumpet mouth; single strap handle from shoulder to middle of the neck; ridge around neck at level of handle; decorated with two snakes in relief applied to the body; made of fine clay fired to a grey core, covered in a highly burnished slip with a metallic lustre; surface damaged in places.
Type series: type series: Base Ring I (early or Proto Base Ring)
Curators Comments:
The present item appears to be the vessel illustrated in Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893, 59 fig. 58, g, pl. CLXXI, g (a hetergeneous group of tomb finds dated '1885 & 1886'), and pl. CXXII, 5. Apart from saying that it came from Nicosia-Ayia Paraskevi, he does not detail the circumstances under which it was found or its location. Either he excavated or collected it for Warren or else studied it when it was in the latter's collection. The former suggestion is more likely, in which case it can be suggested that all of the material in sequence GR 1888,9-27 was excavated by OR for Warren.        
For the type and parallels, see SCE IV/1C, 127-8 (PBR Type 1 C 1 a) and p. 149 (BR I Type V I D 1 b). The snake heads may symbolise rejuvenation or rebirth, which would be appropriate if the juglet contained an opium-based product used as a medicine or simply a perfumed oil to revive the senses. This has been suggested on account of the shape of the vessel - it resembles a poppy head when inverted - but this has not yet been confirmed by scientific analysis of the few vessels of this type which retain their contents.
Bibliography:
Ohnefalsch-Richter, M. 1893, Kypros, the Bible and Homer (London: Asher).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren
Acq notes (exc): Probably deriving from Warren's excavations in the cemetery at Nicosia-Ayia Paraskevi in 1885, thoguh these were probably carried out by Max Ohnefalsch-Richter.

Description: Pottery Red Polished III ware juglet; hand-made; globular body with a rounded base; tall narrow neck with a flaring mouth (plain rim); single handle from shoulder to rim; made of buff clay covered with a burnished red slip, decorated with incised motifs: bands zig-zags, loops and cabling; surface worn.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I; Middle Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Red Polished III (Stewart Type I B3 c1 variety a)
Curators Comments: Stewart noted that the decoration of this vessel resembles those from Geri-Phoenikiais (such as C54, C68, C77 and C78) which is unsurprising given the close proximity of the two sites.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery jar in Bichrome ware; wheel-made. Squat body on a flat base; short vertical neck; pair of opposing vertical handles. Made of buff clay decorated in Bichrome technique: purple-brown bands around the body; below the shoulder on both sides is a complex frieze of geometric/floral ornament (very worn on one side): large lozenges flanked by tree-like motifs, filled with chequers and smaller filled lozenges or other motifs; the handles are decorated with a frieze of vertical strokes; horizontal bands on the neck.
Curators Comments:
John Myres mentioned this vase in his discussion of geometrical decorations on Cypriot vases (1927, 76 and note 2), while Humphrey Payne mentioned the tree motifs on this vessel in the context of Geometric vases from Knossos (Payne 1927/28, 284 and note 3).
Bibliography:
Myres, J. L. 1927, 'Painted vases from Cyprus in the Pitt-Rivers Museum at Oxford, in S. Casson (ed.), Essays in Aegean presented to Sir Arthur Evans in honour of his 75th birthday (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 72-89.
Payne, H. 1927/28, 'Early Greek vases from Knossos'. Annual of the British School at Athens 29, 224-98.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery Bichrome-Red ware crater (wine-mixing bowl) or jar; wheel-made; ovoid-spherical body on a high splaying foot; low but wide cylindrical neck; everted horizontal rim; pair of opposing handles of composite form: double-rib vertical handles connected to the body by a triple-rib support. Made of buff clay with a dull red slip, decorated with red, black and white paint: bands, panels of lotus-flowers and concentric circles.
Curators Comments:
See Fourrier (2010, 328 no. 9 and figs 7a-b, refs) for a discussion of the shape which belongs to a Cypriot series derived from imported Greek craters (wine mixing bowls). Some have animal-headed handles, one of several major departures from the prototype made by the local potter.  
Bibliography:
Fourrier S. 2010, 'Un cratère à anses animales de Kition-Pamboula', RDAC 2010, 325-37.

Description:
Sherds from a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) Pictorial Style crater (The 'Window Crater'); wheel-made; piriform body on a low pedestal base; everted rim; pair of opposing strap handle; made of fine, light buff clay and slip, decorated with lustrous dark red paint: on both sides are fragments of chariot scenes flanked by window-like panels (composed of striped vertical and horizontal boxes) with images of women or decorative motifs. Further sherds found in 1937 allowed more of the vase to be restored (see comments).
On Side A, on the left are four panels with pairs of women above and below; their long dresses are decorated with horizontal stripes like the frames surrounding them; in three of the four cases, the upper part of the costume is plain; to the immediate right, fragments of the heads of riders in a chariot, part of the car, and the rear of the horses (including the lower legs); on the right are remains of four more panels whose corners are filled with fringed motifs. On Site B, the chariot scene is flanked on both sides by women occupying the full height of the frieze, also framed by 'windows'; a pair of women face each other on the right-hand side, a single one holding a flower on the left facing the chariot; all wear long skirts with narrow waists: the upper body is also plain where preserved; in the main scene, parts of the car and wheel survive, along with the lower body and front legs of the horses.
Curators Comments:
This vase was found in fragments in BM tombs 53 and 102 and presumed to have been broken when one of these chambers was previously excavated or looted. John Daniel found further pieces of the vase when he excavated at Bamboula in 1937 (Pennsylvania Tombs 17 and 17A, revealing that this was actually two burial chambers linked by the same dromos) (Benson 1972, 20-21 no. 26). These included more parts of the frame and fringed motifs in the 'windows' on the right side of Side A, the second full-height woman on the left side of Side B, and parts of the handle. The BM fragments were loaned to the Cyprus Museum in August 1969 (Trustees Minute, 12 October 1968) where they were brought together with those from Benson's excavations in a more complete reconstruction of the crater. 
Additional bibliography: V. Karageorghis 1975, 'The Mycenaean 'Window-Crater' in the British Museum', JHS 77,  269-71.

Description: Wheel-made pottery; Mycenaean  krater of Furumark type FS 8, with two flat vertical handles and narrow foot, decorated with encircling bands and scale pattern. Small part of the rim restored.
Curators Comments: This is probably one of the 'Mycenaean pieces with scale pattern' found in a tomb along with the crater GR 1899,12-29.132 which Welch excavated on the last day of the expedition. Malmgren assigned both items to Tomb A32 but the precise findspot of neither is given in the Register or the Catalogue.

Description: Two fragments of a Mycenaean pottery krater; wheel-made; buff slip and dark brown to red paint; pictorial motif of lower part of horse(s) and part of chariot-wheel in brown paint; tassel from pole brace; rock; dotted ring in field.

Description: Pottery amphoroid krater; two vertical strap handles from rim to shoulder; wheelmade; painted in matt brown; exterior with bands and wavy line on neck,  two ducks flanking a flower and flowers beneath handles on body; interior neck with solid brown paint; base missing and reconstructed.

Description: Pottery Pictorial Style amphoroid krater; wheel-made; two pre-firing holes pierced through handle on either side of rim; painted in reddish brown paint with an octopus on each side, body and legs overpainted with white dashes; plant motifs to either side of octopus, chevrons on rim; on the interior of the vessel there are two pot-marks painted in red paint; mended from sherds and a small area reconstructed.

Description: Pottery bell krater decorated in the Pictorial Style; wheel-made; painted in dark brown paint with griffins confronted across a stylised palm, one pulling a chariot in which stands a charioteer and his passenger; on the reverse are two confronted sphinxes.

Description: Pottery: wheel-made bell krater of Furumark type FS 281, with ring base and round loop handles attached vertically; buff clay with buff polished slip, decorated  with brownish-red lustrous paint; the rim is painted with an encircling band below and three encircling bands at the widest part and two further down the foot; the panel is painted, on both sides, in the Pastoral style with a bull sniffing leaves.
Curators Comments: Malmgren erroneously assigned this vase to Tomb 13. Neither the Register nor Walters' vase catalogue provides this information.

Description: Pottery: Wheel-made Mycenaean krater of Furumark type FS 6, restored from fragments, decorated with bands and spirals on stalks painted with brown paint on a white ground; on the handles are oblique bars.

Description: Pottery Pictorial Style amphoroid krater; wheel-made; pre-firing holes pierced through handle at rim and body joins and four holes in ring base; decorated in reddish brown paint on either side with a spotted horse-drawn chariot with three riders wearing spotted robes, man walking behind the chariot, horses over-painted with white dots; plant and geometric motifs in field, rim painted with chevrons and shell motif; mended from sherds and partially restored.

Description: Fragments from the lower part of a Mycenaean Pictorial Style amphoroid krater, probably Furumark shape 55; wheel-made; piriform body on a slender foot; ring on foot; made of fine buff clay with red-buff slip decorated with lustrous paint: chariot-scenes with curvilinear patterns in the field on both sides; handles and upper body lost.
Curators Comments: The vase is no longer assembled as an incomplete vessel.

Description: Mycenaean pottery amphoroid krater; wheel-made; vertical strap handles; everted rim with flattened top; decorated in reddish-brown paint: solid bands of paint on neck and foot; parallel lines on lower part of body; chevrons on rim; pictorial frieze at shoulder: a chariot, with two riders, on each side set amidst whorls, murex shells, rocks, lozenges and  stylized flowers; foot perforated with six holes; Late Helladic IIIA2.

Description: Pottery body fragment of a Mycenaean (Late Helladic IIIB) Pictorial Style krater (wine mixing bowl), Furumark type FS 55; wheel-made; made of finely levigated buff clay and covered with a similar coloured slip, decorated with semi-lustrous orange-brown paint: painted frieze of four wild goats facing right, with stylised trees or plants between them; the fragment is repaired from sherds; surface abraded in places.
Curators Comments: Vermeule and Karageorghis attribute this to early Pastoral Style, but the vase is definitely made in a Late Helladic fabric rather than being a locally-made vessel.

Description: Pottery krater; wheel-made; decorated with painted running spirals and bivalve shells. Rim decorated with painted interlinked 's' band. Prefiring holes through handle at rim and body joins.

Description: Mycenaean pottery bell krater of Furumark type FS 281 with ring base and round loop handles attached vertically, decorated with animal and human scenes; very fragmentary with whole of lower part and much of upper restored; buff clay and slip; decorated with red to black paint: bands above and below the pictorial scene, on rim and in interior, handles also painted; on one side is a scene of man on left restraining a dog (?) on a leash with each hand, to the left is a bull, painted in outline filled with spots, facing towards the right but with its head turned to the left; in addition are filled lozenges; on the other side of the vase is a very fragmentary trace of fore-part and hind-legs of a bull, possibly replicating the better preserved composition on the opposite side.

Description: Pottery Mycenaean amphoroid krater, Furumark type FS 54; wheel-made; greenish buff clay with buff slip decorated with brown paint; a frieze of two birds on each side; mended.

The krater GR 1899,12-29.130 may be one of the 'Mycenaean pieces with scale pattern' found with it. Malmgren assigned both items to Tomb A32 but the precise findspot of neither is given in the Register or the Catalogue.

Description: Pottery: seven non-joining fragments of a Mycenaean IIIA2-B amphoroid krater (probably FS 53-55), several reconstructed from smaller sherds; wheel-made; buff clay and slip, with lustrous painted decoration: octopus and bands.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Height: 14 centimetres max ; Width: 13 centimetres max
Inscription: Inscription type: monogram
Curators Comments: The Catalogue describes five sherds composed from thirteen fragments. Fourteen are listed in the acquisition register but this includes a handle with incised Cypro-Minoan sign actually from Hala Sultan Tekke according to Bailey (HST 1, p. 21) and now registered as 1898,12-1.309*. The GR register states that the sherds came from Tomb 2, but the Catalogue suggests that Tomb 16 was a possible source, based no doubt on the mention in the tomb list of Mycenaean pottery decorated with cuttlefish.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Fragment of a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) Pictorial Style krater of Furumark type FS 53-55; wheel-made; well levigated buff clay, slipped and decorated with lustrous brown paint: a naked man stands facing the right holding an object, possibly a fish, in his left hand; on both sides are irregularly-shaped striped columns, probably indicating a schematic rocky landscape; horizontal bands above and below the figure.
Dimensions: Height: 18 centimetres max ; Width: 12 centimetres max
Curators Comments: Belongs to Vermeule & Karageorghis' Early Pictorial Style of the earlier 14th century BC, to a transitional phase with Middle Pictorial (pp. 24-25).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Wheel-made pottery: Mycenaean bell krater of Furumark type FS 281 and LHIIIB date; ovoid body with wide, everted mouth and two horizontal loop handles; pink clay with buff slip and orange painted decoration; each side, in the central zone, features two deer looking backwards and by the handle a large fish with teeth; horizontal bands enclose the pictorial zone.
Curators Comments:
Bailey (27) sugegsted that this might be one of the missing 'stamni' mentioned in the lists for Tomb 8, but concluded that this is now impossible to confirm. 
Additional bibliography: Rystedt E., 'Bastard animals on a Mycenaean krater in London', RDAC 1988(1), 267-70.

Description: Pottery  wheel-made bell krater of Furumark shape FS 281 with vertical loop handles and a ring base; red clay with buff slip, decorated in brown lustrous paint with a horizontal band at the rim and three horizontal bands around the widest part; within the panel encompassed by these bands are pictures of a  stylised bull and bird; one side the bird is cleaning the horns of the bull with part of a stylised tree and the other side the bird is standing with head turned towards the bull; lozenges appear on both sides; partly reconstructed.
Dimensions: Diameter: 32.50 centimetres rim ; Diameter: 331 millimetres; Height: 305 millimetres; Weight: 6900 grammes; Width: 403 millimetres; Depth: 331 millimetres

Acq notes (exc): The items in the registration sequence 1898,10-20.1-15 were excavated by Gregoris Antoniou, the foreman of the Museum's excavations in Cyprus at this time, following the discovery of some Bronze Age tombs at the site of Klavdhia-Tremithos during ploughing early in 1898 (see correspondence in GR Archives, Letters on Antiquities 1890-1925). The items were sold to the Museum through William Ready (q.v.) because Antoniou, or Percy Christian (q.v.) who was probably the intermediary, was technically employed by the Museum at the time.

Title: The Tamassos Vase (Object)
Description:
Large pottery krater or wine mixing bowl of Bichrome IV ware with painted and moulded figural decoration; wheel-made; ovoid body; low, cylindrical neck and flat rim; low ring base; on each side, two vertical strap handles from body to rim; below these on each side are two strap handles in the form of bulls' (or moufflons') heads with arched horns; underneath are palm tree motifs framing a bird and a deer respectively; made of pinkish clay and buff slip with black and red painted decoration; figural decoration with animals, birds and humans on each side (Side B mostly eroded, though this can be reconstructed through 19th-century accounts) framed by bands of horizontal parallel lines of varying width; hatched zig-zags in a band just below the upper handles. 
Figural decoration: Side A: left side has two naked bearded male figures in a schematically rendered chariot with a long tassle pulled by an elongated horse; the left figure holds a vertical spear, the right has his right arms raised as if to throw a spear (?); large bird with red and black disc-like body and hatched wings and tail hovers over the horse; on the right a bearded huntsman wearing a cloak and a conical cap raises an axe over a fallen quadruped. 
Side B: poorly preserved; left hand part of register shows a man in a (conical?) cap brandishing an axe over a mostly missing figure; he is facing a naked man with outstretched arms, wearing an elaborate tassled helmet, a round shield and single spear; his right hand holds a black object which may be the conical cap of another figure (part of whose right leg is preserved); on the right of the register, a long horned quadruped (goat or deer?) is threatened with a bow and arrow by a man wearing a cap with vertical projections (feathers or tassles?); indistinct traces of figures below; vase repaired from fragments and restored, surface very worn in many places.
Curators Comments:
For an account of the discovery of the vase and the dispute of the excavator with Col. Falkland Warren over the vase, see Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893, 36-7 and 38 note *, figs 37-8. The latter stated that the crater was found, with its foot missing, in a 'deep earth-tomb', but provides no further details (1893, 38 note *). Reinach added that it was found in a very deep pit accessed by a 'galerie ou couloir' (presumably a dromos of some description) closed by a wall composed of small stones (Reinach 1891, 265). See Buchholz et al 2010, 217ff for a detailed account of the cemetery in which the vase was found, including other tombs discovered in 1885, together with a discussion of the vase (with full references) on pp 396-402 and pls 214-17.  
See Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893, 62-3 and figs 71, 75 on the iconography. Reinach also provides an important early account, including illustrations of the vessel before it was damaged during restoration (Reinach 1891, 294-300). The scene on Side B was originally interpreted as Perseus slaying the Gorgon (see Masson 1964, 297) but is more likely to represent a fighting scene complementing the chariot group on Side A (see discussion in Karageorghis and des Gagniers 1971; also Karageorghis 1966, 102-4 and fig. 1). Hermary sees the scene as heroic in nature, perhaps related to 'Homeric' epic (1991, 174-5 and passim for an important modern survey of the vessel).  
Bibliography: 
Buchholz H.-G. et al. 2010, Tamassos. Ein antiker Stadstaat im Bergbaugebiet von Zypern. Band I. Die Nekropolen I, II und III. AOAT 48/1 (Münster).
Hermary A. 1991, 'Un combat homérique sur un vase Chypriote Archaïque', MEFRA 103/1, 167-75.
 
Karageorghis V. 1966, 'A propos de quelques represéntations de chars sur des vases chypriotes de l'Âge du Fer', BCH 90/1, 101-118. 
Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1893, Kypros, the Bible and Homer (London). 
Reinach S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient. Documents sur les fouilles et découvertes dans l'Orient hellénique de 1883 à 1890 (Paris).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Masson 1964 / Kypriaka I. Recherches sur les antiquités de Tamassos
Subjects: hunting/shooting; classical mythology (?); charioteer/chariot; horse/ass; bird
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Colonel Falkland G.E Warren

Description: Pottery two handled bowl/drinking cup in White Painted ware; deep body with vertical sides, divided mid-way by a pronounced horizontal ridge; tall stem with pedestal base; pair of opposing handles sloping upwards. The surface is worn and chipped.

Description: Attic red-figured kylix or cup with figural decoration; wheel-made; pedestal foot; pair of opposing horizontal handles. Interior: A nude woman with frontal archaic eye stoops to the left, lifts (or deposits) with both hands a large footpan which rests on three feet in form of lion's paws; she wears a saccos decorated with longitudinal rows of dots, and an olive wreath,  inscription in Greek alphabetic script around the figure recording the name of the potter, Hermaios; the scene is bordered by a thin red circle; feet on the border; purple wreath and inscription; no inner markings seem to have been used: at least, none are visible, though the sketch marks are still clear.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Hermaios Painter;  Made by: Hermaios (potter)
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription quoted: ΗΕΡΜΑΙΟΣΕΠΟΙΕΣΕΝ Inscription transliteration: 'Έρμαως εποίησεν Inscription translation: Hermaios made me
Curators Comments: Klein, Meistersig2 p. 221. Found in the same tomb (necr. ii, no. 174) with the Cachrylion cup described by Klein, ibid. Companion piece to Hermitage Inv. 647 (Beazley, ARV, pp. 110, 1626; see E. Gjerstad, GGAPC, no. 554, p. 58 & pl. LXXIV,7).

Description: Pottery stand for a lamp, small bowl or incense burner in Bichrome ware; three splaying rectangular feet; neck ridge just below flaring neck with everted rounded rim; pink-buff fabric and slip; red and black bichrome banded decoration; rim incomplete, edges of legs are chipped and worn.
Curators Comments:
The modern excavations around Kouklia have produced numerous examples of small ceramic tripod stands for vessels. See Karageorghis 1983, 364 for an overview and passim for specific instances. Skales Tomb 44 contained no fewer than seven examples and Kouklia-Plakes tomb 143 produced three (Karageorghis and Raptou 2014, nos 9, 19 and 45). The Proto White Painted and early White Pained/Bichrome examples, richly decorated with geometric motifs, can be fairy precisely dated by this criterion alone, though the simpler banded decoration on stands found in the same deposits - and on the present example - are harder to place without a specific context. For example, three of the five stands in Skales Tomb 45, though somewhat squatter, have similar horizontal bands to the present example (nos 26, 31 and 59). They are assigned to Bichrome I by the excavator, but this is based partly on their association with SCE group I ceramic items. At the same time, an 11-cm high amphoriskos in White Painted III ware in Tomb 81 (no. 13) sits on a tripod support similar to the present example. 
Bibliography:
Karageorghis V. 1983, Palaepaphos-Skales. An Iron Age cemetery in Cyprus. Ausgrabungen in Alt-Paphos auf Cypern 3 (Constanz). 
Karageorghis V. and Raptou E. 2014, Necropoleis at Palaepaphos from the end of the Late Bronze Age to the Cypro-Archaic period (Nicosia).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Pottery two handled flask ('lekane') in White Painted ware; ovoid to piriform body on a low ring base; concave band at junction of body and foot; flat shoulder and narrow neck, now missing; two short vertical strap handles, almost lug-like, one now lost except for the stumps; very thick, heavy clay, buff coloured with a buff slip; decorated in deep red paint with registers of wide and narrow red bands of paint; body complete but repaired from fragments.
Curators Comments: Originally described as sub-Mycenaean and assigned to an earlier burial among a predominantly late 6th and 5th century context (Excavations in Cyprus, p. 84; Vase C698, pp. 132-133); the vase was found in the middle section of this triple-chambered tomb.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware lekythos; wheel-made; body widening to flat base; narrow neck with flat mouth and handle-ridge; small handle; banded decoration.
Curators Comments:

Description: Pottery oil flask or juglet (lekythos) in Bichrome-Red ware; globular body with a biconical neck (almost forming a neck ridge) and rounded rim; small handle from shoulder to neck; buff clay with red slip decorated with rings on the black on the body and a black-and-white zig-zag round neck; repaired from twelve fragments, with some pieces missing from the rim.
Curators Comments:
The findspot is not mentioned in the Register nor in the published report. Its intact condition suggests it was found in a tomb rather than in the Sanctuary itself. However, as the CEF explored cemeteries in numerous locations around the village of Kouklia it is impossibe to determine even a general findspot (Gardner et al. 1888, 264ff and plate VII).  
Bibliography: 
Gardner E. et al. 1888, 'Excavations in Cyprus, 1887-88. Paphos, Leontari, Amargetti.', Journal of Hellenic Studies 9, 147-271.

Description: Bichrome Red ware pottery flask or lekythos; wheel-made; baggy ovoid body; biconical neck with a pronounced rib; wide, flat mushroom-rim; vertical strap handle from shoulder to neck ridge; pink-buff clay with a deep slip and black painted decoration: series of three vertically arranged concentric circles on one side of the body and four on the other, line of white dots on a black background below the handle (white paint mostly eroded), parallel black and white lines on the neck, white band on flat rim enclosing two concentric registers of black dots, short parallel strokes on the handle.
Curators Comments: See also Birmingham, AJA 67 (1963), p. 25. Fig. 129 on p. 76 of 'Excavations in Cyprus' does not illustrate this vase but another of similar type which was not accessioned (or at least not attributed to this tomb group).The entry for Tomb 16 on p. 84 does not specify the type of vases found here but simply says they were similar to those in the preceeding tomb (Black-on-Red lekythoi and jugs). The original notebook however (Walters, Notes at Kourion, in the G&R Department archives) mentions only one lekythos.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery lekythos or juglet in Black-on-red ware; wheelmade; elongated conical body with rounded base, bulging biconical neck and trefoil mouth (possibly originally decorated with eyes); handle (now missing) from neck to rim; buff clay and red slip, decorated with black paint: bands around the neck and mouth, fine parallel lines around the body.

For similar examples, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXIX, nos 20a-b. See Schreiber for a modern survey of the ware (with full refs), including reassessment of the chronology, but note Iacovou's criticisms in her review (2004).

Description: Pottery barrel-shaped lekythos or juglet in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; barrel-shaped body with flattened ends; narrow neck with handle ridge, flaring outwards to a trumpet mouth; single small arching handle from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and polished red slip, decorated with black paint: parallel bands around the body, bull's-eye motifs in the form of a spiral on each end, bands around the neck and mouth; complex dart motif on the shoulder.

Description: Small pottery lekythos or juglet in White Painted ware; globular body with flattened sides and rounded base; narrow neck flaring outwards towards the mouth to give a concave profile; buff clay and slip, decorated with brown paint: painted rings on rim, band at base of neck, short parallel bars on handle and four maltese-cross motifs enclosed in concentric circles on the body.
Type series: type series: White Painted I (?);  type series: White Painted II (?)
Curators Comments:
The tomb number for this object is not included in the Register nor in Walters' catalogue of Cypriot pottery. A note in the margin of the register however notes the similarity of this item with a sketch in Myres tomb notebook entry for Tomb 187. However a similar type of juglet is attributed to this tomb group in the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, no. 1096) which therefore seems to be the correct findspot. Tomb 187 is also mentioned in the CM catalogue (no. 1092) in relation to a strainer-spout from a jug found here (also listed in Myres' tomb notebook). Confusingly, the entry implies that the spout is in the BM (but unfortunately gives a reference to a version of the Cypriot vase catalogue superceded by Walters' 1903 catalogue for which there is no known concordance). There is no trace of such a spout in the BM collection to confirm that the tomb group was in fact split between the two institutions.  
Bibliography:
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Small pottery barrel-shaped or juglet in Bichrome III ware; wheel-made; barrel-shaped body with pointed bosses (or 'nipples') on each of the flattened ends; narrow neck flaring upwards to a trumpt mouth; thin handle arching from shoulder to neck; buff clay and reddish-buff slip, decorated in  black and purple paint: concentric bands around the body and neck, the bosses are painted in with a bull's-eye motif.
Curators Comments: This rich tomb contained a great number of pottery vessels and numerous scarabs dating from the Egyptian XXVIth Dynasty.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description:
Pottery: White-ground lekythos (oil or perfume flask).
Arming of warrior. On left is a woman in a saccos and a long chiton, of which she raises the hem with her left, holding in her right a helmet towards a bearded man who stands en face, but looking at her, and holding out his right to receive it; in his left he holds a spear upright. Between them is a goose to right, pecking the ground. In the field on left hangs a small jug.
Fine style. Drawing in brown outline; hair, black strokes on brown wash; saccos and helmet (and perhaps drapery) have been red. Eye, profile. Above, a band of maeander broken by dotted cross squares; on shoulder, pattern of three palmettes; all brown on white. The helmet has the supporting ridge for a crest, but no crest is now visible; it may have been painted in a colour since faded.
Curators Comments:
For a discussion of the scene and the depiction of women in Greek figural art more generally, see Lewis 2002, 161 (and fig. 4.23).
The tomb also contained a woman-and-pitcher jug, a gold signet ring with a oval stone set in a swivel, two pendants gold wire enclosing a blue and white bead, a fragment of a silver funnerl or mouth for an alabastron, and a piece of an iron ring.
Bibliography:
Lewis, S. 2002, The Athenian woman. An iconographic sourcebook (London; New York: Routledge)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro 1891 / Excavations in Cyprus. Third season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou

Description: Pottery: black-figured lekythos (oil-flask). Design black on a red ground, with purple and white accessories; rather worn. On the shoulder, lotus-buds inverted. Departure of warriors (?): In the centre is Eris (or Nike?) to right in the archaic running attitude, looking to left, in long chiton with border of spirals and striped himation tied at the waist; she has two pairs of wings, the upper ones recurved, the lower hanging down, unless the sleeves of her chiton are thereby meant. On the left are two beardless male figures to right, with spears; the first is nude, the other has a striped himation. On the right is a beardless male figure seated to right on an okladias, in long chiton and striped himation, holding a spear; facing him is a nude youth, holding a spear in right hand.
Dimensions: Diameter: 120 millimetres; Height: 255 millimetres; Weight: 600 grammes; Width: 120 millimetres; Depth: 118 millimetres
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases

Description: Circular ivory box lid; thin, flat disc with incised concentric circles around edges and central, conical boss on one side; central hole on top, but not pierced through; decorated side is polished; details turned on a lathe; surface partially damaged with chipped piece at edge.
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.  
The lack of information on the archaeological context makes precise dating uncertain. Cylindrical boxes made of bone or ivory and bone were common on Cyprus from the Late Bronze Age down to Hellenistic and Roman times, with little change in the simpler examples (see SCE IV/1D, fig. 74, 24-5; SCE IV/2, fig. 41, 20; SCE IV/3). Parallels from excavated contexts at Amathus (Chavane 1990, 73 and pl. XVII), Salamis (Chavane 1975, 176-8 and pls. 48-9 and 70-1) and elsewhere suggest a Hellenistic or Roman date for this type.  
Bibliography:
Chavane M.-J. 1975, Salamine de Chypre. VI. Les petits objets (Paris: de Boccard).

Description:
Fragment of a Attic Little Master lip cup by Sakonides. Designs red on black ground, with purple accessories. 
Exterior: A female bust, to left, the face outlined in black, with hair looped up under a fillet. Below, inscription.
Producer name: Attributed to: Sakonides;  Made by: Hermogenes (?);  Made by: Glaukytes (?)
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Greek Inscription script: Greek Inscription quoted: Στ[ροΐβος καλός]. Inscription translation: Stroibos is handsome
Curators Comments:
For a description of the findspot and associated finds, see Munro and Tubbs 1891; also Wilson 1980, 62 and fig. 11. See Eriksson 2011, 98-99 for a modern survey of imported Attic BF and RF pottery in Salamis (the present piece is mentioned on p. 142 no. 6).
Bibliography: 
Eriksson, E. 2011, Athenian pottery and Cypriote preferences. An investigation of the Attic Black Figure and Red Figure pottery found in Cyprus. GOTARC Series B NO. 57 (Gothenburg: University of Gothenburg, Dept of Historical Studies).     
Wilson V. 1980, 'The Tubbs-Munro excavations at Salamis 1890', in: M. Yon (ed.), Salamine de Chypre. Histoire et archéologie (Paris: CNRF), 59-70.; BM Cat. Vases
J.H.S. xii. p. 143.
See comment to BM Vase B401 for the production of this vase.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro and Tubbs 1891 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1890. Third season's work. Salamis; Wilson 1980 / The Tubbs-Munro excavations at Salamis 1890

Description: Tondo sherd of Attic black-figured pottery Little Master cup or Gordion cup; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of naked youth (head and lower legs missing; holding a wreath in left hand and possibly a spear in right hand) to left; on the left, right hand of second figure reaching for youth's genitalia; above part of further object, perhaps held in the left hand; outside of stem glazed; inside reserved.
Dimensions: Diameter: 3.20 centimetres stem ; Height: 2.30 centimetres; Thickness: 0.50 centimetres
Curators Comments:
The provenance for this sherd is not very clear. The British Museum registry provides no provenance except to mention that the sherd came from the museum's Carthaginian basement. However, it was published by Beazley and Payne, as well as by Roberson, as having come from Naukratis. Beazley, in his ABV, listed the provenance simply as Egypt. See also Beazley 1989 [1948], p. 7, no. a11.   
Bibliography:
Beazley, J. 1989 [1948] (ed. D. Kuttz), Some Attic vases in the Cyprus Museum. Oxford University Committee for Archaeology Monograph 27 (Oxford: Oxford University Press). Originally published in the Proceedings of the British Academy 33 (1948).; Not included by Beazley in his list of courting scenes in 'Some Vases in the Cyprus Museum'.
Bib references: ABV / Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters; Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis; Robertson 1951 / Gordion cups from Naukratis; Heesen 2011 / Athenian Little-Master Cups (incorrectly labelled as 1909.2-16.2); Villing et al. 2013-2025 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt

Description: Iron lock in three fragments; traces of wood.
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, 9) as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.
Bibliography:
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Large pottery basin in Red Polished ware; deep conical body with a flat base; two handles, one pierced vertically with two large holes; four grooved projections on rim; dark red clay with a burnished slip; Red Polished III.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (XI D type j)
Curators Comments:
This vessel is called a 'milk-bowl' in the BM catalogue, but Stewart puts this vessel into his Class XI (basins) rather than his group of milk-bowls (Class X) because of the lack of a spout which defines this somewhat arbitrary term (Stewart 1999, 54 and pl. X, 2: Class XI, Group D, type j, variety a).
Bibliography:  
Stewart J. R. 1999 (ed. E. Stewart), Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part III:1 (Jonsered: P. Åström).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Painted wheel-made terracotta model of a bossed shield with a handgrip at the back in the form of a loop handle; boss and handle added separately; red clay and slip decorated in Bichrome technique with black and red painted decoration; central boss or spike is surrounded by three concentric registers of triangles in alternating colours of black and red ('vandyke' pattern); the triangles in the wider, outer band face inwards; the concave interior decorated in black paint with parallel lines flanking the loop handle and a stylized tree at each end of the handle on the same alignment.
Dimensions: Diameter: 22 centimetres; Width: 6.50 centimetres span of handle
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Karageorghis Coroplastic VI / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. VI. Monsters, animals and miscellanea; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Fragmentary terracotta model shield painted with geometric motifs; raised central boss surrounded by groove and a broader flat, raised band; the boss appears to be incomplete and to have been broken off, though traces of the original paint extend over the break; outer edge of the shield also has a continuous groove around the rim; the plain interior has a strap handle (now incomplete) spanning the area of the external boss and raised band; exterior painted in black and red over a white undercoat: parallel bands around the boss and two registers of triangles pointing inwards ('vandyke' pattern) in the same colours; model incomplete and reconstructed from fragments.
Curators Comments: Excavations in Cyprus (p. 85) illustrates this object as fig. 118 which is in fact 1896,2-1.53 from Tomb 98. According to Karageorghis (Coroplastic VI), the central boss originally consisted of a spike or a protome which has been broken off, though he also notes that there are traces of the white undercoat and red and black paint which decorates the rest of the shield. It seems therefore that the break occurred before the vase was painted (rather than fired as he suggests, since the break could conceivably have been repaired up to that point). The black paint in the centre may form a star-like motif, though this is uncertain.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Karageorghis Coroplastic VI / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. VI. Monsters, animals and miscellanea; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Rectangular gypsum panel with recessed or intaglio designs on one side, probably a mould for making bronze figures for a stand; on one side of the panel are two two fighting figures, next to which is a third individual, arranged upside down, carrying two vases.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIIA; Late Cypriot II
Dimensions: Length: 15.30 centimetres; Thickness: 3 centimetres; Width: 9.70 centimetres
Curators Comments: See also: V. Karageorghis, 'A Bronze Age stone mould from Hala Sultan Tekke.', BCH 113 (2), pp. 439-446; G. Papasavvas, 'Cypriot casting technology I: The stands.', RDAC 2003, p. 43; ibid. Χάλκινοι υποστάτες από την Κύπρο και την Κρήτη. (Nicosia 2001), figs, 95-96.
Bib references: Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery mug; wheel-made; decorated with painted bands and N-motif; set of horizontal and vertical dashes opposite handle; concentric circles on base.
Dimensions: Diameter: 98 millimetres; Height: 73 millimetres; Weight: 153 grammes; Width: 104 millimetres; Depth: 98 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Wheel-made Mycenaean pottery mug of Furumark type FS228 with concave body on a wide flat base, splaying outwards towards the top; single loop handle; made from fine buff clay and slip, decorated with lustrous red-brown paint: parallel bands on the base, body and rim, large spiral on the base, stripes on the handle; rim chipped, crack from rim to base in one place; small circular hole on the edge of the base.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Diameter: 9.70 centimetres base ; Diameter: 14.30 centimetres mouth ; Diameter: 141 millimetres; Height: 117 millimetres; Weight: 410 grammes; Width: 166 millimetres; Depth: 141 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Composite pottery vessel in White Painted IV ware; handmade; three globular bodied juglets joined one above two; the lower two are broken with fragments missing including the spouts; the upper juglet has a tapering cylindrical neck with a cutaway spout, now damaged and a small handle opposite; made of buff clay with an orange-buff slip with red painted decoration of encircling lines.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted IV (SCE type XIXb)
Curators Comments: Probably found in a tomb.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description:
Pottery: red-figured neck-amphora.
(a) Athene with acrostolion. Athene, in sleeved chiton, bordered himation, aegis with fringe of snakes conventionally drawn, and with a row of dots at the upper edge, hair looped up with radiated stephane, charges to right with couched spear, holding out in her left an acrostolion, in form of a bunch of curved reeds, to which is attached, on the inner side of the curve, a female face apparently with helmet, looking to left. From left to right is inscribed, Ήρας καλή.
(b) Woman fleeing to right, looking back as if at Athene, extending her arms on either side with a gesture of fear. She wears a Doric chiton undertied with a double band down the front and an apoptygma, decorated with rows of dots like the aegis of Athene in a at her neck. Her hair is short, but looped up, and has a fillet wound irregularly around it. From left to right is inscribed, Ήρας καλή.
This figure is drawn on a larger scale, and with a coarser effect than that of a.
Strong style. Drawing of a good, of b very coarse. Purple inscriptions, and fillet in b. The rays of the stephane in a are engraved. No inner markings. Eye in a of archaic type with both angles open; in b of transition type with large black disk as pupil. Below each side, a strip of running maeander.
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
Él. Cér. i, pl. 75, p. 245; Ann. dell’ Inst. 1851, p. 175; Rhein. Mus. v, p. 148; Arch. Zeit. 1868, p. 6. Wernicke, Lieblingsn. p. 14; Klein, Lieblingsinschr. p. 82; Kretschmer, Vaseninschr. pp. 190, 238; C.I.Gr. 7823; cf. Daremberg and Saglio, s.v. Aplustre.
Possibly the woman in b may be the personification of Asia, as in the Darius vase, Mon. dell’ Inst, ix, pl. 50-51. The object held by Athene is not the usual form of aphlaston; it may be the Άκρα κορνμβα, see Torr, Ancient Ships, p. 68, note 152. Nike holds it on BM Vases Β 608-9; compare the design on a sard scaraboid from Cyprus in the British Museum; also Millingen, Anc. Uned. Mon. pl. 29; and the description by Pausanias (v, 11, 5) of the figure of Salamis holding τον έτί ταίς ναυσιν ακραίε ποιούμενον κόσμον. For the various interpretations suggested and the form of name, see Arch. Zeit. loc. cit. Keil, Anal. Epig. p. 171, suggests that Ήρας is a contracted form for Ήραΐς.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Old Catalogue / A Catalogue of the Greek and Etruscan Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 5 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 7, British Museum 5

Description: Pottery oinochoe; spherical body; two-ribbed handle; narrow neck; trefoil mouth; bichrome black and white decoration on red ground of annules within concentric circles on body.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; ovoid body on a slightly splaying ring base; narrow, concave neck with a trefoil spout; thick strap handle (possibly double-ribbed originally) from shoulder to rim, now missing except for the stump of the base: cream-buff clay and slip, decorated in black and red-brown paint with some incised detail: the body and neck of the vase are divided into registers with narrow bands filled with floral decoration, two large friezes of lotus flowers on the shoulder and lower part of the body, between which is a row of vine tendrils; small flowers with many petals or solar bursts around on the neck; a prominent pair of eyes on the mouth; the underside of base is also painted.
Curators Comments: The incised detail is possibly inspired by imported Greek Black Figure, such as found on works by the 'Amathus Painter' and other workshops from that town. See V. Karageorghis & J. Des Gagniers, La céramique chypriote de style figuré (1974).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery Bichrome IV ware oinochoe or jug with figural decoration; ovoid-globular body on low annular foot; trefoil mouth with painted eye motifs on each side; vertical strap handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip decorated with black and red bichrome decoration; band of black paint around vase at junction of body and neck; narrower horizontal lines and wavy band around the neck; black paint also around the rim and on handles; figural scene depicts a chariot driving towards the left with archer firing arrows from the back; chariot has an elaborate fretwork frame supported by decorated uprights bearing spikes (arrowheads?) and an eight-spoke wheel, both orignally painted in red though now mostly faded; the galloping horse is rendered in silhouette except for a single eye in profile and a band of chevrons or zig-zags along his flank; bearded driver, naked above the waist, wears a kilt with an elaborate belt; the bearded archer is much smaller than the driver but wears a long skirt decorated with cross hatches, a thick black belt and an upper garment with traces of red paint; issuing form the wheel is a large vertical tree motif in black.
Type series: type series: Bichrome IV;  type series: Free Field
Curators Comments:
Additional bibliography: 
Karageorghis, V. 1966, 'A propos de quelques represéntations de chars sur des vases chypriotes de l'Âge du Fer', BCH 90 , 104-105 & fig. 2.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
