Description: Pottery oinochoe in Bichrome ware; baggy-ovoid body with a narrow concave neck with ridge; rounded everted rim; ring base; single double-ribbed hande from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and slip, decorated in purple to brown paint: parallel bands on the body and neck, row of concentric circles on the shoulder, ten in all; vessel slightly dented during firing (?) and lower part of body repaired.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a slightly raised, flat base; short conical neck with a plain, bowl-shaped mouth; short conical spout on the shoulder; arching handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip, decorated in black, yellow and purple paint: eyes and lotus-flowers on shoulder, horizontal bands around body and neck, purple line with short bards at intervals on the handle.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. L, nos 3 (the present examples), and 4. For an overview of this type, based on examples from Amathus in the Louvre and from recent excavations, see Fourrier 2005, 61-62.

Description: Pottery jug in Black Slip ware; wheel-made; ovoid body on a ring base; wide neck with a trefoil mouth; flat handle from shoulder to rim; body fluted vertically, with three incised horizontal bands at junction of body and neck; covered in a worn matt black; lip chipped.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome ware; squat globular body on a small, flat base; wide, slightly concave neck and a trefoil mouth; arching handle form shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated with brown and purple paint in Free Field style: two birds in flight, painted in silhouette with cross-hatched body, facing a geometric motif of three brown lines intersecting with three purple ones; pair of eyes on the spout; part of the spout is missing.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: J. Benson, The Amathus workshop, RDAC 1982, p. 141, 'Manner of the V & A painter' (a); R.S. Morris & D.J. Symons, Four figured style vases from Cyprus, RDAC 1985, p. 187.

Description: Pottery jug in Red Slip ware or Phoenician Red Slip ware of Cypro-Archaic date; wheel-made; ovoid body on a splaying foot; tall neck with a trefoil spout; tall handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and matt red slip; surface worn in places.
Curators Comments: See also J. Birmingham, AJA 67 (1963), p. 25.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville (?)
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District  Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Pottery Black-on-Red ware oinochoe; wheel-made; near-globular body; two-ribbed arched handle; mouth in form of woman's head with chin perforated to form strainer; decoration of concentric circles on shoulder, bands and concentrics below.
Curators Comments: Gjerstad assigned this vessel to Bichrome Red II (V) based on the shape though the form of the head is very similar to those found in SCE group IV pots. Given the uncertainty about the strict division between his ceramic groups, and about the absolute date of the beginning of CA II when Group V vessels became common, this item might well belong in the 7th or the 6th century BC.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in White Painted ware; globular-biconical body on a flat base with a wide neck and trefoil mouth; reddish-orange clay and slip decorated in black paint with bands around the neck and a plant motif flanked by swastikas below the spout, a pair of eyes on the mouth; handle lost.

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made. Globular body on a slightly raised disc base; short cylindrical neck with a trefoil mouth; double rib handle from shoulder to mouth. Curators Comments: For the shape, see SCE IV/2, fig. XXXIV, 16b and 15a for broadly similar decoration.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome ware; ovoid body on a low ring base; wide neck with a trefoil mouth; short handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip, decorated in black to purple and red paint: a fantastic, highly stylised bird in Free Field style facing the right, drawn in outline with a purple centre and hatched wings; chevrons in the open field; a pair of eyes on the spout; bands on the neck, with a single wavy line; ladder pattern and Union Jack motif on the handle, with two hooks descending from the base; swastikas in the field behind the bird's head; surface very abraded.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in White Painted ware; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; narrow conical neck with a trefoil mouth; vertical double-ribbed handle arching from shoulder to rim; reddish clay and cream-buff slip, decorated in brown paint: large vertical concentric circles on the sides intersected at the shoulder by a horizontal band; groups of smaller concentric circles in the spaces between; straight and wavy lines on the neck; three arrow-head motifs on the shoulder below the mouth; pair of eyes on the mouth; surface worn and rim is chipped.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Black-on-Red ware; globular-ovoid body on a low ring base; short broad neck and trefoil lip: groove at the junction of shoulder and neck; flat handle rising from shoulder to the rim; buff clay with a red-orange polished slip, decorated in black paint: row of regularly spaced concentric circles around the body of the vase, black bands at junction of shoulder and neck and on the rim, zig-zag motive down handle; lower part of vessel is cracked.
Curators Comments: The number 69 (?) is pencilled on the base.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville
Acq notes (exc): All the items in the GR 1880,7-10 sequence were formally donated to the  Trustees by the then Foreign Secretary Lord Granville. However the material  originated from various sources on Cyprus and its transfer was probably due  to the suggestion of Charles Newton who visited Cyprus in 1879. The  material said to come from Amathus and Limassol in this sequence was  probably collected or excavated by Col. Falkland Warren, District  Commissioner for Limassol 1878-9.

Description: Upper part of a pottery jug with figural decoration in White Painted ware; wheel-made; globular body with short, slightly concave neck and trefoil mouth; vertical handle from shoulder to rim; pale buff clay and slip decorated in black-brown paint in Free Field composition: a pair of birds schematically rendered with oval hatched bodies and out-stretched wings flanking two vertical trees or reeds; pair of eyes on the trefoilated mouth; band of paint at the junction of the body and neck and around the rim; zig-zig in ladder motif on the handle.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: J. Benson, RDAC 1982, pl. XXVII, 3 (The Double X Painter); S. Fourrier, CCEC 35 (2005), pp. 55-76 on similar objects from Amathus in the Louvre illustrating this local style.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug; wheel-made; oval body on a ring base; wide cylindrical neck with a trefoil mouth; plain strap handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay with a thin matt black slip (extending inside the rim), decorated with horizontal incised lines around the rim, neck and shoulder and vertical flutings down the body as far as the base, made with a rounded tool.
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware with figural decoration of birds in Free Field style; ovoid body on a low ring base; wide conical neck with a trefoil mouth; strap handle from shoulder to rim; reddish clay with deep buff slip, decorated in black and red paint: two fantastic birds facing the right, both standing on flowers (one a lotus blossom) sniffing the ends, one figure quite eroded; they are drawn in silhouette with some hatching of wings; also parallel bands on the neck and rim with a single wavy line in red; a pair of eyes on the spout; part of the spout is missing and the surface is very worn in places.
Curators Comments:
Kition (i.e. Larnaca) is given as the finspot of this vase in the original register, and it seems to be referred to by Reinach in his account of Ohnefalsch-Richter's excavations at Kition in 1881 (Reinach 1891, 175). A later annotation, probably by H.B. Walters, suggested that the item might be one of the jugs decorated with birds found by Ohnefalsch-Richter at Mari in 1881 (referring to Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, 9) but there the text is somewhat sceptical on this point. Reinach's account, written in 1885 and based on information from O-R himself, is more likely to be correct. Conversely, Reinach's comments on the finds from Mari (1891, 188) make it likely that the other bird vase in the GR 1881,8-24 sequence (no. 59) is from this site based on the description of the clay.   
The present item was found in a tomb in the Ayios Ioannis area in the north-west part of the historic town of Larnaca (Reinach 1891, 175). See Nicolaou 1976, 169-181 and fig. 10 for other tombs in this cemetery found in more recent times. Also Fourrier 2015 for a more recent overview of the topography of the site.    
NB this version of the text was written in March 2017 and should supersede previous comments. The attribution of this vessel to Kition seems assured, while the original attribution of GR 1881,8-24.59 to Mari also now seems correct. 
Bibliography:
Fourrier, S. 2015, 'The Iron Age topography of Kition' in: Kyprios Character. History, Archaeology & Numismatics of Ancient Cyprus (kyprioscharacter.eie.gr/en/t/AY)
Nicolaou, K. 1976, The historical topography of Kition (Göteborg: P. Åström)
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Reinach, S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient (Paris: Firmin-Didot).


Bibliography: 
Benson, J. 1982, 'The Amathus workshop', RDAC (1982), 138-43.
Benton, S. 1961, 'Cattle egrets and bustards in Greek art', Journal of Hellenisc Studies, JHS 81 (1961), 44-55. 
Myres, J. and Ohnefalsch-Richer, M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press). 
Reinach, S. 1891, Chroniques d'Orient (Paris: Firmin-Didot).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Kiely 2011b / Maroni (superceded, see Comments); Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Pottery jug or oinochoe in Bichrome red ware; wheel-made; globular-ovoid body on a low ring base; tall, slightly conical neck with a trefoil mouth; two-ribbed handle from shoulder to rim; pink-buff clay with a red slip and black and white painted decoration: a floral volute on the body opposite the handle (black outline with white in-fill, the latter now mostly eroded) is flanked by concentric circles arranged vertically; a horizontal register of rosettes composed of black and white dots flanked by concentric circles runs around the shoulder of the vase; parallel bands in black on the junction of the neck and shoulder (with added white dots) and on and below the rim.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description: Large pottery oinochoe or jug in White Painted ware; wheel-made; globular body on a small foot; short conical neck with trefoil mouth; arched handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and drab slip, decorated in dull dark brown paint: on each side are two large spirals, bordered by thick bands, converging in a central bull's-eye motif; narrow rings around the neck, stripe down the handle with a cross-bar at the top; lip is also painted.
Curators Comments:
See SCE IV/2, fig. XLVI for other WP V shapes of this kind.
Myres' notebook mentions only one item in this tomb, '1 vertical circle jug'. Excavations, p.126 however says that it containted two, one with 'vertical circles' (the present vessel, illustrated as Fig. 156, 5), the other resembling this type but with 'large vertical spirals' (compared to Fig. 156, 1 which is GR 1894,11-1.322, for which no tomb is given there or in Walters' catalogue).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery spouted jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular-ovoid body on a low foot; conical neck with a plain spout; arching handle from shoulder to rim; short conical spout on the shoulder; pale buff clay and slip, decorated in red and black paint: horizontal bands on the body, short bars on the handle, area around spout painted as a triangular patch bordered with black lines, two large eyes on the shoulder each side of this triangle.
Curators Comments:
For the type, see SCE IV/2, fig. L, nos 3 (the present examples), and 4. For an overview of this type, based on examples from Amathus in the Louvre and from recent excavations, see Fourrier 2005, 61-62.

Description: Pottery oinochoe in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; narrow conical neck with slightly pinched trefoil mouth; double-ribbed handle rising vertically from shouler to rim; buff clay with what appears to be the traces of a white slip, decorated with black and red paint (very worn): large concentric circles around the body, at least one smaller one below the base of the handle, solid bands on the handle crossed with groups of three horizontal strokes at intervals.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; globular-ovoid body on a low base; short neck and trefoil mouth; double-rib handle from shoulder to rim; buff slip decorated with purple-brown and red painted decoration: parallel bands intersecting with concentrics on the body, eyes on the trefoil spout; lotus motif flanked by arrows on the shoulder.
Curators Comments: Annotated in the BM catalogue as White Painted V but the use of purple and red paint more properly suggests a Bichrome ware, though there is otherwise little difference between the two wares.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a narrow ring base; narrow neck and trefoil mouth; double-rib handle from shoulder to rim; buff-pink clay and red slip, decorated in black paint: large concentric circles enclosing smaller concentrics arranged around a central bull's-eye motif on each side; single bull's-eye below the mouth above which is a series of concentrics arranged each side of a motif comprising three straight lines intersecting at the top; bands on the neck, handle and base.

Description: Large pottery oinochoe in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; narrow concave neck with trefoil mouth (damaged); double-ribbed handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and drab slip, decorated in purple and brown paint: vertical concentric bands around the body with a similar horizontal band around the shoulder; rosettes of eight petals on the sides (like a boss) and below the mouth; eyes painted on the mouth, bird on shoulder framed by intersecting concentrics; vessel repaired from fragments and partly restored, including the base.

Description: Pottery jug in Bichrome-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a splaying foot; narrow concave neck with a trefoil mouth; double-ribbed handle arching from shoulder to rim (repaired); buff clay and red slip, decorated in black and white paint: concentric bands on the body forming a bull's-eye pattern in the centre, rings around the neck, groups of white dots on the body.

Description: Mycenaean pottery oinochoe or jug of Furumark type FS 133; wheel-made; globular body on a tall stem with a splaying ring base; narrow neck and cutaway spout; plain flat vertical handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip, decorated with lustrous red-brown paint: bands and vertical strips, probably representing stylised sea-weed; repaired and restored.

Description: Large pottery oinochoe or jug in White Painted ware; globular body on a low, flat base; short neck tapering slightly upwards; handle from shoulder to rim arching above the top of the vase; buff clay and drab slip decorated with dull purple-brown paint: on each side a large continuous spirals, band and wavy line around the neck; cross-bars on top and bottom of handle connected by vertical strip; repaired from fragments.
Curators Comments: The jug is illustrated in Excavations, fig. 156, 1 but the tomb number is not given in the text on pp. 108-9 nor in Walters catalogue of Cypriot pottery. In Excavations, the jug is cited as a comparison of a jug from Tomb 295 similar to that with large verical circles on each side listed as from the same tomb (GR 1894,11-1.545) but with spirals instead of concentric circles. However, Myres' notebook entry for this tomb lists only one item item, a 'vertical circle jug'.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; ovoid-biconical body on a low conical foot; conical neck and trefoil mouth (repaired with plaster); two-ribbed handle arching from shoulder to rim; buff clay and slip, decorated with brown, red and purple paint: bands on the body, floral motif like an inverted palmette on the shoulder flanked by pointed leaves, tendrils on each side of the handles, short, irregular parallel strokes on the neck, eyes on the spout; surface worn in places.

Description: Pottery oinochoe in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body on a low ring base; narrow conical neck and plain rim; short conical spout on shoulder; plain arching handle from shoulder to rim; buff clay and drab slip, decorated with black and red paint: horizontal bands on the lower body, a pair of eyes on the shoulder on each side of the spout, with plant motifs next to the handler in the same register, crosses in the field.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; squat globular body on a narrow, flat base; wide, slightly concave neck with a trefoil mouth; arching handle from shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated in black-brown and purple paint: intersecting line motifs and pairs of zig-zags on shoulder; a pair of eyes on the mouth.

Description: Large Bichrome Red pottery ware jug (or oinochoe); wheel-made; spherical body with low ring base; tall neck tapering inwards towards a narrow trefoil spout; two-ribbed handle extending from shoulder to mouth; made of pale buff clay covered in a thick red, polished slip and decorated with black and red paint: two broad bands of fine concentric lines arranged vertically on either side of the handle and spout intersecting with a single horizontal band at the shoulder; the vertical bands frame a central bull's-eye motif of three concentric circles surrounded by seventeen smaller groups of concentric circles; below the neck at the front is a lotus flower motif painted in white flanked by pairs of concentric circles, below the horizontal band is a floral motif of narrow petals in white paint surrounded by concentric circles; on the opposite side below the handle is a T-shaped motif of small concentric circles; bands of white dots on a black background at the junction of shoulder and neck; narrow band of black and white chequer board pattern below spout; horizontal and vertical strokes on the base which appear to be painted on, possibly an inscription; slip worn in various places, sometimes down to the fabric.
Curators Comments: See SCE IV/2, pl. LIV (1) for a similar shape.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery: black-on-red ware oinochoe; globular body; long narrow neck; trefoil mouth; two-ribbed handle; decoration of intersecting bands and concentrics on body, representation of goat on to right on shoulder beneath spout.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; globular-ovoid body; low ring base, concave underneath; short, narrow slightly concave neck; bowl-shaped lip; high looped handle from shoulder to rim with a shallow concavity along the middle, perhaps imitating a double-ribbed handle; drab buff clay with many small inclusions; similar coloured slip decorated with red and dark purple paint around the belly, along the handle and neck: a simple floral motif hangs below the neck opposite the handle.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome IV ware; wheel-made; globular biconical body on a low ring base; wide, slightly concave neck with a trefoil mouth; arching handle from shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated in brown and purple paint: two birds, drawn in outline with hatched interior and solid wings, facing a stylised tree; bands on the neck and rim; a pair of eyes on the mouth; handle and mouth damaged.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug in Bichrome ware; wheel-made; globular body with straight neck and plain trefoil lip; low ring base; double-ribbed handle from shoulder to rim; orange-buff clay with many reddish inclusions; buff slip or self-slip with black and red painted decoration; two groups of vertical concentric bands (red on the outside, black within) framing a bull's eye motif on each side of the spout and handle; below spout is a stylised lotus flower flanked by pairs of concentrics in black paint above a circular, shield-like disc of black and red bands with pair of concentric below; black bands around junction of shoulder and neck and shoulder and handle and below the spout; on the handle a ladder-like motif in black; part of the lower body has been partly restored from sherds.

Description: Pottery oinochoe or jug with figural decoration in Bichrome ware; squat globular body on a flat base; wide, slightly concave neck with a trefoil spout; arching handle from shoulder to rim; cream clay and slip, decorated in brown-black and purple paint in Free Field style: three birds, bodies drawn in outline with cross-hatching inside, in flight facing right, a fourth towards the left; a pair of eyes on the mouth; bands on the neck and rim; bars on the handle.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: Benson, The Amathus workshop, RDAC 1982, p. 142, 'Miscellaneous' no. 6.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.); Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus

Description: Pottery tankard in Base Ring I ware; handmade; squat biconical body with a carinated shoulder and ring base; wide tapering neck with everted horizontal rim; strap handle with thumb grip, forked at one end; buff clay and brown slip with two encircling relief ridges just below the rim.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Base Ring I (SCE type VIIB 1e)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Wall sherd of a Panathenaic amphora; wheel-made;  part of the figure of Athene to right, showing part of shield and one of the pteryges (strips) of her himation hanging from left arm; also part of the column on the right, on the further side of which is an inscription in Greek alphabetic script.
Dimensions: Height: 7.50 centimetres max ; Width: 13 centimetres max
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Ancient Greek Inscription script: Greek Inscription quoted: Άθ[ηνήθεν άθλων. Inscription translation: One of the prizes from Athens. Inscription note: Illustration in Gardner et al 1888, p. 222 fig. 1.
Curators Comments:
See Hogarth et al. 1888, 218 and 220 for details of the find-spot (discovered with GR 1888,11-15.1, 3, 4 and 5) and further discussion. Also Maier and Karageorghis 1984,  241-2 and fig. 223; and Chapter V more generally for an overview of  the Sanctuary in the Hellenistic period; Maier 2007 provides a more  recent account. Leibundgut Wieland and Frey-Asche 2011 provide an  overview of all the known votive offerings from the shrine from  previous excavations.   
		Bibliography:
		Maier F.-G. (2007), ‘From regional centre to sanctuary town: Palaipaphos in the late Classical early Hellenistic period’, in P.  Flourentzos (ed.), From Evagoras I to the Ptolemies. The transition from the Classical to the Hellenistic period in Cyprus (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities), 17-33.
		Maier F.-G. and Karageorghis V (1984), Paphos. History and  archaeology (Nicosia: A.G. Leventis Foundation).

Description: Pottery White Painted Wheelmade III shallow pedestalled bowl with tall stem; wheel-made; carination below everted rim with rounded end; one horizontal pierced indented lug at rim; white slip with pink clay; painted purple-red concentric circles on interior and bands on exterior body.

Description: Pottery two-handled perfume flask or lekythos in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; globular body on a flat base; narrow neck with ridge, flaring to a trumpet mouth; pair of opposing arching handles from shoulder to neck ridge; buff clay and bright red slip, decorated in black paint: solid bands on mouth and neck, bands of fine parallel lines around the shoulder with groups of large and small concentrics on body and shoulder.

Description: Pottery plate in Red Slip ware; wheel-made; carinated body on a solid raised base; wide, flat everted rim, pierced twice for suspension; orange-red clay and traces of a red slip; the catalogue records traces of red, black and yellow painted decoration but these are no longer visible; repaired.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Shallow pottery plate or bowl in Bichrome ware; wheelmade; carinated sides with champfered rim; two opposed horizontal wishbone handles (one now lost); buff clay decorated with purple-brown and red paint; inside a maltese cross surrounded by concentric bands, rows of short parallel strokes on the rim; solid paint on handles (all in purple-brown); exterior has white maltese cross on black background in centre surrounded by broad red band and three narrow brown ones; then a register of hatched triangles within flanking lines and groups of short strokes (all in purple-brown) bounded by broader bands; probably Bichrome II ware.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Late Helladic III (Mycenaean) pottery pilgrim flask; wheel-made; decorated on each face with painted concentric bands; below each handle is a vertical strip of running spirals; one handle and a body fragment are missing; the rim is chipped.
Curators Comments:
According to the excavator, this vessel was found in the same tomb as the WP III-IV Pendant Line Style jug GR 1884,12-10.7 (BM Vase C326). If this is correct, the considerable difference in date between the two suggests that the tomb was used on a number of occasions from MC II-III down to the LCIIB or IIC periods. 
Reuse/continued use of tombs across the MC to LC period has also been observed in Nicosia (Merrillees 2012 for a tomb excavated by Ohnefalsch-Richter; Kromholz 1982, Tombs 6 and 15). This is also one of the very first Mycenaean vessels from Cyprus to have been recorded in situ. 
Bibliography: 
Kromholz, S. 1982, The Bronze Age necropolis at Ayia Paraskevi (Nicosia): Unpublished tombs in the Cyprus Museum (P. Åström: Göteborg). 
Merrillees, R. 2012, The 'Ochsenkrater-Grab' from Nicosia Ayia Paraskevi. SIMAL Pocket-book 177 (Uppsala: Åström).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893 / Kypros, the Bible and Homer Oriental civilization, art and religion in ancient times

Description: Pottery double-flask in White Painted ware; wheel-made; two joined lentoid bodies and sets of two handles; brown painted concentrics on drab ground.
Curators Comments:
The number 13 pencilled on the body of the vessel may be a tomb number, but no tomb inventory has survived. The archival sources suggest that neither Welch nor Christian made one, so this number cannot safely be interepreted as referring to a specific archaeological context.
According to Dr Anna Georgiadou (e-mail of 17/11/2015) this vessel belongs to a rare series made exclusively in the Cypro-Geometric period. Unpublished examples are known from  Amathus, Kition and Lapithos, but this is the only one attested at Palaepaphos.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: Ivory pin with a circular section and pine-cone shaped head; lathe-turned decoration: concentric incisions between concave moulding; point missing. Slightly abraded condition.
Production place: Made in: Cyprus (?);  Made in: Levant (?);  Made in: Egypt (?)
Curators Comments: The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description: Rim and part of upper body of a large Red Slip pottery pithos or storage vessel; wheelmade/ wheel-turned; thick lower body separated from carinated upper part by a prominent ridge; small relief head of a human with long tresses and large ears at the junction, possibly a hathor figure; details of hair rendered with parallel diagonal incisions; broad, flat everted rim with a continuous groove on the inner side; coarse buff clay with small white inclusions covered in a red slip; traces of a darker red paint below the rim may represent an original all-over layer of paint; top and inside of rim painted in black; reconstructed from fragments.
Curators Comments:
Exact parallels are unknown but see SCE IV/2, pl. XXIV for similar protomes on a Bichrome III ring vase; this may also be related to the later protome vases of CA II date (see Vandenabeele 1998, chapter II) or to vases with anthropomorphic elements vase (see Nys 1997). These may also be related to figurines found on wall plaques, some of which were holders for lamps or incense burners (see J. and V. Karageorghis 2006, who discuss the identity of the figurines which may be deities, especially Hathor). The identification of the head on the present example as Hathor is less certain, as it lacks the familiar upcurling locks, though more correctly this is probably an image of the local Great Goddess than Hathor herslef.  
Bibliography: 
Carbillet, A. 2011, La figure hathorique à Chypre (IIe-Ier mill. av. J.-C.). AOAT 388 (Münster: Ugarit-Verlag). 
Karageorghis, J. and V. 2006, 'A propos des appliques murales de Chypre', RDAC 2006, 173-7.
	Nys, K. 1997, 'Vases with anthropomorphic protomes in the Cypro-Geometric and Cypro-Archaic periods (1060-475 B.C.), in: V.  Karageorghis, R. Laffineur and F. Vandenabelle (eds), Four thousand years of images on Cypriote pottery. Proceedings of the Third International Conference of Cypriote Studies, Nicosia 3-4 May, 1996 (Brussels-Liège-Nicosia), 81-7.
Vandenabeele, F. 1998, Figurines on Cypriot jugs holding an oinochoe (Jonsered: P. Åström).
Bib references: Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

The rim is pierced with holes for suspension. A sphinx seated to right, with long hair and wings recurved. Between its legs is a swan to right with beak resting on breast.

Description: Pottery plate in White Painted ware; wheel-made; with two handles, one a projecting spike and the other horizontal with cross-bar; black painted decoration including central star.
Curators Comments:
The number '32' is written on the body of the plate and might be assumed to refer to a tomb number. However, no list of the tombs has survived and, according to a letter written by Percy Christian to A.S. Murray, none of the burials discovered was sufficiently intact or interesting to warrent making one. It is possible that Francis Welch made notes that were shared with the British Museum, but there is no indicaiton of this in his short report to the British Museum preseved in the GR archives (both documents bound in Excavations in Cyprus: Correspondence).     
This shape originates in the Proto-White Painted ware repertoire of the 11th century BC (see Pieridou 1973, 14, Type 2 and pls. 6-11 - examples from Kourion and Lapithos -  and Karageoghis 1975, G1 (from Gastria-Alaas)). Numerous examples of this basic type, with variations in the form of the loop handle, have been found in Cypro-Geometric Tombs at Palaepaphos excavated by the Department of Antiquities in modern times, the best documented of which are those from the cemetery of Skales (e.g. Tombs 44, no. 85; Tomb 45, no. 53; Tomb 48A, no. 4 (pedestalled bowl); Tomb 51, no. 22; Tomb 67, nos 94 and 151) though none of these examples have the divided loop handle of the present example. The motif on the underside is also employed on more regular two-handled shallow bowls/plates, many of which occur in the Skales tombs and which is typical of local production (see Smith 2009, 238-40 and pl. VII.1 with refs).   
Bibliography:
Karageorghis V. 1975, Alaas. A Protogeometric necropolis in Cyprus (Nicosia: Department of Antiquities).
Karageorghis V. (1983), Palaepaphos-Skales. An Iron Age cemetery in Cyprus. Ausgrabungen in Alt-Paphos auf Cypern 3 (Konstanz: Universitätsverlag Konstanz).
Pieridou A. 1973, [The Protogeometric style in Cyprus. Library of the Athens Archaeological Society 77] (in Greek) (Athens: Athens Archaeological Society).
Smith J. 2009, Art and society in Cyprus from the Bronze Age into the Iron Age (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum

Description: White Painted III pottery plate; conical profile with two strap horizontal handles (one missing); wheel-made; buff clay decorated with matt, dark brown paint: inside, band of paint around the rim and broad and narrow bands in centre, random blob of paint between rim and centre; underside with concentric bands around base framing intersecting triangles and row of lozenge flanked by ladders, intersecting triangles and herring-bone patterns on outer side; paint on surviving handle; rim chipped in three places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (described as a bowl in text); Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery plate in Black Slip Bichrome II ware; wheel-made; shallow body with obliquely ribbed exterior wall; pair of opposing wishbone handles, one now missing except for the stumps; broad ring base running around the edge of the underside; buff clay and slip, except on the exterior walls which are covered in black paint; brown and purple painted decoration: on the underside, lattice-triangles and zig-zags framed by parallel lines around a central arrangement of concentric circles, row of short strokes on the ring base; the interior consists of two series of narrow brown bands divided by a broader band in purple.
Type series: type series: Black Slip II;  type series: Bichrome II
Curators Comments: The decoration and technique is a composite of Black Slip and Bichrome ware (see SCE IV/2, 76-7).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.

Description: Pottery pyxis, approximately 1/4 missing and partly repaired, in Base Ring II ware (?) imitating a Mycenaean shape; squat biconical body with rounded base; concave neck; everted rim added separately; three pierced lug-handles (two surviving); very thin, but relatively coarse, orange-buff clay with grey core similar to Base Ring fabric; orange-buff slip; decorated in matt brown paint in the manner of Base Ring II ware: irregular bands of parallel lines on lower part of vase and with multiple concentric lines between the handles.
Culture: Late Cypriot II; Late Cypriot III
Curators Comments: Probably a variant of Base Ring ware decorated in a dark-on-light manner closer to terracotta figurines than to pottery vessels of similar shape found in this fabric in BRI ware (e.g. Enkomi 1897,4-1.1252 and 1897,4-1.977) but not in BRII; this type is described as transitional BRI-II by Åström (SCE IV/1C, p. 143). Åström includes this vase in his WS II category (SCE IV/1C, p. 471) as well as WP VI (p. 55) though the fabric and decoration are closer to BR II. The closest Mycenaean shapes are FS 81 (LH IIA), FS 83 (LHIIA-IIIA1) or 85 (LH IIIA2-B).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Kiely 2011a / Kourion; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Pottery Red Polished ware box (pyxis); hand-made; depressed oval body on a flattened base; oval mouth with small holes on each side midway along; the oval lid, with a single rectangular lug handle, has similar perforations in corresponding posiitions; made of light buff clay covered with a lustrous slip fired orange-red throughout; decorated with incised motifs: concentric rows of semi-circles joined by zig-zags composed of parallel lines on the base and body; on the lid, bands of parallel lines radiating from the lug handle; surface and slip worn in places; minor restoration on the body.
Culture: Early Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Stewart Type IX C c3 -?-
Dimensions: Height: 12.70 centimetres with lid ; Length: 27.94 centimetres
Curators Comments:
Parallels for this type of vessel can be found in North Coast cemteries: Bellapais-Vounous Tomb 1 (Dikaios 1940, 5 note 1 and pl. XXXIVb); Tomb 9 (Dikaios 1940, 23 no. 35; Tomb 11 (Dikaios 1940, 27 no. 55 and pl XXXIVa) and see also the semi-circle motif on another example in Tomb 9 (Dikaios 1940, 23 no. 35 and pl. XXXVII); also Karmi-Lapatsa Tomb 4 (Webb et al. 2009, 21 no. 12 and pl. 8g).
Some more elaborate examples are decorated with animal and human figurines on the top of lid of the box:  Vounous Tomb 2 (Dikaios 1940, pl. XXXVI); Lapatsa Tomb 11 (Webb et al. 2009, 35 no. 1 and 214, fig. 4.13).
Bibliography: 
Dikaios P. 1940, The excavations at Vounous-Bellapais in Cyprus, 1931-2. Archaeologia 88 (Oxford: Soeciety of Antiquaries). 
Webb J. et al. 2009, The Bronze Age cemeteries at Karmi Palealona and Palatsa in Cyprus. Excavations by J.R.B. Stewart. SIMA CXXXVI (Sävedalen).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola
Acq notes (exc): Luigi Palma di Cesnola, like his brother Alessandro (q.v.), assembled large numbers of artefacts in Cyprus which they claimed to have excavated in person. This may be true in some instances, but both - and especially Luigi - made extensive use of agents across the island who dug on their behalf or else collected items from the local antiquity market (itself spurred by the growing demand for ancient artafects by individuals such as the Cesnolas). This practice casts doubt on the provenance assigned to items which in some cases is demonstrably false or misleading - most notoriously in the case of the so-called Curium Treasure which Luigi assembled from tombs (and perhaps shrines) of different periods in the Kourion area.

Description: Late Helladic (Mycenaean) ware squat cylindrical two-handled pyxis (Furumark Shape 94); wheelmade; decorated with bands and N-shapes; one handle is missing.
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
This vessel was illustrated in Furtwängler and Loeschcke's seminal work on Mycenaean pottery (1886, p. 30).   
Bibliography:
Furtwängler, A. und Loeschcke, G. (1886), Mykenische Vasen, vorhellenische Thongefässe aus dem Gebiete des Mittelmeeres (Berlin: A. Asher).
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery (Incorrectly attributed to the Cesnola collection (see C480; 1876,9-9.32))

Description: Cylindrical limestone or alabaster box (pyxis); flaring foot, edges badly chipped throughout; round moulding beneath the rim encircling the vase; ground into shape and polished; below the moulding is a series of signs running around the vase framed by two red ink lines; inscription is lightly incised and painted in the same colour as the borders; fifteen signs of varying size (3-10 mm) with dividers in the form of simple dots.
Dimensions: Diameter: 4 centimetres; Height: 3.80 centimetres; Width: 5 centimetres (approx) including base
Inscription: Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Ancient Greek Inscription script: Cypriot Syllabic Inscription transliteration: ta-ma-ra-ko-se-zo-te-a-ne-te-ke-a-po-lo-ni Inscription translation: Timaratos son of Zoteas dedicated this to Apollo Inscription note: After Masson 1961/1983, p. 295 and 1966, 25. Originally read as 'ka-ma-la-ko-se-zo-te-a-ne-te-ke-a-po-lo-ni' with Timalkos or Gamalkos read as the dedicant (see Masson 1966, 25 for a revised reading).
Bib references: Masson 1966 / Kypriaka III. Vases d'albâtre inscrits du temple de Golgoi; Masson 1983 / Les inscriptions chypriotes syllabiques. Recueil critique et commenté
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang

Description:
Two fragments of a red-figure plastic rhyton by the Sotades Painter 
GR 1888,11-15.4: fragment from lower part of vessel, including a left arm; partly covered with black gloss.
GR 1888,11-15.3: fragment of the lower part of the cup, with only the lower half of the upper frieze preserved. 
Upper frieze: The making of Pandora; In the centre is seen the lower part of the figure of Pandora in a long chiton, with feet close together, facing to front. On the right the feet of Athene in long chiton and peplos, holding her spear, hastening to left. Behind her, the end of an himation of a third figure. On the left of Pandora is Hephaestos, standing partly to the front, wearing a short bordered himation. Next him on left a woman (Aphrodite ?) in a long bordered chiton and an himation falling in pteryges at her right side, looking towards Pandora.
Lower frieze: The Calydonian boar-hunt. A bearded hunter, Meleager, with a skin fastened round his shoulders and covering his extended left arm, the paws knotted on his breast, strides to left after a boar which gallops away up hill to right. Meleager has a small hunter's club in his left, and seems to be hurling a stone with his right hand, which is broken away. He wears a purple fillet. Brown inner markings and details of skin. Eye in archaic type. The two friezes are separated by a band of elaborate maeander alternating with rosettes of four petals, red on black.
Dimensions: Height: 12 centimetres max (1888,11-15.3) ; Width: 6.80 millimetres 1888,11-15.4 ; Width: 9.80 centimetres max (1888,11-15.3)
Curators Comments:
See Hogarth et al. 1888, 218 and 220 for details of the find-spot (discovered  with GR 1888,11-15.1 and 5) and further discussion. Also Maier and  Karageorghis 1984,  241-2 and fig. 223; Chapter V more generally for an  overview of  the Sanctuary in the Hellenistic period; Maier 2007 provides a  more  recent account. Leibundgut Wieland and Frey-Asche 2011 provide an   overview of all the known votive offerings from the shrine from  previous  excavations.   
		On the vessel itself, see Hermary 2004 and Lubsen-Admiraal and Hoffmann  1995. Hoffmann 1997 provides a survey of all of the work attributed to  Sotades. On the significance of plastic vases in Attic Greek pottery, see Lissarrague 1995 (with earlier references), while True 2006 discusses their production. 
 
		Bibliography:
		Hermary, A. 2004, 'Rhytons de l'atelier de Sotadès dans l'Empire  Achéménide,  de Palaepaphos à Suse', Mediterranean Archaeology 17, 43-50.

Description: Fragment of a pottery plastic rhyton (with GR 1888,11-15.3, a rhyton by the Sotades Painter); mould-made; part in form of left arm; part of the fragment is covered with black gloss.
Curators Comments:
See Hogarth et al. 1888, 218 and 220 for details of the find-spot (discovered with GR 1888,11-15.1, 3, 4 and 5) and further discussion. Also Maier and Karageorghis 1984,  241-2 and fig. 223; and Chapter V more generally for an overview of  the Sanctuary in the Hellenistic period; Maier 2007 provides a more  recent account. Leibundgut Wieland and Frey-Asche 2011 provide an  overview of all the known votive offerings from the shrine from  previous excavations.   
On the vessel itself, see Hermary 2004 and Lubsen-Admiraal and Hoffmann 1995. Hoffmann 1997 provides a survey of all of the work attributed to Sotades.

Description: Fragment of Clazomenian painted terracotta sarcophagus. Satyr. Below, dividing band of dots, chequers, and presumably another band of dots. Inner details in white, much of which has perished. No certain traces of purple.
Curators Comments:
CVA British Museum 8 (Comment relates to whole sarcophagus, with 1886.3-26.5)
The shape is that of the ordinary sarcophagus. The rounding of the top of the headpiece is modern: according to Dennis the fragment had been reused for building (AD i, 34).
For the boy and dogs compare closely Istanbul 1352, which is by the same hand (Johansen, Acta Arch xiii, 41-47, fig. 27). The Istanbul sarcophagus has also the framing band, rosettes - though of different antecedents - in the upper corner strip, and the chequering below the upper panel; but these appear on other early sarcophagi. Satyrs painted in white are frequent blazons of shields in the Albertinum group; those always have human feet, perhaps in deference to Attic. But this hooved satyr looks back to his older relations on Clazomenian black figure pots (see BSA xlvii, 142 n. 87). So, much more obviously, do the large cockerels (cf., for example, Pl. 587, 16-17).
The headpiece is decorative both in arrangement and intention. The central figure, as Johansen has explained admirably, is excerpted from the Attic group, familiar in the mid and later sixth century, of the man who woos his boy friend with the gift of a cockerel (From the Collections iii, 134-40; and on these scenes generally see J. D. Beazley, Some Attic Vases in the Cyprus Museum, 18-24). The doubling of the cockerels, though authorized by Attic, is necessary here for decorative symmetry; and the dogs and flanking poultry are more or less appropriate filling. A similar grouping of a boy holding a small cockerel and a large cockerel beside him can be made out on an earlier Clazomenian black figure potsherd (Pl. GB 588, 5). There is, of course, no need or excuse for a chthonic interpretation of this headpiece, nor yet of the satyr of the upper panel.
This is evidently an early sarcophagus. Its not very competent painter, whether he drew directly on Attic or not, was partly dependent on the Borelli painter. Johansen proposes a date in the 530's (Acta Arch xiii, 45-47); but some of his parallels are dated perhaps a little too early and he makes no allowance for lag.
G. Dennis, JHS 1883-iv, 20, fig. 15 (inaccurate drawing of satyr). C. Smith, JHS 1885, 190-1, fig. 4 (fair drawing of satyr). AD i, pl. 46. 3. A. Joubin, de Sarcophagis Clazomeniis, no. 3. K. F. Johansen, From the Collections iii, 134-41, fig. 6; Acta Arch xiii, 41-47, fig. 28. A. W. Byvanck, l’Antiquité Classique 1948, 98-D.1.
(For interpretations and criticisms of these interpretations see also: G. Loeschke, aus der Unterwelt; A. Furtwangler, AA 1889, 147; F. Deneken, in W. H. Roscher's Ausführliches Lexikon der gr. und rom. Mythologie i. 2, 2586; O. Immisch, ibid. ii. 1, 1127-9; E. Rohde, Psyche8 i, 306; F. Winter, AA 1898, 177; C. C. Edgar, BSA v, 61; P. Perdrizet, Revue des Études Anciennes 1904, 14-16; L. Malten, Jdl 1914, 236 n. 8; E. Pfuhl, Malerei und Zeichnung i, 169; C. T. Seltman, BSA xxvi, 93 and 100-1.)

Description: Fragment of Clazomenian painted terracotta sarcophagus. Upper corner strip, rosettes. No certain traces of purple.
Curators Comments:

D. Beazley, Some Attic Vases in the Cyprus Museum, 18-24). The doubling of the cockerels, though authorized by Attic, is necessary here for decorative symmetry; and the dogs and flanking poultry are more or less appropriate filling. A similar grouping of a boy holding a small cockerel and a large cockerel beside him can be made out on an earlier Clazomenian black figure potsherd (Pl. GB 588, 5). Johansen proposes a date in the 530's (Acta Arch xiii, 45-47); but some of his parallels are dated perhaps a little too early and he makes no allowance for lag.
G. Dennis, JHS 1883-iv, 20, fig. 15 (inaccurate drawing of satyr). C. Smith, JHS 1885, 190-1, fig. 4 (fair drawing of satyr). AD i, pl. 46. 3. A. Joubin, de Sarcophagis Clazomeniis, no. 3. K. F. Johansen, From the Collections iii, 134-41, fig. 6; Acta Arch xiii, 41-47, fig. 28. A. W. Byvanck, l’Antiquité Classique 1948, 98-D.1.
(For interpretations and criticisms of these interpretations see also: G. Loeschke, aus der Unterwelt; A. Furtwangler, AA 1889, 147; F. Deneken, in W. H. Description: Pottery skyphos (cup) with white decoration on a red ground.
Curators Comments:
Belongs to Lund's Cypriot-made West Slope type E ('A tall skyphos with carinated body and lateral arched handles') (Lund 2015, 96-104). The ware as a whole circulated between around 250/225 BC and the beginning of the 1st century BC, with a possible concentration between 200 and 150 BC (p. 104). See also Lund 2006, 34-5 and fig. 1. See Salles 1993, 184 nos 201-202 for examples from Kition, though he suggests a source in southern Turkey which Lund rejects (2006, 35 note 44).  
Bibliography:
Lund J. 2015, A study of the circulation  of ceramics in Cyprus from the 3rd  century BC to the 3rd century AD.  Gösta Enbom Monographs (Aarhus:  Aarhus University Press).
Lund J. 2006, 'On the circulation of goods in Hellenistic and early Roman Cyprus: the ceramic evidence', in eds L. Wriedt Sørensen and K. Winther Jacobsen, Panayia Ematousa II. Political, cultural and social relations in Cyprus. Approaches to regional studies. Monographs of the Danish Institute at Athens 6,2, 31-49.
Salles J.-F. 1993, Kition-Bamboula IV: Les niveaux héllenistiques (Paris: ERC).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Tatton-Brown 1987 / Ancient Cyprus; Lund 2015 / A study of the circulation of ceramics in Cyprus from the 3rd  century BC to the 3rd century AD
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Luigi Palma di Cesnola

Description:
Pottery: two-handled deep cup or bowl (skyphos) decorated in red-figure technique; wheel-made; deep body on a wide moulded base; wide mouth with a plain rim; pair of opposing loop handles (restored); made of buff clay covered with a black lustrous slip (almost metallic sheen) reserved for red-figure decoration:
(a) A woman standing en face, looking to left, in a Doric chiton schistos, with apoptygma, and earrings, holding upright in left a long burning torch, and extending in right a phiale. The hair is looped up with a broad fillet. On left, ΚΑΛΟΣ, καλός (now faint).
(b) A Maenad in a long chiton and himation, and radiated fillet, standing to right holding upright in left a thyrsos; from its stem an ivy branch springs to right. On left ΚΑΛΕ, καλή (now faint).
Below each handle is a palmette with tendril ornament; black concentric circle on underside of base; vase reconstructed from fragments, with some restoration, edges chipped at the joins; surface worn in places.
Inscription:
Inscription type: inscription Inscription language: Attic Greek Inscription script: Greek Inscription quoted: ΚΑΛΟΣ, καλός
ΚΑΛΕ, καλή Inscription transliteration: Kalos/kale Inscription translation: Handsome/beautiful
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 4 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 5, British Museum 4; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti

Description: Four stone whorls or beads.
Curators Comments:
The exact provenance of each item in the registration sequence GR 1881,8-24.1-165 is not given in every case but everything with a stated findspot comes from either Salamis - the majority - or Kition. A few items, namely, the bird vases GR 1881,8-24.47 and 59, may have been found in Mari, if they are the same items mentioned in the Cataogue of the Cyprus Museum (Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter 1899, 9) as among those excavated there by Ohnefalsch-Richter. Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.
Bibliography:
Myres J. and Ohnefalsch-Richter M. 1899, A catalogue of the Cyprus Museum (Oxford: Clarendon Press).
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Salamis is the most likely provenance for the Hellenisticand Roman material in this registration group given the preponderance of finds of this date among the provenanced items.  
Material identified by F. Poplin April 2007. 
For comparable examples of Roman date (from Corinth) see Davidson 1952, cat. nos. 1396-1398. 
Bibliography:
Davidson G. 1952, Corinth. Volume XII. The minor objects (Princeton: American School of Classical Studies at Athens).
Acq name (acq): Donated through: Claude Delaval Cobham; Division of Finds: Government of Cyprus

Description:
Pottery: red-figured squat lekythos.
Aphrodite and a young hunter (Adonis?). In the centre, Aphrodite (flesh coloured white) is seated on raised ground to left, with a mantle over her legs, leaning on her left hand; her face and right arm are missing; she wears a radiated fillet, necklace of beads, and bracelets. Confronting her on left is seated a youth in a chlamys and a Phrygian cap, resting his left hand on the end of his club, the head of which rests on the ground beside him; his left elbow is placed in the hollow between the branch and trunk of a tree which springs from the ground on his left. His face, which is broken away, seems to be turned to the front. Behind Aphrodite, Eros flies towards her, and appears to be clasping her round the neck; his face is damaged; he wears a fillet. On the right is a group of two women: one is seated on raised ground, and holds out in her right hand to left a wreath of laurel (part missing), of which her left hand probably held the other end. Behind her stands a woman who rests one hand on either shoulder of the seated figure; her drapery flies back as if she were in quick movement, though her feet are together. On the left a third woman stands looking to right, leaning forward with left knee raised, and resting her left elbow in another hollow of the tree. All the women wear a long chiton tied, earrings, necklace, and bracelets, and their hair is knotted high with a fillet. In the ground, branches of laurel spring up.
Below, egg pattern; above, a kind of alternate palmette and lotus; round neck, tongue pattern. Below the handle, a pattern composed of four palmettes with tendrils.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Meidias Painter
Curators Comments:
BM Cat. Vases
J.H.S. vol. xi (1890), pl. 4, p. 47.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Munro & Tubbs 1890 / Excavations in Cyprus, 1889. Second season's work. Polis tes Chrysochou-Limniti
Condition: Badly damaged. Neck and portions of design missing.
Assoc name: Representation of: Aphrodite/Venus;  Representation of: Adonis (?)

Description: Pottery stamnos or vase in Bichrome Ware with figural decoration; wheel-made; two upright handles beneath shoulder; buff clay and slip decorated in purple and black paint with horizontal bands framing a figural scene around the shoulder on each side: a large snake, outlined with dots running continuously around its body, facing a tree from which hangs an indeterminate object, also fringed in dots, hanging from the branches; a geometrical motif of triangles framed by bands of vertical parallel lines flanks the central scene; the scene on the opposite side of the vase is very worn. Bichrome III-IV ware.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis and Des Gagniers 1974 / La céramique chypriote de style figuré. Âge du Fer (1050-500 av. J.-C.)

Description: Large pottery stamnos or wide-mouthed jar in Black-on-Red ware; wheel-made; deep body, slightly angular at the top and bottom, on a turned ring base; narrow, flat disc-like rim; pair of opposing double-loop handles in quasi-zoomorphic form; orange-yellow clay and orange-red slip, decorated in black paint: on both sides of the body are panels comprising latticed chequer-board between vertical parallel; horizontal bands of fine parallel lines around the body; on the rim, groups of transverse strokes at intervals; solid handles.
Type series: type series: Black-on-Red III;  type series: Black-on-Red IV
Curators Comments: Circumstances of the discovery of the tomb recorded in the Book of Presents, Supplementary I, no. 2868 and Reports 1879-90, Greek and Roman Antiquities, 8th July 1880. Summarised by Bailey 1968, pp. 36-41 along with full description and interpretation of the material. Bailey suggests (p. 46) that Gjerstad's assignment of this vase to BoR IV is incorrect and probably belongs in the preceding group on grounds of comparison with Bichrome III shapes.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; SCE IV/2 / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 2. The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods.; Bailey 1970 / The village priest's tomb at Aradippou in Cyprus
Acq name (acq): Donated by: Granville George Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville

Title: The Marion Kouros (Object)
Description:
Parian marble kouros.  
Statue of a nude standing youth, less than life-size; from the base of the neck to below the knees is preserved, the head and lower legs are missing. Both arms are broken away above the biceps. Except for minor abrasions, the surface is in excellent condition.
The youth stands to the front, balanced on both legs, the right slightly drawn back. The arms were at the sides, the forearms bent forward to reach the front of the thighs, where the points of attachment remain. The hair was short, as no trace remains on the neck.
The bony structure of the chest is heavily emphasised, in contrast with the remainder of the modelling, the other body forms being slender and soft. The collar-bones are prominent; the shoulders are narrow and sloping. The breasts are high placed and in high relief, which is carried back to the armpits; both nipples are chipped, but were originally large. The lower edge of the ribs is strongly outlined; the navel is eye-shaped, the lower abdomen and the hips are long and narrow. The thighs and legs are square-cut in section. At the back the shoulders are flat and the pelvis prominent, the spine slightly incurved.
Curators Comments:
Additional bibliography: M. Ohnefalsch-Richter 1893, Kypros, the Bible and Homer (London), 361-2, 497, 503; pls XXVII, 3 and CLXXIV, 2 [includes a description of the findspot by the excavator]; 1893 K. Sheedy 2008, 'The Marion Kouros in the British Museum', in ed. Y. Kourayos and F. Prost, La Sculpture des Cyclades à l’Époque Archaïque. BCH Supplément 48. Paris 2008, 335–65 (with full references to this date); D. Williams 2009, Masterpieces of Classical Art (London), 86.
Also registered with this object was a silver coin of Idalion dating 'slightly before 500 B.C.' according to the register (1887,8-1.3) and a silver boss from a shield (1887,8-1.3). The comments in the register state that the tomb also contained 'gold cups, with acorns repoussé; electrum ring with engraving of boat of the sun; large bronze vessel; many black figure vases; no red figd. vases...and additional items'. Photographs of some of these are included in an album entitled 'Misc. Photographs II' in the Greek and Roman Department archive.
For the excavations in 1886 see Ohneflsch-Richter 1893 passim; the main analytic account sis P Herrmann 1888, Das Gräberfeld von Marion auf Cypern (Berlin). Many of the contents of the 441 tombs opened during this campaign were sold in Paris in 1887, though the finds in the BM were directly through Charles Christian, one of the archaeological syndicate. The published catalogue details only a fraction of the overall finds, which amounted to several thousand items in total.; BM Sculpture
The statue is generally recognised as Ionic in origin ('Island-Ionic’, Studniczka; 'Samian’, Langlotz). 
Smith, no. 207; Collignon, Statues funeraires, p. 83; Deonna, Apollons archaiques, p. 238, no. 141, et passim; Furtwangler, Coll. Sabouroff, I, p. 54, n. 1; Herrmann, Graberfeld von Marion, p. 22; Langlotz, Frühgr. Bildhauerschulen, pp. 109, 118; Markides in J.H.S., 1913, p. 49; Müller, Nacktheit u. Entblössung, p. 113; Murray, Handb. of Gr. Arch., p. 246, fig. 8. Myres and Ohnefalsch-Richter, Cyprus Mus. Catalogue, p. 30; Ohnefalsch-Richter, Kypros, Bible and Homer, p. 361, pl. XXVII, 3a and b; Orsi in Mon. Ant., I, p. 795, n. 4; Perrot, Hist. de l’Art, VIII, p. 400, n. 2; S. Reinach, Chroniques d'Orient I, p. 559 and in Rev. Critique, 1889, p. 285, n. 1, and Repertoire, II, p. 78. 3; Studniczka in Jahrbuch, 1911, pp. 125, n. 4, and 153.
Bib references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum; Richter 1970 / Kouroi. Archaic Greek youths. A study of the development of the kouros type in Greek sculpture

Description: Tall pottery stirrup jar (or false-necked jar); thick, coarse clay with buff slip and black-red paint; decorated on each side with a large painted octopus occupying most of the vessel, framed on top and bottom by parallel lines; restored from fragments; each handle is incised with a ￂ sign; Late Minoan fabric from Crete.
Culture: Late Minoan IIIA2; Late Minoan IIIB
Dimensions: Height: 45 centimetres; Weight: 4 kilograms; Width: 30 centimetres
Inscription:
Inscription type: pottery mark Inscription language: Ancient Greek Inscription script: Linear B Inscription transliteration: 'da' (?) Inscription note: Linear B?
The incised sign is similar to 'da' in Linear B but also 'ta' in the later Classical Syllabary but it is unclear if the sign was added before or after this vase came to Cyprus. See also AJA LXV (1941), 267, fig. 11; Berytus XIV, 37; Catling & Karageorghis, Minoica in Cyprus, ABSA LV 55 (1960), 118 no. 23.
Ancient Greek?
Curators Comments:
Some fragments of this vase were discovered by Daniel and the University of Pennsylvania excavations in the late 1930s (their Tomb 26) and presented to the BM where they were joined with existing parts (June 1957) (see Benson 1972, 4, 25-6).
The incised sign is similar to 'da' in Linear B but also 'ta' in the later Classical Syllabary but it is unclear if the sign was added before or after this vase came to Cyprus (See Daniel 1941, 267, fig. 11)
See also Catling and Karageorghis 1960, 118 no. 23; Benson 1961, 37.

Description: Pottery stirrup jar in Proto-White Painted ware; wheel-made; depressed globular-biconical body on a small conical foot; buff clay and slip, decorated with matt black paint: lower body, foot and false-neck is solid; concentric bands around the shoulder, above which are lattice and hatched triangles on the shoulder; short strokes on the handles; concentric circle on the false-mouth.

Description: Pottery stirrup jar with tall piriform profile and a high splaying foot, concave underneath; wheel-made; spout is relatively wide, slightly averted, with a prominent ridge at the junction between the neck and the spount; buff slip and red paint; bands of painted decoration on body; vertical strokes and parallel bands on shoulder; spirals on closed mouth, restored and repaired from fragments; Mycenaean.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB

Description: Wheel-made pottery Mycenaean IIIA2 stirrup jar of Furumark type FS 166, with false neck, conven, flaring spout and a high stemmed foot with low ring base; orange clay with buff core; buff slip and painted decoration of red bands and chevrons; the foot and false neck are chipped.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Description: Pottery stirrup jar in Late Helladic (Mycenaean) ware; wheelmade. Decorated with a `foliate band'.
Dimensions: Diameter: 100 millimetres; Height: 98 millimetres; Weight: 193 grammes; Width: 100 millimetres; Depth: 97 millimetres
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery

Description: Pottery stirrup jar with globular body, vertical strap handles, false mouth and spout; wheel-made; buff slip and dark brown paint varying to black and red; decorated with registers of parallel lines on body and foot, concentric circles on false mouth and four stylised floral motifs on shoulder arranged around the handles; Mycenaean.
Dimensions: Diameter: 68 millimetres; Height: 68 millimetres; Weight: 80 grammes; Width: 68 millimetres; Depth: 67 millimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery: Wheel-made Mycenaean stirrup jar with a high stem with Furumark shape FS166; orange clay with cream slip decorated with painted reddish-brown bands and concentric semicircles; the spout is missing; a side fragment is missing.

Description: Pottery Late Minoan ware stirrup jar; wheel-made; conical-piriform body on a high stem foot; false neck; stirrup handles; made of buff clay and buff-cream slip, decorated with lustrous red-brown paint: horizontal bands and wavy cross-hatched lines in red-brown paint; stylised motifs on the shoulder (FM 64:16 and FM71c); a fragment of the body is missing; foot is chipped.
Culture: Late Minoan IIIA; Late Minoan IIIB1
Dimensions: Diameter: 3.50 centimetres base ; Diameter: 9.10 centimetres max ; Height: 10.50 centimetres

Description: Pottery Mycenaean stirrup jar of Furumark type FS184; wheel-made; pyxis-type body with vertical (but slightly concave) sides on a ring base; broad angular shoulder; false spout with three stirrup handles; short tubular spout with concave sides; made with buff clay, slipped and decorated with brown and orange lustrous paint: vertical lines of chain motifs on the body, the shoulder has patterns in concentric circles, including chains and N-shaped motifs, the handle zone has floral designs.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Diameter: 17.50 centimetres; Height: 16 centimetres; Weight: 439 grammes

Description: Pottery Mycenaean stirrup jar of Furumark type FS 173; wheel-made; globular body on a ring base; false-neck with stirrup handles; short tubular spout with a thick squared rim; made of buff clay and similar slip, decorated with lustrous borwn-orange paint: wide and narrow circular bands around the body and shoulder, single horizontal chain motif around the middle of the vase, stylised floral motifs on the shoulder, solid paint on the handles and rim.  .

Description: Pottery storage jar ('amphora') in Red Polished Ware III ware; handmade; globular body, round base and a wide cylindrical neck with slightly everted rim; vertical handles from mid-neck to shoulder; decorated with  raised bands and rings and incised zig-zags; orange clay with a red slip, worn in places; heavily restored.
Type series: type series: Stewart Type (VII A2 z2)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery storage jar ('amphora')  in Red Polished III ware; handmade; depressed biconical body on a flat narrow base with a wide cylindrical neck indented around the join with the body and an everted rim with an angular profile; pair of opposing handles with slight horns; two raised cable-bars on neck and shoulder of both sides; buff clay covered with a reddish-brown slip burnished to a high lustre; surface worn in places; repair on the handles.
Type series: type series: Red Polished III;  type series: Stewart Type (VII a2 type z2)

Description: Pottery tankard; White Painted VI ware; hand-made; wide cylindrical neck and biconical body; vertical handle with horned projection from rim to shoulder (centre section missing); flat base; decorated in black paint with bands, hatched lozenges and wavy lines; paint worn and flaking.
Type series: type series: White Painted VI (SCE typeVI B b)
Dimensions: Diameter: 14.70 centimetres; Height: 19.60 centimetres; Weight: 315 grammes
