Description: Pottery Base Ring I miniature tankard; hand-made; slightly tapering neck with everted rim with flat top; biconical body; ring base; vertical strap handle from rim to carination with high horned thumb grip; two horizontal relief ridges around neck; lustrous mottled brown and black slip, worn in places; brown clay.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware miniature tankard; hand-made; cylindrical neck with flaring rim; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder, originally with thumb grip on rim, now missing; biconical body with low ring base; decorated with double horizontal relief bands on neck and wavy line on shoulder; thin reddish brown slip burnished to a medium lustre; pale brown fabric.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery White Painted VI ware tankard; hand-made; neck tapering slightly to a stepped rim with pointed profile; vertical strap handle from below rim to shoulder; thumb grip at rim; convex biconical body with flat base; reddish brown to black painted decoration; horizontal framed running hatched lozenges on neck, triple zig-zag on upper body and on lower body a thick band with pendant sets of four or five vertical lines to base; fabric buff on surface with pink interior; mended from sherds and partially reconstructed.
Type series: type series: White Painted VI (SCE type VI C a)
Dimensions: Diameter: 13.90 centimetres; Height: 16.50 centimetres to rim ; Height: 18 centimetres total
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in White Slip II ware; hand-made; ovoid globular body with tall and wide neck and flaring, flattened rim; ring base (chipped); strap handle from shoulder to rim; thumb grip with bifurcating tip above handle; grey fabric with small white and red inclusions; grainy white slip with matt brown paint; upper body decorated with panels filled with horizontal strokes, rosettes and verticals and horizontal rows of plain lozenges framed by double vertical rows of cross-hatched lozenges within parallel lines; below, horizontal band with complex ladder patter from which vertical bands of ladders and plain and cross-hatched lozenges descend to the base; base with plain bands criss-crossing over the centre; bands or parallel and wavy lines on rim; thumb grip with series of short horizontal strokes; handle with zig-zag decoration composed of parallel lines.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: White Painted hand-made pottery tankard; wide neck with plain rim; thumb-piece at top of handle; black painted decoration on buff ground including band of lattice-triangles and annules; matt slip.
Type series: type series: White Painted VI (SCE type VI B b)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Pottery White Slip II tankard; hand-made; slightly tapering neck, round mouth; thickened everted rim with flat top and triangular profile; high vertical handle from rim to shoulder; ring base; decorated in dark brown paint with ladder motif at maximum diameter and six pendant ladder motifs on lower body, double framed hatched running lozenges and hatched running lozenges on neck, alternating long and short pendant framed hatched running lozenges between ladder motifs on body; vertical lines and dashes rim and neck interior; vertical lines down handle and a circle with crossed double lines on the underside of the base; matt pale grey slip of variable thickness, desurfaced on one side of body; fabric grey.
Dimensions: Diameter: 11.70 centimetres; Height: 15.50 centimetres rim ; Height: 17.50 centimetres total
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in White Painted V ware; handmade; squat globular body with round base,a wide neck and an everted rim; handle fromrim to shoulder with a thumb-grip projection at the top; pale clay with buff slip and brown painted decoration; on the neck the pattern is a zigzag lattice pattern and on the body alternating zigzag and lattic patterns between vertical lines.
Culture: Middle Cypriot II; Middle Cypriot III
Type series: type series: White Painted V (SCE type, VIIB 1d)
Curators Comments: Probably found in a tomb.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description: Pottery Base Ring I ware tankard; hand-made; short tapering, slightly concave neck with everted rim with broad concave top; round mouth; vertical strap handle with thumb grip from rim to shoulder; squat ovoid body with wide ring base; decorated with horizontal relief ridge on upper neck and antithetic curves on body opposite handle; thin, mottled reddish brown to black slip burnished to a low lustre; fabric brown with grey core; chip from base and top of thumb grip missing.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot IIA-B
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description:
Pottery: White Slip I ware tankard; hand-made; depressed globular-ovoid body on a conical ring base; wide cylindrical neck with everted rim; strap handle from mid-neck to shoulder; horned thumb-grip on top of handle. 
Made of orange-buff clay with thick cream slip, decorated with orange and black paint: on body, chequer board arrangement of alternating panels with plain or hatched fill; neck decoration comprises cross-hatched ladders separated by a band of horizontal zig-zags; other motifs in the fill, including vertical lozenges and dots; orange wavy line on base and inside lip; pairs of horizontal lines on the handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery White Slip II small tankard; hand-made; slightly tapering neck, round mouth; thickened flaring rim with flat top; high vertical handle from rim to shoulder; originally with ring base, now missing; decorated in dark brown paint with ladder pattern at maximum diameter and down lower body, double framed hatched running lozenges and running lozenges on neck, dotted lines on body and rim; thick pinkish white slip, worn at rim and handle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in Black Slip II ware; handmade; squat body; squat biconical body with a rounded base and a short widening neckwith a carinated horizontal rim; high loop oval handle rising from rim to the shoulder; loop stringhole at the base of the neck; pale clay covered with a greyish black slip on the outside and half-way down the inside; decorsted with relief ornaments of horizontal parallel lines and wavy lines.
Culture: Middle Cypriot III; Late Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Black Slip II (SCE type X A 1 e)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age

Description: Pottery Base Ring II tankard; hand-made pottery; piriform body on a flaring ring base; everted rim; single strap handle from rim to shoulder with thumb grip; made of buff clay with a matt black slip, decorated with white painted decoration and a black matt slip.
Curators Comments: Malmgren erroneously attributes this vessel to Tomb 19, but no specific findspot is provided in the Register or the Catalogue.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site.; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus

Description: Pottery White Slip II (Early) tankard; hand-made; neck slightly tapering to everted rim with flat top edge; little differentiation between neck and globular body join; ring base; vertical strap handle with horned thumb projection from rim to shoulder; matt cream slip with thick dark brown painted decoration; neck with three sets of vertical framed double hatched lozenges with horizontal dotted band and vertical lozenge rows between; vertical row of hatched diamonds under handle; body with horizontal lattice with pendant alternating lattice and framed hatched lozenges; at front of body two vertical lozenge rows with arcs and dots; net pattern on base; vertical wavy lines down handle exterior; rim and neck interior with dotted bands, framed double lines and wavy lines.
Curators Comments: Almost certainly manufactured by same hand as 1897,0401.935 and possibly 1897,0401.936.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in Bichrome Wheelmade ware; wheel-made; neck widening slightly to everted rim; slight ridge at neck to body join; carinated body; ring base; handle vertical originally with thumb grip projection (now missing) from below rim to shoulder; painted red and brown decoration comprising; three alternating brown framing red bands below rim and below carination, brown maltese cross motif on neck opposite handle and on either side of body above carination, brown band at neck to shoulder join, on upper body three sets of bands comprising brown cross-hatched bands with one red line to interior framing open and filled running lozenge motif; pale cream self-slip burnished vertically on neck and horizontally on shoulder to slight lustre; fabric pinkish; surface abraded over half of vessel; s-shaped crack on base means vessel was never water tight.
Curators Comments:
See Epstein for the classic study of this ware, and papers in Åström 2001 for more recent approaches. 
Bibliography: 
Epstein C. 1966, Palestinian Bichrome Ware (Leiden: Brill)
Åström P. ed.2001, The chronology of Base-Ring ware and Bichrome Wheel-made ware (Stockholm: Royal Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in Bichrome Wheelmade ware; wheel-made; everted rim with straight neck widening to shoulder; carinated shoulder with globular body; small ring base; vertical strap handle from rim to shoulder; surface with cream self-slip, burnished vertically on neck, horinzontally on body to a slight lustre; burnishing marks visible; painted decoration in dark red and dark purple paint; ticks on rim; triple zig-zag down handle exterior; neck and shoulder decorated with three sets vertical bands with triple borders of alternating purple-red-purple framing running concentric lozenge pattern  opposite handle and vertical triple zig-zags at sides; band at neck-shoulder join; triple horizontal band of purple-red-purple at maximum diameter and below rim.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in Base Ring I ware; handmade; depressed globular body with a ring base and tapering neck with an everted horizontal rim; strap handle with thumb grip from rim to shoulder; buff clay with brown-grey mottled slip with a decorative relief ridge on the body.
Culture: Late Cypriot I; Late Cypriot II
Type series: type series: Base Ring I (SCE type VIIB 1d)
Curators Comments:
Provenance: 
All of the items in the sequence 1868,9-5.1-57 appear to be from the excavations in the Dali area in the early part of 1868, mentioned by Pierides in his letter to Newton dated 21 Feb. 1868 (Original Letters 1861-68, no. 590; see also Letter Book 1861-79, 1868 nos 16, 27 and 31). Pierides gives no details of the findspot(s) of the pottery which ranges in date from the Early and Middle Bronze Ages down to Cypro-Archaic times. Robert Hamilton Lang however relates that the initial focus of tomb digging around Dali this year took place at the base of a hill north of the village (with a well at the top known as Laksha Nicoli). It is not clear from his further observation that the local population then began to dig on a very large scale, if other cemeteries around Dali were also excavated at this time. His account implies however that the initial area of discovery was the one in which he and his colleagues - Pierides, Ceccaldi, Sandwith and Cesnola - concentrated their own digging activities (Lang 1878, 331-3), though it is quite likely that in addition all of these individuals purchased items from the local population. This might explain the chronological range of the Pierides group, though it is possible that the later material came from older cemeteries or tombs reused in the first millennium BC, if not from more than one site.
Bibliography:
Lang R.H. 1878, Cyprus: its history, its present resources, and future prospects (London).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 1D. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Other arts and crafts

Description: Pottery fragment of neck and shoulder of White Painted Wheelmade I Ware tankard; wheelmade; black matte painted decoration on exterior; free field bird in flight with one wing above body and two legs with claws horizontally to front and head painted hollow with black dot for eye tail and top of wing missing and framed zig-zag bands above and below and quadruple zig-zag on shoulder with beginnings of another framed zig-zag below; burnished to a high lustre.
Type series: type series: White Painted Wheel-made I
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard in Black Slip II ware; handmade; low biconical body; wide, tall neck tapering upwards to an everted rim; strap handle from shoulder to rim with horn-shaped thumb-grip; drab brown clay with a matt red/black slip.
Type series: type series: Black Slip II (SCE type X B 1g)
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; SCE IV/1B / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV/ 1B The Middle Cypriot Bronze Age; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1

Description: Pottery White Slip II (Early) tankard; hand-made; neck tapering to everted rim with flat top edge; globular body; ring base; vertical strap handle with horned thumb projection from rim to shoulder; slightly lustrous white slip with brown painted decoration; neck with three sets of vertical framed double hatched lozenges with hatched lozenge rows between; vertical row of hatched diamonds under handle; line at neck to body join; body with horizontal lattice with pendant alternating lattice and framed hatched lozenges; net pattern on base; vertical wavy lines down handle exterior; rim and neck interior with dotted bands, framed double lines and wavy lines.
Curators Comments: Stylistically similar to 1897,0401.934 and 935 but more carefully executed decoration and finishing.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery White Slip II (Early) ware tankard; hand-made; neck tapering to everted rim with flat top edge; little differentiation between neck and globular body join; vertical lug at neck-body join opposite handle; ring base; vertical strap handle with horned thumb projection from rim to shoulder; slightly lustrous cream slip with thick dark brown painted decoration; neck with three sets of vertical framed double hatched lozenges with horizontal dotted band and vertical lozenge rows between, two rosettes near lug; vertical row of hatched diamonds under handle; body with horizontal lattice with pendant alternating lattice and framed hatched lozenges; at front of body two vertical lozenge rows with arcs; cross and circle on base; vertical wavy lines down handle exterior; rim and neck interior with dotted bands, framed double lines and wavy lines; lozenge rows either side of lug.
Curators Comments: Almost certainly manufactured by same hand as 1897,0401.934 and possibly 1897,0401.936.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery tankard (or jug) in White Slip II ware; handmade; hemispherical body with a ring foot with a high neck and everted ledge rim; rising strap handle from rim to shoulder; made of brownish-buff clay with a thick creamy-white, matt slip and brown painted decoration; this consists of vertical  framed lozenge patterns and diamond patterns crossing a horizontal band of columns of dots framed inside parallel lines; the lower body was painted with ladder lattices and framed lozenge patterns interspersed with diamond pattern, the rim and handle were decorated with parallel lines.

Type series: type series: White Slip II (SCE type 4 jug)

Description:
Pottery White Slip I ware tankard; hand-made; ovoid body on a low ring base; wide neck with horizontal everted rim; strap handle from rim to shoulder with thumb-rest projection at the top; opposite the handle is a trefoil shaped projection
Made of red-brown clay with cream to beige slip, decorated with purple-red paint: concentric bands consisting of lines and dots, with similar vertical bands connecting them; interior rim painted with bands and groups of parallel lines; surface very abraded in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description:
Pottery: White Slip I ware tankard; hand-made; depressed globular body on a low conical ring base; wide cylindrical neck, slightly concave, with an everted rim; wide strap handle from mid-neck to shoulder (thumb-grip now missing); large pointed boss or knob projecting from base of neck.
Made of orange-buff clay with thick cream slip, decorated in red-orange paint: vertical bands enclosing lozenges and cross-hatching on the body, separated by horizontal bands: the band at the junction of body and neck encloses a frieze of lozenges; vertical lines of lozenges and dots on the body; pair of wavy lines just below the rim; the vertical bands continue as semi-wavy lines under the base; zig-zags of parallel lines on the handle, with a hollow circle within each corresponding triangle.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Johnson 1980 / Maroni de Chypre; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011b / Maroni

Description: Pottery tankard in Bichrome Wheelmade ware; wide cylindrical neck with high vertical handle from rim to shoulder; carinated shoulder and low ring base; decorated in thin reddish brown and dark brown paint; on the neck are two pairs of confronted male figures; one pair seem to be shaking hands, one figure of the other pair, who is armed with a mace and a dagger or sword, appears to be attacking the other, who is unarmed; the three unarmed figures are wearing long robes and the attacking figure is wearing a short kilt; vertical wavy and straight lines to one side of the handle; framed double zig-zag band on shoulder; dashes on rim interior; buff self-slipped surface.
Curators Comments: Additional bibliography: C. Epstein, Palestinian Bichrome Ware, Leiden: Brill (1966); P. Åström ed., The chronology of Base-Ring ware and Bichrome Wheel-made ware, Stockholm: Royal Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities (2001).
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis 1979 / Kypriaka IV; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Pottery White Painted VI teapot; hand-made; short concave neck with round mouth and flaring rim; high vertical handle from rim to shoulder; tapering tubular spout on opposite shoulder; ovoid body with rounded base; surface worn; pale cream fabric with only traces of black-brown painted bands remaining.
Type series: type series: White Painted VI (SCE type VII A a)
Bib references: SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Fragment of the body of a Late Helladic (Mycenaean) vessel of indeterminate shape; wheel-made; buff clay and slip, decorated with brown lustrous paint: rosette, scale-pattern and bands.
Culture: Late Helladic IIIA2; Late Helladic IIIB
Dimensions: Height: 7 centimetres max ; Width: 8 centimetres max

Description: Pottery miniature double vessel; wheel-made; shape is of two piriform jars, with three horizontal loop handles on the shoulders, joined at the maximum diameter; originally with a basket handle between vessels but now broken; four holes pierced through thickest area to aid firing; decorated in reddish brown paint with bands, dashes, n-motif and concentric semicircles.
Dimensions: Diameter: 5.90 centimetres of each vessel half ; Height: 7 centimetres; Width: 11.50 centimetres
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Furumark 1941 / The Mycenaean Pottery. Analysis and Classification.; Crewe 2009 / Enkomi

Description: Small kalathos or basket-shaped vase in White Painted ware; wheel-made; slightly concave, carinated body with everted rim; flat base; two opposing horizontal loop handles; buff clay and slip decorated with dark brown paint; interior has two broad concentric bands at the rim and base; on exterior, between each handle is a large latticed triangle with dots within each lozenge; four intersecting lines forming an eight-point star on the base; parallel bands of paint running around the base of the vase below the handles; solid bands on the handles; surface worn in places.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Glazed composition vessel, bucket-shaped with two loops rising above rim for handle attachment; modelled; two incised lines below upright rim; slightly concave walls widening towards slightly convex base; patches of blue glaze preserved on exterior and interior.

Description: Small fragment from the wall of a large vessel of uncertain type; wheel-made; made of greenish clay with a buff slip, decorated with stems and leaves of plants in olive brown paint.
Culture: Late Cycladic; Late Minoan IA; Late Cypriot IIC; Late Cypriot IIIA
Production place: Made in: Cyclades;  Made in: Crete (?);  Made in: Cyprus (?)
Curators Comments:
The tomb number is provided in the Register but Bailey (p. 12) observes that this is uncertain as the vase is not mentioned in the tomb lists. At the same  time, it was Walters who entered the finds from HST in the Register and he  may have had a reason for attributing this item to Tomb IV.
There are numerous views as to the identification of this ware. It is described as Late Cycladic  by Forsdyke in BMC Vases A390, but as a fragment of a Late Minoan IA vase by Bailey in HST I. Åström somewhat ambitiously ascribed it to Furumark Shape 281, despite the small size of the sherd. Vermeule and Karagoeghis in MPVP regard it as part of a 'Cypro-Mycenaean' (that is, White Painted Wheelmade III) Pastoral Style krater, though this too is uncertain.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; MPVP / Mycenaean Pictorial Vase Painting; Bailey 1976 / Hala Sultan Tekke I. Excavations 1897-1971; SCE IV/1C / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition vol. IV. Part IC. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Architecture and pottery; Kiely 2011c / Hala Sultan Tekke

Description: Pottery body sherd from a vessel in Base Ring ware or variant fabric; thin walled grey core with a black burnished slip on the outer surface, overlain with white painted dots and bands.
Curators Comments:
Originally classed as Minoan and, specifically, as Middle Minoan II in an annotation in the BM Catalogue and reported as such in the literature (see, for example, Wace and Blegen 1939, 8 note 1). This was rejected in Catling and Karageorghis (1960, 125) who confirmed a relationship with a BR fabric. 
According to a marginal note in the BM Catalogue, the sherd joins B1223 from Tomb 13 of the University of Pennsylvania Expedition to Kourion (Benson 1972, 122) and a vase illustrated by Daniel in the Bulletin of the Pennsylvania University Museum 8 (1940), pl. IV. f, where it is described as as a possible 'Syrian variety of Base Ring ware'. Note however that B1223 is listed in Benson 1972 as an unstratified fragment from Area A. 

Bibliography: 
Benson, J. 1972. Bamboula at Kourion.
Catling, H. and Karageorghis, V. Minoica in Cyprus. ABSA 55 (1960), 109-27. 
Daniel, J. 1940. Bulletin of the Pennsylvania University Museum 8. 
Stubbings, A. 1961. Mycenaean pottery in Italy. Berytus 14, p. 103, note 5. 
Berytus vol. XIV, p. 37 note 2.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus; Kiely 2011a / Kourion

Description: Pottery Red Polished ware vessel in the shape of an inverted cow horn; hand-made; tubular body with slightly swelling sides, tapering to a point; slightly everted mouth, with pairs of perforations on each side, possibly for suspension; covered with a polished slip, fired red-orange throughout, decorated with lime-filled incisions: panels composed of five or six horizontal lines arranged around the body to form a chequer-board arrangement against the red background, three incised rings around the neck; surface worn in places.
Culture: Early Cypriot III; Middle Cypriot I
Type series: type series: Red Polished III (Stewart Type XXXVIIIB)
Curators Comments:
Most of the provenanced examples of horn models come from Bellapais-Vounous though two however were found at Nicosia-Ayia Paraskevi. Their meaning may be connected with the proliferation of bull/ horned-animal imagary in the EC period, perhaps related to changes in animal husbandry and the adoption of new symbolic systems (see Webb and Frankel) 2010). 
Parallels: 
Bellapais-Vounous Tomb 9 (Dikaios 1940, 24 nos 61 and 105, pl. XXXVIII, b and e) but note the curving end and the fact that the groups of horizontal lines are arranged in friezes separated by lines around the body of the horn (cf. Karageorghis 1991, 114, Hd6 and pl. LXIV:1; also 114-5 for other examples).
Bibliography:
Dikaios P. 1940, The excavations at Vounous-Bellapais in Cyprus, 1931-2. Archaeologia 88 (London: Society of Antiquaries).
Stewart J.B. Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age. Part 4. SIMA III:4 (Uppsala: Åström).
Webb J. and Frankel D. 2010, 'Social strategies, ritual and cosmology in Early Bronze Age Cyprus: an investigation of burial data from the north coast', Levant 42, 185–209.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Karageorghis Coroplastic I / The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. I. Chalcolithic - Late Cypriot I; CVA British Museum 1 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 1, British Museum 1; Stewart CCAEBA / Corpus of Cypriot artefacts of the Early Bronze Age

Description: Pottery spouted flask or askos in Bichrome ware; the zoomorphic body consists of two globular-biconical vessels set one on top of the other, each with separate handles at the back: the smaller upper part has a small flaring spout on top- a small hole on the front and surrounding broken surface indicate the existence of a front spout as well; the lower vessel has a long spout in front with a bulbous swelling towards the end; both parts have schematic wings and fans tails on the sides and back; three crudely made stump legs, two largely restored; made with orange clay and buff slip, decorated originally with red and black paint, traces of which survive on the body and inside the top spout.
Bib references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum; Kourou 1997 / Cypriot zoomorphic askoi of the early Iron Age
Acq name (acq): Purchased from: Sir Robert Hamilton Lang
